# Introduction

# Herbs are the most extraordinary plants. Their

# incredible ability to heal on all levels of our being

# never ceases to amaze and inspire me. Through

# my years in practice as a herbalist I have been

# asked many times how I came to be in this

# profession. The story actually begins in my

# childhood.

# Herbal Roots

<!-- chunk -->

## I have loved herbs ever since I was a child. I was intrigued by

<!-- chunk -->

## their delicious scents, all so unique, and their beautiful shapes

<!-- chunk -->

## and forms. Brought up in the country, I loved being surrounded

<!-- chunk -->

## by natural beauty, to the point that I have never been able to live

<!-- chunk -->

## in a town or city. My mother gave me a piece of her garden when

<!-- chunk -->

## I was little so I could grow my own herbs and flowers. This was

<!-- chunk -->

## my favourite occupation.

## In my early twenties, while living in a cottage on a small island

## off the east coast of England, growing my own food and

<!-- chunk -->

## harvesting as much from the wild as I could, I began to learn

## about the wild herbs that were growing around me. I realised that

<!-- chunk -->

## being and that herbs have the ability to keep us balanced in body,

## mind, emotions and spirit, if we can only understand the

## many parts of the world, looking for meaning in existence that

# Global Herbal Traditions

# Today's herbalists draw on a variety of healing

# traditions, from shamanic ritual to remedies

# proven by scientific trials. Many of the world's

# traditional systems of healing share a common

# thesis: that everything in the universe, including

# plants and human beings, is composed of energy

# and matter and manifested as five elements, and

# that keeping them in balance is the key to

# ensuring health and wellbeing. This is the basis of

# the humoral system of the ancient Greek

# physicians, as well as Indian Ayurveda, traditional

# Chinese medicine, Tibetan medicine and Islamic

# Unani Tibb. Herbs play a central role in all these

# systems, preventing and treating a wide range of

# health problems in mind and body.

# The use of herbs as medicines on physical, as

# well as subtler, levels is common to all cultures,

# and has been for as far back as we know. We can

# trace the link between human life and healing

# herbs to the Neanderthal era. In 1963,

# archeologists opened the grave of a man in a cave

# in Iraq, who had been placed there 60,000 years

# ago. He had been buried with many herbs,

# including horsetail, hollyhock, St Barnaby's

# thistle, yarrow, grape hyacinth and ephedra. The

# herbs appeared to have been chosen for their

# symbolic and healing virtues, for amongst them

# were diuretics, emetics, astringents, stimulants,

# and pain relievers.

# Ancient and Modern Medicine

# With the vast network of communication that has

# developed in recent decades has come a wealth of

# information and wisdom concerning healing. This

# has engendered a considerable amount of

# integration of herbal traditions so that herbalists

# today can draw on the knowledge of a number of

# medicinal systems and philosophies, both ancient

# and modern, and can access herbs from most

# corners of the world.

<!-- chunk -->

## Some therapeutic traditions, such as Chinese, Ayurvedic, Unani

<!-- chunk -->

## and Tibetan medicine, are based on systems of healing that have

<!-- chunk -->

## remained almost intact through thousands of years and still form

<!-- chunk -->

## the primary healthcare system for a significant proportion of the

<!-- chunk -->

## population in those countries today. Many students and

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioners of Western herbal medicine study these traditions,

<!-- chunk -->

## and incorporate their ancient wisdom and practices into their own

<!-- chunk -->

## diagnostic methods and treatments.

<!-- chunk -->

## Other age-old systems of herbal healing, particularly in the

<!-- chunk -->

## Western world, have largely been broken and replaced by

<!-- chunk -->

## modern drugs and allopathy (conventional medicine). The

<!-- chunk -->

## current popularity of herbal medicine has inspired a re-evaluation

<!-- chunk -->

## of our global medical roots, with their rich source of effective

<!-- chunk -->

## medicines that certainly have their place in modern medical

<!-- chunk -->

## practice. Herbs such as garlic, ginkgo, ginseng, echinacea and St

<!-- chunk -->

## John's wort have proved themselves to the world, becoming

<!-- chunk -->

## household names in the process, and many are recommended by

<!-- chunk -->

## some doctors.

<!-- chunk -->

## In recent decades, the scientific world has identified specific

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents of herbs, as well as their properties and interactions.

<!-- chunk -->

## Modern studies into their efficacy using double-blind, clinically

<!-- chunk -->

## controlled trials have proven that herbs can be effective

<!-- chunk -->

## medicines, vindicating the ancient use of such plants that goes

<!-- chunk -->

## back thousands of years.

# Shamanic Healing

# The earliest known herbalists of every culture

# were shamans – important men or women whose

# instincts were raised to a highly intuitive level

# through years of training to develop their inner

# eye. This deeper perception enabled them to

# communicate directly with the plant and spirit

# world, and to visit other realities through their

# own spirit allies.

# Origins

<!-- chunk -->

## Shamanistic practices are said to predate all organised religions,

<!-- chunk -->

## dating back to the Paleolithic and Neolithic periods. Many

<!-- chunk -->

## shamanic traditions, including European, Tibetan, Mongolian,

<!-- chunk -->

## Korean, Japanese, and Native American from both North and

<!-- chunk -->

## South America, originally came from Siberia and

<!-- chunk -->

## metamorphosed as they traveled to other parts of the world.

<!-- chunk -->

## African slaves took their shamanic traditions to America, where

<!-- chunk -->

## they merged divination and other rituals with Christian practices

<!-- chunk -->

## to produce, for example, Haitian voodoo (vodou), Cuban

<!-- chunk -->

## santería, and Brazilian candomblé. Elsewhere, shamanism

<!-- chunk -->

## became absorbed into religion, clearly shown in, for example,

<!-- chunk -->

## Tibetan Buddhism. In some cultures, the early shamans were

<!-- chunk -->

## known as priest physicians. They were also sorcerers, magicians,

<!-- chunk -->

## diviners; intermediaries between the mortal and the spirit worlds.

# Contemporary Shamanism

<!-- chunk -->

## Today, shamanism is still alive and well especially in Siberia. It

<!-- chunk -->

## exists in a variety of different forms, mainly among indigenous

<!-- chunk -->

## peoples in rural areas, often as the main form of treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## available. It is also found in cities and shantytowns, particularly

<!-- chunk -->

## in Africa, Central America and South America, where it is an

<!-- chunk -->

## important part of the culture and used alongside, or as an

<!-- chunk -->

## alternative to, any available modern medicine. Belief in

<!-- chunk -->

## witchcraft and sorcery, known as brujeria in South America, is

<!-- chunk -->

## still prevalent in many shamanic societies. Some cultures,

<!-- chunk -->

## including several from Africa, distinguish shamans who cure

<!-- chunk -->

## from sorcerers who harm, while others believe that all shamans

<!-- chunk -->

## have the power to both cure and kill. Shamanism is also still

<!-- chunk -->

## practiced in South Korea, Japan, Vietnam, Inuit and Eskimo

<!-- chunk -->

## cultures, Papua New Guinea, Australia and Tibet.

# The Shaman's Journey

<!-- chunk -->

## In some cultures the shaman's powers are believed to be

<!-- chunk -->

## inherited, while in others a shaman follows a “calling”,

<!-- chunk -->

## sometimes from their dreams, and endures rigorous training.

<!-- chunk -->

## Initiation occurs often through a transformational experience,

<!-- chunk -->

## which could be a serious illness, or being struck by lightning. In

<!-- chunk -->

## North America, Native Americans may seek communion with

<!-- chunk -->

## the spirit world through a “vision quest”, while an aspiring

<!-- chunk -->

## shaman in South America might apprentice themselves to a

<!-- chunk -->

## respected shaman.

<!-- chunk -->

## Shamans enter altered states of consciousness, often ecstatic

<!-- chunk -->

## trance states, journeying to the beat of a drum or rattle, or using

<!-- chunk -->

## singing, music, sweat lodges, vision quests, or fasting to

<!-- chunk -->

## communicate with other realms of reality and the entities that

<!-- chunk -->

## guide them (a teacher, a spirit guide from the animal or plant

<!-- chunk -->

## world or a totem), asking for wisdom and guidance. In this way

<!-- chunk -->

## they gain their knowledge and power. The shaman's journey is

<!-- chunk -->

## intended to help the patient or community to rediscover their

<!-- chunk -->

## connection to nature and spirit. In the Ecuadorian and Peruvian

<!-- chunk -->

## rainforests, shamans are known as curanderos. Some base their

<!-- chunk -->

## healing work on the use of ayahuasca, a hallucinogenic plant that

<!-- chunk -->

## can induce divine revelation and healing, mental and emotional

<!-- chunk -->

## as well as physical. Visiting an Ayahuasquero has become

<!-- chunk -->

## popular among Western spiritual seekers who can now go on

<!-- chunk -->

## tours into the jungle for just this purpose.

<!-- chunk -->

## Other Native American shamans alter their consciousness

<!-- chunk -->

## through the use of mind altering plants such as psychedelic

<!-- chunk -->

## mushrooms, cannabis, San Pedro cactus, peyote, datura, fly

<!-- chunk -->

## agaric and salvia divinorum. In so doing, shamans can put

<!-- chunk -->

## themselves at risk. They therefore use rituals to protect

<!-- chunk -->

## themselves from enemies and rivals in the spirit and human

<!-- chunk -->

## world. Many of the plants they use are poisonous in large doses,

<!-- chunk -->

## and not being able to return from out of body experiences can be

<!-- chunk -->

## fatal. These plants are best used under the guidance of an

<!-- chunk -->

## authentic shaman.

<!-- chunk -->

## Illness in shamanism is generally attributed to spiritual causes.

<!-- chunk -->

## It could be the bad will of another towards the patient, the work

<!-- chunk -->

## of evil spirits, witchcraft or divine intervention, and both spiritual

<!-- chunk -->

## and physical methods are used to heal, depending on what is

<!-- chunk -->

## recommended in the spirit world. In the healing rituals the

<!-- chunk -->

## shaman will “enter the body” of the patient to confront and

<!-- chunk -->

## banish the spirit responsible. Incense and aromatic plants are

<!-- chunk -->

## often burnt as tools of transformation to help transport the minds

<!-- chunk -->

## of the participants to another dimension – the origins of modern

<!-- chunk -->

## aromatherapy. Spells, incantations, amulets and ritual dances are

<!-- chunk -->

## used to dispel or placate the spirits thought to be responsible for

<!-- chunk -->

## the patient's ill health.

# Humoral Medicine

# Around the time of the development of the

# Ancient Greek empire, the transition from hunter-

# gatherer to nomadic tribes, and then into farming

# communities, meant the development of trade and

# agriculture. At this time huge advances in the

# development of medicine were taking place.

<!-- chunk -->

## As densely populated centres of trade developed, they incubated

<!-- chunk -->

## epidemics of diseases including malaria, tuberculosis, measles,

<!-- chunk -->

## digestive and chest infections, caused by the insanitary living

<!-- chunk -->

## conditions. These presented challenges to shamans with their

<!-- chunk -->

## ritualistic approaches to healing. Shamanic practice and control

<!-- chunk -->

## gave way to complex philosophical systems of medical theory

<!-- chunk -->

## and practice arising from the increase in trade and travel, and the

<!-- chunk -->

## exchange of ideas between cultures of Egypt, Syria, Persia,

<!-- chunk -->

## China and India.

# The Father of Medicine

<!-- chunk -->

## The increasingly sophisticated and educated clientele of the

<!-- chunk -->

## physicians expected good results and a rationale behind their

<!-- chunk -->

## prescriptions. This was the beginning of rational medicine, and

<!-- chunk -->

## theories were developed to explain patterns of illness. Physicians

<!-- chunk -->

## studied studied anatomy, physiology and surgery at the great

<!-- chunk -->

## medical school of Alexandria in Egypt. One of the greatest

<!-- chunk -->

## legacies of this period of learning was the development of

<!-- chunk -->

## holistic medicine, largely inspired by the great 5th century BC

<!-- chunk -->

## philosopher and physician Hippocrates, who observed that the

<!-- chunk -->

## body was subject to natural laws and that susceptibility to illness

<!-- chunk -->

## depended on a person's constitution, hereditary tendencies, and

<!-- chunk -->

## the influence of environmental factors, including diet, water,

<!-- chunk -->

## hygiene, climate and society.

<!-- chunk -->

## Hippocrates has been called “the father of medicine” as he laid

<!-- chunk -->

## down many of the principles of medicine and his work formed

<!-- chunk -->

## the basis for medical theory and practice that has been developed

<!-- chunk -->

## until the present day. He emphasised the value of ethical

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine, working for the benefit of the sick and not the

<!-- chunk -->

## physician's pocket alone and this is incorporated in the

<!-- chunk -->

## Hippocratic oath still used in modern medical schools today. He

<!-- chunk -->

## taught close observation of patients through the senses, touch,

<!-- chunk -->

## smell, taste and sound and encouraged keeping written case

<!-- chunk -->

## histories and basing treatment on results. He promoted

<!-- chunk -->

## addressing the whole person, not suppression of the symptoms,

<!-- chunk -->

## and enhancing the ability of the body to heal itself through herbs,

<!-- chunk -->

## fresh air, exercise, bathing and diet. He is recorded as using

<!-- chunk -->

## around 400 herbs.

# The Five Elements

<!-- chunk -->

## Hippocrates' humoral system of medicine paralleled other great

<!-- chunk -->

## traditional systems with five element theory that existed at the

<!-- chunk -->

## time in India and China. He saw that all matter could be

<!-- chunk -->

## explained by the five basic elements, ether, air, fire, water and

<!-- chunk -->

## earth, and the individuality of people explained by the four

<!-- chunk -->

## humours arising from these elements, blood, phlegm, choler

<!-- chunk -->

## (yellow bile) and melancholy. The proportions of these humours

<!-- chunk -->

## in each person would determine their personality and body type,

<!-- chunk -->

## and their susceptibility to particular kinds of imbalance and

<!-- chunk -->

## illness. Hippocrates thus perceived that illness was not a

<!-- chunk -->

## punishment of the Gods, as believed by his forefathers, but arose

<!-- chunk -->

## from imbalances of the elements that composed everything in

<!-- chunk -->

## nature.

<!-- chunk -->

### Hippocrates, the ancient Greek

<!-- chunk -->

### physician and philosopher, is widely

<!-- chunk -->

### regarded as the father of medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

## The element earth corresponded to the melancholic humour or

<!-- chunk -->

## temperament, black bile and the season of autumn. It had a cold

<!-- chunk -->

## and dry nature, giving rise to symptoms such as constipation,

<!-- chunk -->

## arthritis, depression or anxiety. Warming herbs such as ginger

<!-- chunk -->

## and senna would be used to clear black bile and restore balance.

<!-- chunk -->

## Water corresponded to phlegm and a phlegmatic temperament.

<!-- chunk -->

## Phlegm had a cold and damp nature, epitomised by the season of

<!-- chunk -->

## winter, and gave rise to illnesses such as catarrh, respiratory

<!-- chunk -->

## infections, weight gain and fluid retention. Warming and drying

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs such as thyme, hyssop and ginger were used to clear cold

<!-- chunk -->

## and damp symptoms, and thereby restore the balance of the

<!-- chunk -->

## humours. Fire corresponded to choler, or yellow bile, related to

<!-- chunk -->

## summer. A choleric type would be hot tempered and prone to

<!-- chunk -->

## liver and digestive problems. Cooling and moistening herbs such

<!-- chunk -->

## as dandelion, violets and lettuce would help to balance the excess

<!-- chunk -->

## heat and dryness of the choleric temperament. Air corresponded

<!-- chunk -->

## to blood and the sanguine temperament, epitomised by spring. A

<!-- chunk -->

## sanguine type would be easy going and good humoured, but

<!-- chunk -->

## prone to excesses and over-indulgence, giving rise to problems

<!-- chunk -->

## such as gout and diarrhoea. Cool dry herbs such as burdock or

<!-- chunk -->

## figwort were used to balance the humours.

<!-- chunk -->

### Thyme is a warming herb and was

<!-- chunk -->

### therefore used to clear cold and damp

<!-- chunk -->

### symptoms and restore the balance of

<!-- chunk -->

### the humours in the body.

# Great Greek Herbals

<!-- chunk -->

## Another famous Greek physician was Theophrastus (372-286

<!-- chunk -->

## BC), a friend and pupil of Aristotle, who inherited Aristotle's

<!-- chunk -->

## garden and library and wrote the first important herbal, Enquiry

<!-- chunk -->

## into Plants, which has survived until today. He listed 500 healing

<!-- chunk -->

## plants, and the properties of oils and spices, basing much of his

<!-- chunk -->

## work on Aristotle's botanical writings that expanded much of

<!-- chunk -->

## Hippocrates' work. Another great source of herbal knowledge

<!-- chunk -->

## derives from the Alexandrian school, which enabled Greek

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine to flourish – it drew on Greek herbal knowledge as

<!-- chunk -->

## well as Egyptian, Sumerian and Assyrian healing traditions, and

<!-- chunk -->

## included knowledge brought back from campaigns in Asia. The

<!-- chunk -->

## strong traditions developed here survived into medieval Europe

<!-- chunk -->

## through the writers and scholars of the Arab world.

<!-- chunk -->

### Taraxacum officinale, or dandelion,

<!-- chunk -->

### was believed to balance the excess

<!-- chunk -->

### heat and dryness of the choleric

<!-- chunk -->

### temperament.

<!-- chunk -->

## Galen (131-200 AD), another notable Greek physician, studied

<!-- chunk -->

## at the Alexandrian school and later became renowned as surgeon

<!-- chunk -->

## to the gladiators in Rome, and personal physician to the Emperor

<!-- chunk -->

## Marcus Aurelius (121-180 AD). In his herbal De Simplicibus he

<!-- chunk -->

## expanded on Hippocrates' philosophy and classification of herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## into the four humours. His works became the standard medical

<!-- chunk -->

## text of Rome and later of the Arab physicians and medieval

<!-- chunk -->

## monks. His theories are still clearly to be found in Unani Tibb

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine today (pages 20-23).

<!-- chunk -->

## Pedanius Dioscorides was a Greek physician serving with the

<!-- chunk -->

## Roman army during the reign of Emperor Nero, which allowed

<!-- chunk -->

## him to travel extensively in Asia Minor. Around 60 AD he set

<!-- chunk -->

## himself the enormous task of collating all the current knowledge

<!-- chunk -->

## on medicinal plants and healing substances in one work, De

<!-- chunk -->

## Materia Medica. It included discussion of the components of

<!-- chunk -->

## perfumes and their medicinal properties, and the aromatic herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## used for these included balm, basil, coriander, fennel, garlic,

<!-- chunk -->

## hyssop, marjoram, mint, myrtle, rosemary and violet. His famous

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal provided the major source of herbal knowledge for all the

<!-- chunk -->

## herbals that followed for the next 1500 years and has been

<!-- chunk -->

## copied and quoted to the present day.

# Continuing Legacy

<!-- chunk -->

## Under the Romans the Catholic papacy grew more powerful, and

<!-- chunk -->

## the early Christians, feeling that the church, rather than

<!-- chunk -->

## physicians, should be responsible for health of mind and soul,

<!-- chunk -->

## started to repress the use of many “pagan” herbs. In 529 AD

<!-- chunk -->

## Pope Gregory the Great ruled that learning that was not in

<!-- chunk -->

## accordance with the political ambitions of the papacy should be

<!-- chunk -->

## forbidden. Thus, during the Dark Ages (around 200-800 AD)

<!-- chunk -->

## knowledge of herbs and the use of the great herbals was pushed

<!-- chunk -->

## underground and scientific research and writing in Europe came

<!-- chunk -->

## to a halt.

<!-- chunk -->

### Steiner's theory of temperaments

<!-- chunk -->

### divides personalities into four types,

<!-- chunk -->

### and explains how each type relates to

<!-- chunk -->

### the others, and the world.

<!-- chunk -->

## However, the highly sophisticated Arab culture of the time

<!-- chunk -->

## maintained and developed the healing legacy of the Greeks,

<!-- chunk -->

## merging it with their ancient folk medicine and surviving

<!-- chunk -->

## Egyptian traditions. By 900 AD, all Greek herbal and botanical

<!-- chunk -->

## texts that had survived were translated into Arabic in the cultural

<!-- chunk -->

## centres of Cairo, Damascus and Baghdad. When Arab armies

<!-- chunk -->

## invaded North Africa and Spain they took with them their

<!-- chunk -->

## knowledge of healing plants and medicine. In Spain, particularly

<!-- chunk -->

## in Cordoba, schools of medicine were established that kept alive

<!-- chunk -->

## the Greek and Arabic medical traditions in the medieval period,

<!-- chunk -->

## spreading the teachings throughout Europe. Indeed, as late as the

<!-- chunk -->

## 18th century, the standard textbook in use in medieval schools

<!-- chunk -->

## across Europe, Avicenna's Canon Medicinae or The Canon of

<!-- chunk -->

## Medicine, was a fusion of ancient Greek, Arabic and Indian

<!-- chunk -->

## systems of medicine and herbal healing.

<!-- chunk -->

## The knowledge of humoral medicine preserved by the Arabic

<!-- chunk -->

## schools can be seen in some of today's practice of herbal

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine. Rudolf Steiner, for example, derived many of his ideas

<!-- chunk -->

## of anthroposophical medicine from Graeco-Arabic thought. His

<!-- chunk -->

## four temperaments are related to the dominance of one or more

<!-- chunk -->

## of the four levels of self. Choleric with the ego (which Steiner

<!-- chunk -->

## associates with warmth and “fire”), sanguine with the astral

<!-- chunk -->

## body, phlegmatic with the etheric body, and melancholic with the

<!-- chunk -->

## physical body. The personality types described by Hans Eysenck

<!-- chunk -->

## (basically extrovert and introvert) are also divided into four

<!-- chunk -->

## different types resembling the influence of the humours.

<!-- chunk -->

## Introverted types tend to be melancholic and phlegmatic, while

<!-- chunk -->

## extroverts tend to be choleric and sanguine.

# Unani Tibb

# Between the 9th and 13th centuries, Graeco-

# Roman medicine from Hippocrates and Galen

# was assimilated by the Arabs, and an Arabic

# tradition of medicine, known as Unani Tibb,

# developed. The word Unani (meaning “Ionian”)

# reflects the strong Greek influence to this

# tradition, while Tibb means the knowledge of the

# states of the human body in health and disease.

<!-- chunk -->

## A succession of renowned Arab physicians including Albucasis,

<!-- chunk -->

## Razis and Ibn Sina (also known as Avicenna) were particularly

<!-- chunk -->

## responsible for the development of medicine at this time, adding

<!-- chunk -->

## their own inventions and discoveries to the sum of herbal and

<!-- chunk -->

## botanical knowledge. Avicenna (980-1037 AD) brought together

<!-- chunk -->

## all that was available on the nature of disease, plant medicines,

<!-- chunk -->

## aromatics and medical theories, including the teachings of

<!-- chunk -->

## Sushruta and Charaka from the Ayurvedic tradition, in his Canon

<!-- chunk -->

## Medicinae. It was Avicenna who developed the process of

<!-- chunk -->

## distillation originated in the Alexandrian school around the 3rd

<!-- chunk -->

## century. He invented the apparatus and method of alembic

<!-- chunk -->

## distillation to extract essential oils from aromatic plants – a great

<!-- chunk -->

## landmark in the history of aromatherapy. Fragrant oils were

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly used for their purifying and restorative properties at

<!-- chunk -->

## this time and were thought to reduce the impact of destructive

<!-- chunk -->

## emotions such as grief and fear on the health of the body.

# Practice in India and Beyond

<!-- chunk -->

## When the Mongols invaded Persia and Central Asia, many

<!-- chunk -->

## scholars and physicians of Unani fled to India. Once established

<!-- chunk -->

## in India, Unani Tibb then suffered setbacks under British rule,

<!-- chunk -->

## although it still flourished unofficially. In the ensuing struggle

<!-- chunk -->

## against British colonialism a friend of Mahatma Gandhi,

<!-- chunk -->

## Muhammad Ajmal Khan, founded the Unani Tibb and

<!-- chunk -->

## Ayurvedic College in Delhi in 1916, a landmark in its survival.

<!-- chunk -->

## Today Unani is practiced in Iran, Pakistan, China, India,

<!-- chunk -->

## Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, and other parts of the

<!-- chunk -->

## Middle East. In India there are now many Unani medical colleges

<!-- chunk -->

## where, after a five and half year course, graduates are awarded a

<!-- chunk -->

## BUMS (Bachelor of Unani Medicine and Surgery) degree and

<!-- chunk -->

## can practice as government approved doctors. There are about

<!-- chunk -->

## Unani medical colleges awarding postgraduate degrees. There

<!-- chunk -->

## are also schools of Unani in Australia and the US. The American

<!-- chunk -->

## Institute of Unani Medicine was founded in 1986.

# The Seven Components

<!-- chunk -->

## According to Unani, the human body is composed of seven

<!-- chunk -->

## components called Umoor e Tabaiyah, which are responsible for

<!-- chunk -->

## maintenance of health. Changes to any of these can predispose to

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalance and disease, and each need to be taken in to

<!-- chunk -->

## consideration in diagnosis and assessment of the correct

<!-- chunk -->

## treatment. These are:

<!-- chunk -->

## • Arkan (Elements)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Mizaj (Temperament)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Akhlaat (Humours)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Aaza (Organs)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Arwah (Vital forces or Neuro)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Quwa (Faculties)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Afaal (Functions)

<!-- chunk -->

## The balance of one's constitution can be disrupted by

<!-- chunk -->

## emotional, psychological, social, environmental or spiritual

<!-- chunk -->

## factors, or by diet. Environmental and lifestyle factors that are

<!-- chunk -->

## vital to good health are divided into five categories, and any

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalance of these can predispose to disturbance of the humours

<!-- chunk -->

## and lead to ill health. They are:

<!-- chunk -->

## • Fresh air

<!-- chunk -->

## • Food and drink

<!-- chunk -->

## • Movement and rest

<!-- chunk -->

## • Sleep

<!-- chunk -->

## • Emotions

# The Four Humours

<!-- chunk -->

## The four elements, known as Anasir-e-Arba (hava, pani, mitti,

<!-- chunk -->

## and dhup), are earth, water, fire and air. In varying combinations

<!-- chunk -->

## these four elements constitute four bodily humours (akhlaat):

<!-- chunk -->

## • Blood (dam)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Phlegm (kafa)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Bile (safra)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Black bile (souda)

<!-- chunk -->

## According to Unani theory, the humours develop in the liver

<!-- chunk -->

## from digested nutrients, and are carried around the body in the

<!-- chunk -->

## blood. Each person's unique balance of these substances

<!-- chunk -->

## determines his temperament, mizaj or individual metabolic

<!-- chunk -->

## constitution; a predominance of blood gives a sanguine

<!-- chunk -->

## temperament; a predominance of phlegm makes one phlegmatic;

<!-- chunk -->

## yellow bile, bilious or choleric; and black bile, melancholic. As

<!-- chunk -->

## long as these humours are in balance, the human system is

<!-- chunk -->

## healthy; it is imbalance which leads to ill health and disease.

<!-- chunk -->

### Alembic distillation was perfected by

<!-- chunk -->

### Arab physicians to extract oil from

<!-- chunk -->

### plants.

<!-- chunk -->

## Each individual has their own innate healing mechanisms, akin

<!-- chunk -->

## to ojas in Ayurveda and known in Unani as the tabiyat-e-

<!-- chunk -->

## muddabare badan, which is considered the best physician, and it

<!-- chunk -->

## is this that maintains the equilibrium of the four humours or

<!-- chunk -->

## akhlat so that we can be in good health and the happy state of

<!-- chunk -->

## mind that is our birthright.

# Disciplines and Diagnoses

<!-- chunk -->

## There are eight branches of Unani medicine resembling those in

<!-- chunk -->

## the Ayurvedic system:

<!-- chunk -->

## • Internal medicine (moalijat)

<!-- chunk -->

## • Gynaecology including obstetrics and paediatrics

<!-- chunk -->

## • Diseases of the head and neck

<!-- chunk -->

## • Toxicology

<!-- chunk -->

## • Psychiatry

<!-- chunk -->

## • Rejuvenation therapy including geriatrics

<!-- chunk -->

## • Sexology

<!-- chunk -->

## • Regimental therapy

<!-- chunk -->

## • Dietotherapy

<!-- chunk -->

## • Hydrotherapy

<!-- chunk -->

## The diagnostic skills of practitioners of Unani, known as

<!-- chunk -->

## hakims, include observation, pulse taking, questioning, palpation

<!-- chunk -->

## and urine analysis. Pulse diagnosis requires the hakim to be in a

<!-- chunk -->

## clear state of spiritual awareness to enable him to analyse the

<!-- chunk -->

## subtle qualities of the pulse. Practices including breathing and

<!-- chunk -->

## voice exercises and visualisations to help to calm and clear the

<!-- chunk -->

## mind. In the initial consultation, the Tibb practitioner will take a

<!-- chunk -->

## detailed case history from the patient and make observations of

<!-- chunk -->

## their skin, tongue, eyes, hands and nails. They will also take their

<!-- chunk -->

## pulse, as a considerable amount of information about the patient's

<!-- chunk -->

## state of health can be gleaned from this in just minutes.

<!-- chunk -->

## Unani classifies health in three different stages: health, disease

<!-- chunk -->

## and neutral. Neutral exists between health and disease when

<!-- chunk -->

## symptoms have not yet manifested. Disease occurs when the

<!-- chunk -->

## functions associated with the vital, natural and psychic forces of

<!-- chunk -->

## the body are obstructed or unbalanced due to some form of

<!-- chunk -->

## deviation.

<!-- chunk -->

## Symptoms of illness are seen in a positive light, as an

<!-- chunk -->

## opportunity to cleanse and balance us on physical, emotional,

<!-- chunk -->

## mental, as well as spiritual levels. Pain, for example, is a message

<!-- chunk -->

## that something is wrong, the underlying causes of which need to

<!-- chunk -->

## be addressed so that our health can be better in the future. A

<!-- chunk -->

## “healing crisis” is simply tabiyat, or the homoeostatic

<!-- chunk -->

## mechanisms of the body attempting to eliminate toxins through

<!-- chunk -->

## vomiting, diarrhoea, fevers, sweating, and increased urination in

<!-- chunk -->

## order to re-establish equilibrium of the humours, health and well

<!-- chunk -->

## being.

<!-- chunk -->

### The Tibb practitioner will always take

<!-- chunk -->

### the pulse of their patient.

# Treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## Unani healers follow strict ethical codes of conduct and practice,

<!-- chunk -->

## which are based on Islam. These include earning the respect of

<!-- chunk -->

## their patients, proper cleansing routines, moderation in food and

<!-- chunk -->

## drink, and spiritual purification techniques. As in Ayurvedic and

<!-- chunk -->

## Tibetan medicine, both prevention and treatment of health

<!-- chunk -->

## problems are based on each person's body type, personality and

<!-- chunk -->

## mizaj, or individual metabolic constitution.

<!-- chunk -->

## Treatment is aimed at rebalancing the patient physically,

<!-- chunk -->

## emotionally, mentally and spiritually. It is based largely on

<!-- chunk -->

## lifestyle advice, including advocating bathing, fresh air, fresh

<!-- chunk -->

## food and codes of conduct to promote and maintain health.

<!-- chunk -->

## Hakims also prescribe herbs, precious metals and stones (gold,

<!-- chunk -->

## silver, gems and pearls), detoxification and dietary regimes,

<!-- chunk -->

## minerals, and aromatherapy. Oils or attars are extracted from

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs and given singly or in combinations, according to the

<!-- chunk -->

## needs of the patient, to affect body, mind and emotions. Some of

<!-- chunk -->

## the herbs, such as saffron, fennel, caraway, haritaki (Terminalia

<!-- chunk -->

## chebula), bibhitaki (Terminalia bellerica), and amalaki (Emblica

<!-- chunk -->

## officinalis) are also used in Ayurvedic and Tibetan traditions.

<!-- chunk -->

## Other herbs used in the Unani tradition include guggulu

<!-- chunk -->

## (Commiphora mukul), ashwagandha (Withania somnifera),

<!-- chunk -->

## coriander, bacopa (Bacopa monnieri), violet, liquorice, long

<!-- chunk -->

## pepper, and guduchi (Tinospora cordifolia). Massage or

<!-- chunk -->

## cold/heat suction cups might be used, as well as puncturing

<!-- chunk -->

## certain reflex points to release a few drops of blood in acute

<!-- chunk -->

## disease.

# Food and Taste

<!-- chunk -->

## Foods and herbs are categorised according to their own miza, or

<!-- chunk -->

## balance of the humours and elements, and appropriate treatments

<!-- chunk -->

## are prescribed to suit the imbalances of an individual's

<!-- chunk -->

## constitution, which obviously vary from one person to another.

<!-- chunk -->

## Substances in foods and herbs are also classified according to

<!-- chunk -->

## whether their therapeutic effects are mild (which can be used by

<!-- chunk -->

## anyone), moderate, or powerful (includes potential poisons for

<!-- chunk -->

## use only by hakims). Qualities of hot, cold, wet and dry are also

<!-- chunk -->

## attributed to physical conditions, foods and herbs.

<!-- chunk -->

## In common with Chinese, Tibetan and Ayurvedic systems,

<!-- chunk -->

## Unani Tibb emphasises the importance of tastes as well as the

<!-- chunk -->

## manner in which food is prepared to adjust the imbalances which

<!-- chunk -->

## contribute to ill health. There are five tastes: salty, sweet, bitter,

<!-- chunk -->

## pungent, and sour, each of which affects the humours in its own

<!-- chunk -->

## way. In addition appropriate warming and cooling spices and

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs are added to cooking to help address underlying

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalances of the humours. Even the aromas from preparing,

<!-- chunk -->

## cooking, eating and digesting food contribute to the healing

<!-- chunk -->

## benefit and are taken into consideration in planning meals.

<!-- chunk -->

## Cooking and eating are seen as rituals which, if containing the

<!-- chunk -->

## right foods and herbs and practiced with a pure heart, good

<!-- chunk -->

## intent and clear focus, can help transform the energy of the meal

<!-- chunk -->

## and contribute to the healing process.

# Tibetan Medicine

# Tibetan Medicine is a highly evolved system of

# medicine that developed as a synthesis of medical

# knowledge and wisdom from Indian Ayurveda,

# Chinese medicine, Greek medicine and Unani

# Tibb. Its origins can be traced back to at least the

# 7th century. It also incorporated Buddhist

# philosophy that was introduced to Tibet over two

# thousand years ago. Being deeply rooted in

# Buddhist philosophy, its perspective is that

# physical illness is inextricably bound with

# mental, social and spiritual illness.

<!-- chunk -->

## Tibetan medicine has developed into a sophisticated and complex

<!-- chunk -->

## medical science with intricate theories about causes of disease,

<!-- chunk -->

## diagnosis and therapeutics, and has existed in its present form for

<!-- chunk -->

## over one thousand years. Sangye Menla, the “medicine Buddha”,

<!-- chunk -->

## is respected as the source of medical teachings and the inspiration

<!-- chunk -->

## for correct practice as a physician. The essential aspects of this

<!-- chunk -->

## teaching are summarised in the rGyud-Bzhi (pronunciation giu

<!-- chunk -->

## shi) or the Four Medical Tantras, the twelfth century text in four

<!-- chunk -->

## volumes, which is still taught today. The Tibetan system of

<!-- chunk -->

## healing, known as sowa rigpa, or the knowledge of healing, is

<!-- chunk -->

## still practiced in Tibet, India, Nepal, Bhutan, Sikkim, Ladakh,

<!-- chunk -->

## Siberia, China, Russia and Mongolia, as well as in parts of

<!-- chunk -->

## Europe and North America.

# The Three Humours

<!-- chunk -->

## Like other Asian systems of medicine, Tibetan medicine is based

<!-- chunk -->

## on the principle that everything in the cosmos, including human

<!-- chunk -->

## life, is composed of five elements: earth, water, fire, wind and

<!-- chunk -->

## space. These are symbols for matter, cohesion, energy,

<!-- chunk -->

## movement and space that affect the mind as well as the body. The

<!-- chunk -->

## universe and the body are a result of the interplay of these five

<!-- chunk -->

## elements, which manifest themselves in the form of energy into

<!-- chunk -->

## three humours or energies:

<!-- chunk -->

## 1. Wind (rLung, pronunciation loong) is vital for movement,

<!-- chunk -->

## responsible for breathing, circulation of bodily fluids including

<!-- chunk -->

## blood and lymph, mental activity like thinking, speech, energy,

<!-- chunk -->

## and transmission of nerve impulses. There are five

<!-- chunk -->

## subcategories of rLung each with different locations and

<!-- chunk -->

## functions: Srog-'Dzin rLung, Gyen-rGyu rLung, Khyab-Byed

<!-- chunk -->

## rLung, Me-mNyam rLung, Thur-Sel rLung.

<!-- chunk -->

## 2. Bile (mKhrispa, pronunciation Tripa) is heating energy, which

<!-- chunk -->

## regulates digestion and metabolism, liver function and

<!-- chunk -->

## maintains body temperature and the discriminating mind. The

<!-- chunk -->

## five subcategories of mKhris-pa are Ju-Byed mKhris-pa,

<!-- chunk -->

## sGrub-Byed mKhris-pa, mDangs-sGyur mKhris-pa, mThong-

<!-- chunk -->

## Byed, mKhris-pa, mDog-Sel mKhris-pa.

<!-- chunk -->

## 3. Phlegm (Badkan, pronunciation Beken) governs the structure

<!-- chunk -->

## of the physical body such as bone and muscle as well as

<!-- chunk -->

## mucous membranes. It is responsible for some aspects of

<!-- chunk -->

## digestion, the maintenance of our physical structure, joint

<!-- chunk -->

## health and mental stability. The five subcategories of Bad-kan

<!-- chunk -->

## are: rTen-Byed Bad-kan, Myag-byed Bad-kan, Myong-Byed

<!-- chunk -->

## Bad-kan, Tsim-Byed Bad-kan, Byor-Byed Bad-kan.

<!-- chunk -->

## Health depends on the equilibrium of the humours, so disease

<!-- chunk -->

## is caused when they are out of balance. The three energies are

<!-- chunk -->

## present in different proportions in each person and determine

<!-- chunk -->

## their constitution including their body shape, temperament, and

<!-- chunk -->

## susceptibility to specific health problems.

<!-- chunk -->

### Thangka painting on fabric, depicting

<!-- chunk -->

### the medicine Buddha Sangye Menia.

# Balancing the Humours

<!-- chunk -->

## Another important concept in Tibetan medicine is the dichotomy

<!-- chunk -->

## between warm and cold. Diseases, as well as remedies and food,

<!-- chunk -->

## are distinguished as warm and cold or as warming and cooling

<!-- chunk -->

## respectively. mKhrispa is warm and badkan is cool. rLung is a

<!-- chunk -->

## special case and is basically neutral, it can aggravate “warm” and

<!-- chunk -->

## “cold”, much like wind is able to boost a fire as well as cool

<!-- chunk -->

## down the body. A rLung imbalance is at the root of most

<!-- chunk -->

## diseases.

<!-- chunk -->

## The understanding of physiology is governed by the dynamic

<!-- chunk -->

## interaction of three humours (rLung, mKhrispa and badkan).

<!-- chunk -->

## Health is a dynamic equilibrium and is therefore relative because

<!-- chunk -->

## all three humours must be in a corresponding balance for each

<!-- chunk -->

## individual. The aim of Tibetan therapy is thus to restore this

<!-- chunk -->

## equilibrium in the patient.

# Diagnosis and Treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## As in Ayurveda and Unani medicine, the balance of the humours

<!-- chunk -->

## determines the constitution of each individual. This balance is

<!-- chunk -->

## influenced by our external and internal environment, including

<!-- chunk -->

## diet, lifestyle, relationships and emotional, mental and spiritual

<!-- chunk -->

## influences. The dynamic equilibrium of the humours also

<!-- chunk -->

## changes with the climate, the seasons and the ageing process. In

<!-- chunk -->

## Buddhist thought, all physical and mental suffering, and hence

<!-- chunk -->

## all illness, is caused by the three mental poisons: attachment,

<!-- chunk -->

## anger and ignorance, as well as the effect of past karma. Tibetan

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine stresses the importance of compassion in healing.

<!-- chunk -->

## Diagnosis of imbalance and disease involves observation and

<!-- chunk -->

## an in-depth interview of the patient, taking the pulse, and

<!-- chunk -->

## examining urine and faeces as well as the tongue. Once the

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalance of the humours has been ascertained, treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## specific to the individual is recommended, designed to re-

<!-- chunk -->

## establish mental harmony and equilibrium of the three humours.

<!-- chunk -->

## This can include advice on lifestyle, exercise, conduct and

<!-- chunk -->

## behaviour, healing of the mind through mantras and meditation,

<!-- chunk -->

## yoga, moxibustion (burning of the herb mugwort), the use of

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs, vegetable and mineral supplements, massage and

<!-- chunk -->

## inhalations with specially formulated herbal oils, bathing,

<!-- chunk -->

## cupping and occasionally acupuncture. Foods and herbs all

<!-- chunk -->

## consist of their own individual balance of the five elements and

<!-- chunk -->

## three humours. Foods and diets appropriate to each patient and

<!-- chunk -->

## the balance of the humours are recommended, and this includes

<!-- chunk -->

## quantities of food, and when they are eaten.

# Herbal Medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## If dietary and behavioural changes are not sufficient to remedy

<!-- chunk -->

## the condition, herbs are prescribed. The Tibetan Materia Medica

<!-- chunk -->

## consists largely of medicinal herbs, as well as minerals and, to a

<!-- chunk -->

## lesser extent, animal substances. As in Ayurveda, medicinal

<!-- chunk -->

## substances are grouped according to their properties, their taste

<!-- chunk -->

## (sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent and astringent), their potency

<!-- chunk -->

## (heavy/light, oily/rough, hot/cold and blunt/sharp) and the effect

<!-- chunk -->

## of these on the humours. Tibetan medicines are frequently

<!-- chunk -->

## composed of 20 or more different ingredients, and include one

<!-- chunk -->

## major group of ingredients and two minor ones aimed at

<!-- chunk -->

## supporting the major group and preventing unwanted side

<!-- chunk -->

## effects. Herbs that are used in the Tibetan tradition include

<!-- chunk -->

## amalaki, roses, calendula, nettles, coriander, cinnamon,

<!-- chunk -->

## cardamom, ginger, garlic, rhodiola, gentian and liquorice.

<!-- chunk -->

## Medicines are considered to be offerings to the Medicine Buddha

<!-- chunk -->

## and other medicine deities and are prepared with spiritual rituals

<!-- chunk -->

## by traditional methods of drying, grinding, mixing and pressing

<!-- chunk -->

## the plants to make pills, powders or decoctions.

<!-- chunk -->

## The annexation of Tibet by the People's Republic of China

<!-- chunk -->

## (PRC) in the 1950s had a great impact on Tibetan medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

## During the Cultural Revolution in particular, practitioners

<!-- chunk -->

## suffered great persecution, and clinical practice, study and

<!-- chunk -->

## research largely censored by the repressive Chinese.

<!-- chunk -->

## Nevertheless, Tibetan medicine has survived almost intact. His

<!-- chunk -->

## Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama lives in exile in Dharamasala and

<!-- chunk -->

## has been a powerful influence in Tibetan medicine. In 1961 he

<!-- chunk -->

## founded the Men-Tsee-Khang (the Tibetan Medical and

<!-- chunk -->

## Astrological Institute – TMAI) which has a college of Tibetan

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine, a clinic, a pharmacy that produces and dispenses

<!-- chunk -->

## medicines, and carries out research and publication of medical

<!-- chunk -->

## and astrological texts. There are other schools and clinics in

<!-- chunk -->

## Tibet, India and Nepal and recently huge pharmaceutical

<!-- chunk -->

## factories have started making traditional Tibetan formulas in

<!-- chunk -->

## China.

<!-- chunk -->

### Many herbs used in Tibetan medicine,

<!-- chunk -->

### for example garlic and ginger, are

<!-- chunk -->

### already part of our daily lives.

# Ayurvedic Medicine

# The name Ayurveda derives from two Sanskrit

# words: ayur meaning life, and veda meaning

# knowledge or science. Ayurveda is the knowledge

# or science of life. More than just a system of

# medicine, Ayurveda is a way of life encompassing

# science, religion and philosophy that enhances

# well being, increases longevity and ultimately

# enables self realisation. It aims to bring about a

# union of physical, emotional and spiritual health

# or swasthya, which is a prerequisite for attaining

# moksha or liberation.

<!-- chunk -->

### The lotus flower, with its far reaching

<!-- chunk -->

### roots, symbolises the Ayurvedic

<!-- chunk -->

### approach to deep individual healing.

<!-- chunk -->

## Ayurveda is a unique holistic system of healing based on the

<!-- chunk -->

## interaction of body, mind and spirit. It is thought to be the oldest

<!-- chunk -->

## health care system in the world with its roots going back over

<!-- chunk -->

## 5000 years into the Vedic Age. It evolved on the far reaches of

<!-- chunk -->

## the Himalayas from the deep wisdom of spiritually enlightened

<!-- chunk -->

## prophets or rishis. Their wisdom was transmitted orally from

<!-- chunk -->

## teacher to disciple and eventually set down in Sanskrit poetry

<!-- chunk -->

## known as the Vedas. These writings, dating approximately

<!-- chunk -->

## BC, distilled the prevailing historical, religious, philosophical and

<!-- chunk -->

## medical knowledge and form the basis of Indian culture. The

<!-- chunk -->

## most important of these texts are the Rig Veda and the Atharva

<!-- chunk -->

## Veda. Ayurveda has survived largely as an oral tradition until the

<!-- chunk -->

## present day, one of its greatest values being its timelessness and

<!-- chunk -->

## its application to every facet of daily living, now, as it was all

<!-- chunk -->

## those centuries ago.

<!-- chunk -->

## Ayurveda has had a strong influence on many systems of

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine, from ancient Greek medicine in the West, to traditional

<!-- chunk -->

## Chinese medicine in the East. The Chinese, Tibetan, and Islamic

<!-- chunk -->

## (Unani Tibb) systems of medicines are thought to have their

<!-- chunk -->

## roots in Ayurveda. The Buddha, who was born around 550 BC,

<!-- chunk -->

## was a follower of Ayurveda and the spread of Buddhism into

<!-- chunk -->

## Tibet during the following centuries was accompanied by

<!-- chunk -->

## increased practice of Ayurveda. The ancient civilisations were

<!-- chunk -->

## linked to one another by trade routes, campaigns and wars. Arab

<!-- chunk -->

## traders spread knowledge of Indian plants in their Materia

<!-- chunk -->

## Medicas and this knowledge was passed on to the ancient Greeks

<!-- chunk -->

## and Romans, whose practices were eventually to form the basis

<!-- chunk -->

## of European medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

## The first Ayurvedic medical school was founded around

<!-- chunk -->

## BCE by Punarvasu Atreya. He and his pupils recorded medical

<!-- chunk -->

## knowledge in treatises that would in turn influence Charaka, a

<!-- chunk -->

## scholar who lived and taught around 700 BC. His writings, the

<!-- chunk -->

## Charaka Samhita, describe 1500 plants, identifying 350 as

<!-- chunk -->

## valuable medicines. This major text is still considered the main

<!-- chunk -->

## authority today of Ayurveda and referred to constantly in both

<!-- chunk -->

## teaching and practice of Ayurveda. The second major work was

<!-- chunk -->

## the Susruta Samhita, written a century later, which forms the

<!-- chunk -->

## basis of modern surgery and is still consulted today. It describes

<!-- chunk -->

## the medicinal properties of 700 healing plants.

# The Five Elements

<!-- chunk -->

## According to Ayurveda, the origin of all aspects of existence is

<!-- chunk -->

## the field of pure intellect or consciousness, known as purusha,

<!-- chunk -->

## and this appeals to those influenced by the theories of modern

<!-- chunk -->

## quantum physics that locate the basis of the physical universe in

<!-- chunk -->

## a single unified field that directs and orchestrates the continuous

<!-- chunk -->

## flow of matter. Energy and matter are one. Ayurveda does not

<!-- chunk -->

## separate the external from the inner world. Everything that exists

<!-- chunk -->

### Ayurveda.

<!-- chunk -->

## The five elements manifest in the functioning of the five

<!-- chunk -->

## senses, and these in turn enable us to perceive and interact with

<!-- chunk -->

## the environment in which we live. Ether, air, fire, water and earth

<!-- chunk -->

## correspond to hearing, touch, vision, taste and smell respectively.

# The Three Doshas

<!-- chunk -->

## From the five elements derive three basic forces, or humours, the

<!-- chunk -->

## tridoshas, which exist in everything and influence all mental and

<!-- chunk -->

## physical processes.

<!-- chunk -->

## 1. From ether and air, vata, the air principle is created.

<!-- chunk -->

## 2. From fire and water comes pitta, the fire principle.

<!-- chunk -->

## 3. From earth and water derives the water principle, kapha.

<!-- chunk -->

## The balance of the doshas in each person will promote health

<!-- chunk -->

## and well-being, while imbalance leads to ill-health and disease.

<!-- chunk -->

## We are all born with a certain balance of doshas brought about

<!-- chunk -->

## mainly by the dosha balance in our parents at the time of our

<!-- chunk -->

## conception. This is our basic constitution (prakruti) that remains

<!-- chunk -->

## unchanged throughout our lives. The dominant dosha

<!-- chunk -->

## determines our body type, temperament and illness we may be

<!-- chunk -->

## susceptible to. Our vikruti, our present dosha balance, reflects the

<!-- chunk -->

## effect that lifestyle has on our prakruti to cause further

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalances that predispose to imbalance and ill health.

# Diagnosis and Treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## The first requirement for health in Ayurveda is proper balance of

<!-- chunk -->

## the doshas according to our prakruti. If the balance is disturbed

<!-- chunk -->

## by our diet, lifestyle or state of mind for example, illness

<!-- chunk -->

## (vyadhi) of one kind or another eventually results. The

<!-- chunk -->

## disruption may be felt in physical discomfort and pain, or in

<!-- chunk -->

## mental and emotional suffering such as fear and anxiety, anger or

<!-- chunk -->

## jealousy. Our current state of imbalance causing such symptoms

<!-- chunk -->

## to manifest is known as our vikruti.

<!-- chunk -->

## Both prakruti and vikruti can be ascertained by careful

<!-- chunk -->

## diagnosis which involves taking a detailed case history and

<!-- chunk -->

## examining the body, paying attention to build, skin and hair type,

<!-- chunk -->

## temperature of the body, digestion and bowel function, all of

<!-- chunk -->

## which point to more profound aspects of the patient's condition.

<!-- chunk -->

## Pulse and tongue diagnosis are exceptionally valuable tools for

<!-- chunk -->

## confirming analysis of health and constitution. In these respects

<!-- chunk -->

## Ayurveda has much in common with Chinese and Tibetan

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine, in which these two indicators of the state of health are

<!-- chunk -->

## also of the greatest importance. A highly complex technique for

<!-- chunk -->

## taking the patient's pulse has been developed by Ayurvedic

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioners, which requires many years of practice to perfect.

<!-- chunk -->

## Once the dosha balance has been diagnosed and the causes of

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalance have been established, treatment and lifestyle advice is

<!-- chunk -->

## given. The first step back to health is the elimination of toxins

<!-- chunk -->

## and enhancing digestion or raising digestive fire, known as agni.

<!-- chunk -->

## Treatments fall into three main categories:

<!-- chunk -->

## 1. Natural medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## 2. Dietary regimes

<!-- chunk -->

## 3. Lifestyle changes

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### as the physician of the gods and the

### patron saint of Ayurveda.

<!-- chunk -->

## These are all classified according to their effect on the three

<!-- chunk -->

## doshas. To illustrate, a health problem associated with excess

<!-- chunk -->

## kapha could be characterised by catarrh, lethargy, weight gain

<!-- chunk -->

## and fluid retention. A diet consisting of warm, dry, light food

<!-- chunk -->

## would be advised since kapha is cool and damp. Avoidance of

<!-- chunk -->

## foods with a cold, damp quality such as wheat and milk products

<!-- chunk -->

## and sugar, which would serve to increase kapha, would also be

<!-- chunk -->

## recommended. Herbal remedies would include warming spices

<!-- chunk -->

## like ginger, cinnamon, cloves and pepper to raise the digestive

<!-- chunk -->

## fire and cleanse toxins from the body. Bitters such as turmeric

<!-- chunk -->

## and aloe vera may also be prescribed.

<!-- chunk -->

## The specific choice of herbal remedy depends on its “quality”

<!-- chunk -->

## or “energy” which Ayurveda determines according to

<!-- chunk -->

## attributes (vimshati guna) such as hot, cold, wet, dry, heavy or

<!-- chunk -->

## light.

## Ayurveda also classifies remedies according to six tastes:

<!-- chunk -->

## sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter and astringent.

<!-- chunk -->

## • Sweet, sour and salty substances increase kapha and decrease

<!-- chunk -->

## vata.

<!-- chunk -->

## • Pungent, bitter and astringent tastes decrease kapha and

<!-- chunk -->

## increase vata.

<!-- chunk -->

## • Sweet, bitter and astringent taste decrease pitta and pungent,

<!-- chunk -->

## salty and sour increase pitta.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# Ayurveda Today

<!-- chunk -->

## The value of Ayurveda is proved partly by its timelessness, since

<!-- chunk -->

## it has existed as an unbroken tradition for thousands of years,

<!-- chunk -->

## despite a number of setbacks. Following the rise of the Mogul

<!-- chunk -->

## Empire in the 16th century, the dominance of Unani Tibb

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine led to the partial repression of Ayurveda in India. In the

<!-- chunk -->

## 19th century, the British dismissed it as nothing more than native

<!-- chunk -->

## superstition and in 1833, they closed all Ayurvedic schools and

<!-- chunk -->

## banned the practice of Ayurveda. Great centres of Indian

<!-- chunk -->

## learning thus fell apart and Ayurvedic knowledge retreated into

<!-- chunk -->

## the villages and temples. At the turn of the century, however,

<!-- chunk -->

## some Indian physicians and enlightened Englishmen began to re-

<!-- chunk -->

## evaluate Ayurveda, and by the time India had become

<!-- chunk -->

## independent in 1947, it had regained its reputation as a valid

<!-- chunk -->

## healing system. Today in India Ayurveda flourishes alongside

<!-- chunk -->

## Unani Tibb and Western allopathic medicine and is actively

<!-- chunk -->

## encouraged by the Indian government as an inexpensive

<!-- chunk -->

## alternative to Western drugs.

## developing countries. Here in the West, the popularity of

## Ayurveda is growing daily as more and more people recognise

# Traditional Chinese Medicine Today

<!-- chunk -->

## As in Ayurvedic medicine, these early texts are still studied and

<!-- chunk -->

## their precepts adhered to by modern practitioners of Chinese

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine. At the same time, Chinese medicine has continually

<!-- chunk -->

## been developed and refined in response to cultural and clinical

<!-- chunk -->

## advances and ongoing research. It survived through the rise and

<!-- chunk -->

## fall of several dynasties, and still exists happily in China

<!-- chunk -->

## alongside Western allopathic medicine, providing healthcare for

<!-- chunk -->

## the majority of the Chinese population. It continues to grow in

<!-- chunk -->

## the adverse effects of certain Chinese herbs.

# The Life Force

<!-- chunk -->

## The Chinese, like the Indians, regard the human body and all its

<!-- chunk -->

## functions as a microcosm of the macrocosm. All forms of life are

<!-- chunk -->

## seen to be animated by the same essential life force called qi. By

<!-- chunk -->

## breathing we take in qi from the air and pass it into the lungs,

<!-- chunk -->

## and by digesting we extract qi from food and drink and pass it

<!-- chunk -->

## into the body. When these qis meet in the bloodstream they

<!-- chunk -->

## become known as human qi, which circulates around the body as

<!-- chunk -->

## vital energy. The quality, quantity and balance of qi in each

<!-- chunk -->

## person influences their state of health and lifespan, and this in

<!-- chunk -->

## turn is affected by factors such as the season, climate, lifestyle,

<!-- chunk -->

## diet and air. Wind, dampness, dryness, heat, and cold can

<!-- chunk -->

## derange the internal balance of the body, obstructing the

<!-- chunk -->

## movement of qi in the organs. Disturbance of internal wind

<!-- chunk -->

## causes vertigo, unsteady movement, and trembling; dampness

<!-- chunk -->

## causes increases phlegm and oedema, dryness causes drying of

<!-- chunk -->

## mucus membranes, cold decreases circulation and slows

<!-- chunk -->

## metabolism, while excess heat leads to inflammation.

<!-- chunk -->

## Qi flows through a network of channels, or meridians,

<!-- chunk -->

## throughout the body, and can be stimulated and balanced using

<!-- chunk -->

## acupuncture, acupressure, diet and herbal medicine. The body is

<!-- chunk -->

## also composed of moisture, which is the fluid in the body that

<!-- chunk -->

## protects, nurtures and lubricates the tissues and blood, which is

<!-- chunk -->

## the basic material from which bone, muscle, nerves, organs and

<!-- chunk -->

## skin are made. For the body to be adequately healthy qi, moisture

<!-- chunk -->

## and blood need to circulate within a network of channels that

<!-- chunk -->

## connect all parts of the body. All illness is seen as a result of

<!-- chunk -->

## either depletion or congestion of qi, moisture and blood caused

<!-- chunk -->

## by unhealthy diets and lifestyle, stress, tension, overwork, lack

<!-- chunk -->

## of exercise or any other thing that impairs the ability of the organ

<!-- chunk -->

## networks to function properly.

<!-- chunk -->

# Yin and Yang

<!-- chunk -->

## The principles of Chinese medicine originate in traditional Taoist

<!-- chunk -->

## philosophy, China's most ancient school of thought. Central to

<!-- chunk -->

## this philosophy is the idea of fluctuation and mutability,

<!-- chunk -->

## explaining natural phenomena in terms of the constant ebb and

<!-- chunk -->

## flow of cosmic forces. Yin and yang, the two primordial cosmic

<!-- chunk -->

## forces, are concepts that are familiar to many. Yin symbolises

<!-- chunk -->

## passive, yielding force that is cold, dark, negative, contractive

<!-- chunk -->

## and female, represented by water. Yang is active, positive, hot,

<!-- chunk -->

## light, expansive and male, symbolised by fire. The constant

<!-- chunk -->

## interplay between these opposite and mutually dependent forces,

<!-- chunk -->

## produces all the change and movement in the universe. Different

<!-- chunk -->

## parts of the body are described as predominantly yin or yang. Yin

<!-- chunk -->

## is found in the internal, lower and front part of the body, in the

<!-- chunk -->

## body fluids and blood, and it governs innate instincts, while

<!-- chunk -->

## yang governs qi, vital energy and learned skills, and presides in

<!-- chunk -->

## the upper, external and back parts of the body. To maintain

<!-- chunk -->

## health, yin and yang need to be in balance.

<!-- chunk -->

### Chinese herbs are often used

<!-- chunk -->

### combined in formulae; synergy

# The Five Elements

<!-- chunk -->

## As in Ayurveda, the theory of five elements is vital to the

<!-- chunk -->

## Chinese understanding of life in all its variety. Wood, fire, earth,

<!-- chunk -->

## metal and water are the elements that compose and relate to all

<!-- chunk -->

## aspects of life, including parts of the body, vital organs,

<!-- chunk -->

## emotions, seasons, colours and tastes. To illustrate, wood relates

<!-- chunk -->

## to spring, the colour green, the liver and gall bladder, anger and

<!-- chunk -->

## the sour taste. Fire corresponds to summer, the heart and small

<!-- chunk -->

## intestine, joy and bitter taste.

<!-- chunk -->

## The constant interplay of the five elements along with that of

<!-- chunk -->

## yin and yang spark off all change and activity in nature. The

<!-- chunk -->

## fundamental relationships among the five elements are the key to

<!-- chunk -->

## understanding how our bodies and the environment interact and

<!-- chunk -->

## influence each other. To maintain good health, the elements need

<!-- chunk -->

## to be in harmony and if one element becomes over-dominant,

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalance and illness can result. Although the emphasis is on the

<!-- chunk -->

## internal causation of a disease, traditional Chinese medicine

<!-- chunk -->

## recognises that outside factors play a role. A 2nd century CE

<!-- chunk -->

## physician called Zhang Zhongjing wrote the Treatise of Cold-

<!-- chunk -->

## Damage Disorders, which described the diagnosis and treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## of diseases caused by external cold factors; in effect, this referred

<!-- chunk -->

## to infectious diseases.

# The Organ Networks

<!-- chunk -->

## The body is also divided into five functional systems called

<!-- chunk -->

## organ networks. These govern certain tissues, as well as mental

<!-- chunk -->

## and physical activities by regulating and preserving qi, moisture,

<!-- chunk -->

## blood, spirit (shen), and essence (jing). The kidney network is

<!-- chunk -->

## responsible for fluid balance in the body and also stores the

<!-- chunk -->

## essence or jing, which is responsible for fertility, growth, and

<!-- chunk -->

## regeneration. Its province is the teeth, bones, marrow, brain,

<!-- chunk -->

## inner ear, pupil of the eye, and the lower back, as well as the

<!-- chunk -->

## emotion of fear, the will, and the ability to think and see things

<!-- chunk -->

## clearly. The heart network circulates blood and is the home of the

<!-- chunk -->

## spirit (shen) and governs the mind. The spleen network governs

<!-- chunk -->

## digestion and assimilation of food and fluids, as well as digestion

<!-- chunk -->

## of information and ideas, while the liver network controls the

<!-- chunk -->

## storage of blood, flow of qi, and stability of mood and

<!-- chunk -->

## temperament. The lung network governs breathing, circulation

<!-- chunk -->

## and the distribution of moisture.

<!-- chunk -->

## This involves taking a case history which includes the patient's

## includes reading of the basic indicators of health and disease

## texture of the tongue and its coating. Pulse and tongue diagnosis

## are the principal diagnostic tools of the practitioner of Chinese

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine and enable the practitioner to detect imbalances and ill

<!-- chunk -->

## health before they show up on other modern diagnostic

<!-- chunk -->

## apparatus such as blood tests and x-rays.

# The Healing Tradition in North

# America

# Native North American herbalism was a shamanic

# tradition – ritualistic dances, playing drums and

# rattles and taking mind-altering plants such as

# peyote and datura were intended to enable the

# shaman or medicine man or woman to enter a

# trance-like visionary state to enable him or her to

# communicate with the spirit world, including the

# Great Spirit (Wakan Tanka, in the language of the

# Lakota Sioux, like a notion of God that permeates

# everything), and the soul of the ill person in order

# to bring about healing. Help was sought in this

# way for healing physical ills and troubles of the

# psyche, and to engender harmony within

# communities or between individuals.

<!-- chunk -->

## Plants were revered not only for their ability to cure diseases of

<!-- chunk -->

## the body but also imbalances in the mind, emotions and spirit.

<!-- chunk -->

## They were an inextricable part of the Native American religion

<!-- chunk -->

## and mythology, used in ceremonies and rituals. Disease was seen

<!-- chunk -->

## to be caused by human, supernatural or natural causes and the

<!-- chunk -->

## medicine man or woman was called upon to administer herbs for

<!-- chunk -->

## anything from wounds and broken bones to unfulfilled dreams,

<!-- chunk -->

## spiritual intrusion and soul loss.

<!-- chunk -->

## Everything was performed traditionally in a circle, and

<!-- chunk -->

## according to Black Elk of the Teton Dakato, the “Power of the

<!-- chunk -->

## World” always worked in circles. “All our power came to us

<!-- chunk -->

## from the sacred loop of the nation”, he said, and his people

<!-- chunk -->

## flourished as long as the circle was unbroken. “The flowering

<!-- chunk -->

## circle of the four quarters nourished it. The east gave peace and

<!-- chunk -->

## light, the south gave warmth, the west gave rain and the north

<!-- chunk -->

## with its cold and mighty wind gave strength and endurance.”

<!-- chunk -->

## A group of herbalists in 19th century North America, known

<!-- chunk -->

## as Physiomedicalists, blended together the traditions of European

<!-- chunk -->

## herbalism brought to America by the Pilgrim fathers, with the

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal wisdom of the North American Indians. These herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## included pleurisy root (Asclepias tuberosa), barberry (Berberis

<!-- chunk -->

## vulgaris), black cohosh (Actaea racemosus), gravel root

<!-- chunk -->

## (Eupatorium purpureum), boneset (Eupatorium perfoliatum),

<!-- chunk -->

## golden seal (Hydrastis Canadensis), witch hazel (Hamamelis

<!-- chunk -->

## virginaurea), poke root (Phytolacca decandra), cramp bark

<!-- chunk -->

## (Viburnum opulus) and black haw (Viburnum prunifolium). The

## Like ancient and modern herbalists, Thomson recognised the

<!-- chunk -->

## presence of the vital force that flows throughout nature and

<!-- chunk -->

## animates all in existence. Described as the spirits by the ancient

<!-- chunk -->

## Greeks and American cultures, the qi of China's medicine and

<!-- chunk -->

## philosophy, and prana of Ayurveda, the vital force is our innate

<!-- chunk -->

## healing energy that manifests itself daily in the amazing feats of

<!-- chunk -->

## the body including coughing to clear the airways of phlegm,

<!-- chunk -->

## sneezing to shift irritants from the nose, vomiting to clear the

<!-- chunk -->

## stomach of infection, and diarrhoea to remove toxins from the

<!-- chunk -->

## bowel. This self-healing mechanism is called homoestasis by

<!-- chunk -->

## modern science.

<!-- chunk -->

## Thomson also held that all bodies were composed of the four

<!-- chunk -->

## elements, earth, air, fire and water, and health derived from their

<!-- chunk -->

## harmonious interplay. Herbs were used primarily to maintain or

<!-- chunk -->

## correct this balance, and prescriptions were designed to do one

<!-- chunk -->

## of four things: astringe (tone) or relax, stimulate or sedate.

<!-- chunk -->

## Toning herbs included shepherd's purse, agrimony and beth root;

<!-- chunk -->

## relaxing herbs included crampbark and lemon balm. Ginger and

<!-- chunk -->

## cayenne were seen as stimulating while chamomile and yellow

<!-- chunk -->

## jasmine were sedating. Thomson's model of physiomedicalism

<!-- chunk -->

## was followed in America by other botanic schools, notably the

<!-- chunk -->

## Ecletics founded by Dr Wooster Beech in the 1830s, who also

<!-- chunk -->

## used native Indian traditions mixed with European knowledge

<!-- chunk -->

## and orthodox medical practices. Physiomedicalism was brought

<!-- chunk -->

## to England in 1838 by Dr Albert Coffin, and Wooster Beech

<!-- chunk -->

## arrived in the 1850s to bring Eclectic medicine to Europe.

<!-- chunk -->

## Although Thomson's ideas met with enormous opposition from

<!-- chunk -->

## allopathic doctors in America, as the same ideas have survived in

<!-- chunk -->

## Europe until more recently. They are the same ideas that formed

<!-- chunk -->

## the basis of Hippocrates' humoral medicine, and the vast systems

<!-- chunk -->

## of Chinese, Indian and Tibetan medicine.
