# Aromatherapy

# The use of essential oils distilled from highly

# scented plants is hugely popular, a natural enough

# fact given that people have enjoyed the perfumes

# of plants as far back as we can remember. Most

# ancient civilisations have used fragrant oils and

# plants; herbs, flowers and aromatic woods were

# burned in temples to purify the atmosphere and to

# please the gods. Their perfumes were believed to

# rise higher than the temple ceilings to the heavens

# where they scented the realms of Paradise. In

# Biblical times, aromatic oils were used for

# anointing and as temple incense; we read of

# spikenard, myrrh and frankincense, camphor and

# cinnamon that perfumed the rooms of temples

# and palaces. Myrrh and frankincense were

# obviously so highly valued that they were

# considered by the Magi to be worthy gifts for the

# infant Jesus.

<!-- chunk -->

## The ancient Egyptians used aromatic oils skillfully in their

<!-- chunk -->

## healing ointments and in the mummification process, and used

<!-- chunk -->

## perfumes in courtship just as we do today; Queen Cleopatra's

<!-- chunk -->

## royal barge apparently emitted the most exotic perfumes as it

<!-- chunk -->

## sailed down the Nile to meet Mark Anthony. Cleopatra is said to

<!-- chunk -->

## have bathed several times daily with essence of rose and orange

<!-- chunk -->

## blossom. The Romans loved aromatic oils, favouring rose above

<!-- chunk -->

## all for wine making, perfumes and their famous baths. When the

<!-- chunk -->

## fashion for bathing died out or when water was short, aromatic

<!-- chunk -->

## oils would be applied to skin and clothes to mask more

<!-- chunk -->

## unpleasant smells – they were particularly popular in Tudor and

<!-- chunk -->

## Elizabethan times. In the reign of Queen Elizabeth I, perfumed

<!-- chunk -->

## gloves were the height of fashion, and in fact Queen Elizabeth

<!-- chunk -->

## herself possessed her own still room for distilling oils for making

<!-- chunk -->

## the royal floral perfumes. So powerful was the effect of scent

<!-- chunk -->

## with its sensual, often mind-altering properties, that when the

<!-- chunk -->

## Crusaders returned from the Holy Land laden with perfumes of

<!-- chunk -->

## the Orient, the medieval clergy were greatly alarmed and

<!-- chunk -->

## associated it with the forces of evil. Later in the eighteenth

<!-- chunk -->

## century the House of Commons considered applying the laws of

<!-- chunk -->

## witchcraft against women who tried to seduce any of the crown's

<!-- chunk -->

## subjects into marriage with the aid of scent! Certainly the exotic

<!-- chunk -->

## fragrances of plants have traditionally been associated with the

<!-- chunk -->

## supernatural, and used in love potions as well as magical and

<!-- chunk -->

## religious ceremonies to heighten perception, and for divination.

# Healing Heritage

<!-- chunk -->

## Fragrant oils have also long been used in healing. From

<!-- chunk -->

## Hippocrates onwards we know that aromatic baths, massages and

<!-- chunk -->

## inhalations have been employed to remedy all kinds of health

<!-- chunk -->

## problems. Herbs such as rosemary, pine and juniper were burnt

<!-- chunk -->

## and pomanders were worn to keep contagion away and for

<!-- chunk -->

## protection during epidemics. With the development of scientific

<!-- chunk -->

## analysis of plants and their constituents, more has become

<!-- chunk -->

## known about the amazing range of biochemical constituents that

<!-- chunk -->

## make up the volatile oils. In the 1920s a French chemist, Rene

<!-- chunk -->

## Gattefosse, brought the healing benefits of oils to the attention of

<!-- chunk -->

## the orthodox scientific world, which by now was disregarding

<!-- chunk -->

## much of the benefit to be derived from the plant world,

<!-- chunk -->

## preferring to develop the synthesis of more powerful drugs in

<!-- chunk -->

## the laboratory. Gattefosse had a family perfume business and

<!-- chunk -->

## while experimenting in his laboratory, he burnt his arm badly

<!-- chunk -->

## and plunged it into the nearby vat of lavender oil. To his great

<!-- chunk -->

## delight his arm healed quickly with no scarring. Gattefosse was

<!-- chunk -->

## then inspired to devote much time to researching essential oils

<!-- chunk -->

## and their medical application, particularly in relation to their

<!-- chunk -->

## benefit on the skin. In 1937 he published his book

<!-- chunk -->

## Aromatherapy, the name he coined for describing the healing

<!-- chunk -->

## benefits of essential oils that is still used to this day. Gattefosse's

<!-- chunk -->

## research papers were read by a French army doctor, Jean Valnet,

<!-- chunk -->

## who was so interested in the subject he began his own clinical

<!-- chunk -->

## research using oils on soldiers as antiseptics and wound healers,

<!-- chunk -->

## and was greatly impressed by their efficacy. He then began to

<!-- chunk -->

## experiment with treating the emotional or psychological

<!-- chunk -->

## problems of war veterans, and to write extensively about

<!-- chunk -->

## aromatherapy. His Practice of Aromatherapy, published in 1964,

<!-- chunk -->

## is a standard text now for all professional aromatherapists.

<!-- chunk -->

### Essential oils are stored in dark glass

<!-- chunk -->

### bottles to preserve active ingredients

<!-- chunk -->

### that are destroyed by light and heat.

# Modern Aromatherapy

<!-- chunk -->

## The practice of aromatherapy as it exists today, using essential

<!-- chunk -->

## oils with massage for health and well-being, was actually

<!-- chunk -->

## popularised by an Austrian biochemist, Marguerite Maury. She

<!-- chunk -->

## was particularly interested in the healing and rejuvenating

<!-- chunk -->

## properties of essential oils and carried out an extensive research

<!-- chunk -->

## programme on the effectiveness of oils when absorbed through

<!-- chunk -->

## the skin. She went on to write about essential oils and publicised

<!-- chunk -->

## La Capital Jeuness in 1961, which has been reprinted and

<!-- chunk -->

## translated into English as The Secret of Life and Youth. Dr Maury

<!-- chunk -->

## opened several clinics for aromatherapy, offering massage using

<!-- chunk -->

## essential oils to treat a wide range of physical problems and to

<!-- chunk -->

## address underlying emotional and mental problems. Many

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioners have since followed her example. As well as the

<!-- chunk -->

## great versatility of the effects of essential oils, massage gives the

<!-- chunk -->

## opportunity of benefiting from the comfort of touch, and the

<!-- chunk -->

## great therapeutic value that brings.

<!-- chunk -->

## Volatile oils can be taken into the body in a variety of different

<!-- chunk -->

## ways. They can be taken in aromatic herbs in foods and drinks;

<!-- chunk -->

## diluted in a carrier oil and rubbed on to the skin, or inhaled

<!-- chunk -->

## through the nose stimulating olfactory receptor cells to carry

<!-- chunk -->

## nerve impulses to the brain, especially the limbic system, where

<!-- chunk -->

## they have the potential to affect our instinctual responses,

<!-- chunk -->

## emotions and memory. As oils are inhaled, molecules are also

<!-- chunk -->

## taken via the lungs into the bloodstream and the systemic

<!-- chunk -->

## circulation. Their actions are felt throughout the digestive tract,

<!-- chunk -->

## the urinary tract and the respiratory system, and affect sweat,

<!-- chunk -->

## salivary, vaginal and lacrimal secretions. It is probable that the

<!-- chunk -->

## oils are passed in some amount through the breast milk; fennel,

<!-- chunk -->

## dill and chamomile tea for example have been drunk for

<!-- chunk -->

## centuries by lactating women to soothe babies' colic and help

<!-- chunk -->

## induce sleep.

<!-- chunk -->

### Lavendula, or lavender, when

<!-- chunk -->

### distilled as an essential oil, was

<!-- chunk -->

### discovered by the French chemist

<!-- chunk -->

### Rene Gattefosse to be a powerful

<!-- chunk -->

### treatment for burns.

<!-- chunk -->

## When oils are absorbed through the skin during massage or

<!-- chunk -->

## baths, they stimulate nerve endings in the skin and messages are

<!-- chunk -->

## relayed to underlying tissues, muscles, blood and lymphatic

<!-- chunk -->

## vessels, and also via the nervous system to the pituitary gland,

<!-- chunk -->

## thereby having the ability to regulate the action of other

<!-- chunk -->

## endocrine glands, including the adrenals. This can be helpful in

<!-- chunk -->

## the treatment of hormonal problems and stress-related symptoms.

# Flower Remedies

# The story of flower remedies begins really with

# Dr Bach. Dr Edward Bach (1886-1936) was a

# man of deep compassion for those suffering pain

# or distress. This led him to train in medicine and

# become a respected immunologist, pathologist

# and bacteriologist. Dissatisfied, however, with

# medicine's palliative rather than curative effect on

# illness, he was driven to continue studying,

# knowing that true health and well-being comes

# from within and depends on harmony of body,

# mind, emotion and spirit. His research as a

# bacteriologist led to his discovery of the

# relationship between the bacterial population of

# the gut and chronic illness and the use of vaccines

# from these bacteria. In 1919, working in the

# London Homoeopathic Hospital, he realised the

# work and philosophy of Dr Samuel Hahnemann

# echoed much of his own approach to medicine –

# the treatment of the person, not the disease.

<!-- chunk -->

## He began to prepare his vaccines homeopathically and used them

<!-- chunk -->

## with great success. However, he still felt that he was working in

<!-- chunk -->

## the area of physical disease and not addressing the underlying

<!-- chunk -->

## causes. His understanding was that disease resulted from inner

<!-- chunk -->

## disharmony, negative thoughts and feelings, which were

<!-- chunk -->

## frequently manifested on a physical level. He saw that the strain

<!-- chunk -->

## of stress causing fear, anxiety, panic, anger, intolerance and

<!-- chunk -->

## impatience, depleted general vitality and resistance to disease.

# Dr Bach's Discoveries

<!-- chunk -->

## Dr Bach had a great love of nature and intuitively understood

<!-- chunk -->

## that remedies to emotional pain and suffering could be found

<!-- chunk -->

## among flowers, herbs and trees. So, at the height of his medical

<!-- chunk -->

## career, he left to spend the rest of his life travelling in Wales and

<!-- chunk -->

## Southern England in search of remedies to restore peace of mind

<!-- chunk -->

## and happiness which he believed to be the essential nature of our

<!-- chunk -->

## being. During this time he discovered 38 flower remedies, which

<!-- chunk -->

## provided answers to our many sufferings, derived (with the

<!-- chunk -->

## exception of one) from flowering trees and plants. He realised

<!-- chunk -->

## that the early morning dew on plants exposed to sunlight

<!-- chunk -->

## absorbed the properties of that plant better than on those growing

<!-- chunk -->

## in the shade. So he devised the “sun method” of extracting the

<!-- chunk -->

## properties of the plants. This involves floating picked flower

<!-- chunk -->

## heads in a glass bowl on top of spring water that fills it. The

<!-- chunk -->

## bowl is placed on the ground near the parent plants and exposed

<!-- chunk -->

## to sunlight for a few hours, after which time the flowers are

<!-- chunk -->

## removed carefully with a twig or a leaf. The essence is then

<!-- chunk -->

## poured into bottles half full of brandy to preserve it. The “boiling

<!-- chunk -->

## method” involves placing the plant in an enamel pan of spring

<!-- chunk -->

## water and simmering it for half an hour. Once cool, the essence

<!-- chunk -->

## is filtered and preserved in equal parts of brandy. He published

<!-- chunk -->

## his discoveries in main homoeopathic journals and produced

<!-- chunk -->

## several booklets for lay people, so that his remedies would be

<!-- chunk -->

## accessible to everyone. These included Heal Thyself, Free Thyself

<!-- chunk -->

## and The 12 Healers.

<!-- chunk -->

# The Flower Essence Society

<!-- chunk -->

## Although flower remedies are associated with Dr Bach, they

## were actually described in the 1500s by Paracelsus, who

<!-- chunk -->

## prepared remedies from dew he had collected from flowers to

<!-- chunk -->

## treat his patients' emotional problems. In the early seventies

<!-- chunk -->

## “flower power” were the words on many people's lips,

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly in California, and people would refer to “good

<!-- chunk -->

## vibrations”, and they were interested in the wisdom of the East,

<!-- chunk -->

## the power of love and meditation. Flowers were in vogue, and

<!-- chunk -->

## not surprisingly a variety of people in the healing and psychic

<!-- chunk -->

## world began to discover intuitively a whole host of new flower

<!-- chunk -->

## essences. Within the context of mind altering substances and

<!-- chunk -->

## popular New Age concepts, the profusion of flower remedies

<!-- chunk -->

## was causing some confusion, with some doubt as to whether

<!-- chunk -->

## allegations for their remarkable healing abilities was actually

<!-- chunk -->

## sound or not. Richard Katz and Patricia Kaminski were among

<!-- chunk -->

## those who were developing flower essences, having worked with

<!-- chunk -->

## the Bach flower remedies for many years, but were concerned

<!-- chunk -->

## that charlatans in the area would bring flower healing into

<!-- chunk -->

## disrepute. In 1979 they set up the Flower Essence Society (FES)

<!-- chunk -->

## to separate the wheat from the chaff, to gather case studies from

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioners worldwide to confirm the genuine effects of flower

<!-- chunk -->

## essences, and to run training courses for students and seminars

<!-- chunk -->

## for practitioners. After extensive testing of their remedies on

<!-- chunk -->

## health practitioners, the FES produced a range of flower essences

<!-- chunk -->

## called Quintessentials made from organically grown flowers

<!-- chunk -->

## cultivated around the Californian Sierra Nevada. While Dr Bach's

<!-- chunk -->

## remedies reflected the spirit of his era during the Depression,

<!-- chunk -->

## with flowers for negative emotions such as fear, anger,

<!-- chunk -->

## resentment, depression and discouragement, the Californian

<!-- chunk -->

## Flower Essences were affected by California in the 1970s. Their

<!-- chunk -->

## remedies include flowers for enhancing spiritual development,

<!-- chunk -->

## releasing sexual inhibitions and blocks to creativity and for

<!-- chunk -->

## resolving problems in relationships. From the 1970s onwards the

<!-- chunk -->

## world of flower essences has continued to blossom with ranges

<!-- chunk -->

## of flower essences originating from all corners of the world,

<!-- chunk -->

## including New Zealand, Hawaii, Alaska, Scotland, the

<!-- chunk -->

## Himalayas, Africa, the Amazon and Australia.

# The Chemistry of Herbs

# How do herbs work on the human organism?

# Much of their medicinal action can be classified

# according to a plant's therapeutic constituents,

# measured using the tools of biochemistry and

# pharmacology. However, plants also work

# synergistically – the whole being more than the

# sum of its parts – and this has been less well

# studied. As a result, many herbalists are happy to

# evaluate the healing potential of plants according

# to both modern scientific findings and more

# holistic philosophies of energy medicine.

# Re-evaluating Herbal Medicines

# Modern evaluation of herbal medicines is divided

# between “rationalistic/scientific” and “energetic”

# viewpoints. With the emergence of modern

# Western scientific medicine, herbs have been seen

# either as old fashioned and obsolete or as sources

# of pharmacological constituents to be used as

# building blocks for making drugs.

<!-- chunk -->

## For thousands of years, until the last 200 years or so, plants

<!-- chunk -->

## provided the sole source of medicines and many familiar and

<!-- chunk -->

## potent medicines of the 21st century have been derived directly

<!-- chunk -->

## or indirectly from herbs. Despite this, there are still those who

<!-- chunk -->

## persist in the view that the value of herbs is unproven

<!-- chunk -->

## scientifically. Cinchona bark, for example, is the source of

<!-- chunk -->

## quinine, the anti malaria drug, periwinkle is the source of

<!-- chunk -->

## vincristine, the anti-tumour drug, the opium poppy is the source

<!-- chunk -->

## of morphine and codeine. Atropine, aspirin, digoxin and

<!-- chunk -->

## ephedrine are all plant derived drugs found in modern

<!-- chunk -->

## pharmacological textbooks and dispensaries. At the same time,

<!-- chunk -->

## however, the unquestionable value and popularity of herbs as

<!-- chunk -->

## medicines in the last 20-30 years has prompted an increasing

<!-- chunk -->

## amount of research into the action of plant components that is

<!-- chunk -->

## not only fascinating but also greatly helpful to the modern

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioner.

<!-- chunk -->

### The bark from the Cinchona tree,

<!-- chunk -->

### native to South America, is the source

<!-- chunk -->

### of quinine in anti-malarial drugs.

<!-- chunk -->

## Alongside this enquiry into the world of herbs has come a re-

<!-- chunk -->

## emergence in popularity of more ancient systems of medicine

<!-- chunk -->

## with their “energetic” or “holistic” philosophies, as well as more

<!-- chunk -->

## modern systems of healing using plants, such as aromatherapy

<!-- chunk -->

## and flower essences. This has occurred, amid a milieu of natural

<!-- chunk -->

## healing that has challenged modern allopathic medicine to the

<!-- chunk -->

## point that now many people are conscious that valid choices exist

<!-- chunk -->

## for the patient who is embarking on a course of treatment,

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly for addressing one or more chronic problems.

# Whole Plant Medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## To stand up to scrutiny in a modern scientific world, herbalists

<!-- chunk -->

## now have to provide evidence of the efficacy and safety of the

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutic herbs they use and apply the tools of the scientific

<!-- chunk -->

## world, biochemistry and pharmacology, to their task. While

<!-- chunk -->

## herbalists advocate the use of whole plant medicines, their

<!-- chunk -->

## enquiry necessitates that, for study and evaluation purposes,

<!-- chunk -->

## ingredients are singled out and their actions are ascertained. Such

<!-- chunk -->

## research enables quality testing, identifies efficient extraction

<!-- chunk -->

## methods and provides pointers to potential side effects and herb-

<!-- chunk -->

## drug interactions. Once this is accomplished it does not,

<!-- chunk -->

## however, tell the whole story and the knowledge gained from

<!-- chunk -->

## such study needs still to be incorporated into a more overall view

<!-- chunk -->

## of the whole plant. It has long been held that a herb is more than

<!-- chunk -->

## the sum of its parts, and, despite investigations into what are seen

<!-- chunk -->

## as the active ingredients in a given plant, there are other “lesser”

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents that have an equally important role to play

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutically. These play an essential role in determining how

<!-- chunk -->

## effective the primary healing agents will be by rendering the

<!-- chunk -->

## body more or less receptive to their powers. Some of these

<!-- chunk -->

## “synergistic” substances will make the active constituents more

<!-- chunk -->

## easily assimilated and readily available in the body, while others

<!-- chunk -->

## will buffer the action of other potent plant chemicals, thus

<!-- chunk -->

## preventing the risk of side effects. It is the natural combination of

<!-- chunk -->

## both types of substances that determines the healing power and

<!-- chunk -->

## safety of any herbal medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

### Opium poppies in Tasmania,

<!-- chunk -->

### Australia; some 50% of the world's

<!-- chunk -->

### crop used in medicine is grown here.

<!-- chunk -->

## Before the development of modern scientific methods for

<!-- chunk -->

## isolating active constituents, whole plant medicines were used.

<!-- chunk -->

## Then, as science progressed, many of these constituents were

<!-- chunk -->

## able to be synthesised in the laboratory, perhaps in the

<!-- chunk -->

## assumption that synthetic compounds were similar to those

<!-- chunk -->

## derived from the plant world and as such would be assimilated

<!-- chunk -->

## just as easily by the body, and herbs became more or less

<!-- chunk -->

## redundant. However, chemical analysis of medicinal plants has

<!-- chunk -->

## demonstrated that there is a similarity in the molecular structure

<!-- chunk -->

## of components of plants and the human body, which makes the

<!-- chunk -->

## foods we eat and the herbs we use as medicines easily

<!-- chunk -->

## assimilated. The isolation and synthesis of potent active

<!-- chunk -->

## ingredients can produce an array of side-effects. Plant-derived

<!-- chunk -->

## drugs such as morphine, digoxin, ephedrine and atropine clearly

<!-- chunk -->

## need to be used with great caution. Even aspirin carries its risks

<!-- chunk -->

## and after 1986 all children's aspirin based drugs were withdrawn

<!-- chunk -->

## from the market due to their implication in association with

<!-- chunk -->

## Reye's syndrome in children, which can cause damage to the

<!-- chunk -->

## kidneys and brain.

<!-- chunk -->

### be the source of vincristine, the anti-

# Constituents of Herbal Medicines

# Through photosynthesis, plants manufacture

# carbohydrates and give off oxygen, and through

# this process they create metabolic pathways that

# provide building blocks for the production of a

# vast array of compounds.

<!-- chunk -->

## In medicinal plants these include minerals, vitamins and trace

<!-- chunk -->

## elements, and a vast assortment of substances known to have

<!-- chunk -->

## specific therapeutic actions in the body. The more widely known

<!-- chunk -->

## of these are as follows:

# Phenols

<!-- chunk -->

## Phenols, sometimes called phenolic compounds, are a large class

<!-- chunk -->

## of secondary plant compounds. They are aromatic alcohols and

<!-- chunk -->

## the building blocks of many plant components, and generally

<!-- chunk -->

## have antiseptic, antibacterial and anthelmintic actions. The

<!-- chunk -->

## simplest of the class is the antimicrobial phenol (C


<!-- chunk -->

## H


<!-- chunk -->

## OH).

<!-- chunk -->

## Another simple phenolic compound is salicylic acid, which

<!-- chunk -->

## forms glycosides found in willow, cramp bark, and

<!-- chunk -->

## meadowsweet, and has antiseptic, painkiller and has anti-

<!-- chunk -->

## inflammatory properties. It forms the basis of aspirin.

<!-- chunk -->

## Other compounds include hydroxycinnamic acids, including

<!-- chunk -->

## caffeic, ferulic and sinapic acids, which form the basis of

<!-- chunk -->

## phenolic esthers, coumarins, glycosides and lignans; also

<!-- chunk -->

## cynarin, the main constituent of globe artichoke, with its liver-

<!-- chunk -->

## protective and cholesterol-lowering actions, and curcumin, the

<!-- chunk -->

## main component from turmeric, which is famous as an anti-

<!-- chunk -->

## inflammatory agent and also for its ability to lower blood

<!-- chunk -->

## pressure and protect the liver (Pengelly, 2004).

<!-- chunk -->

## Other phenolic compounds include stilbenes, which occur in

<!-- chunk -->

## grape skins and red wine, with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory,

<!-- chunk -->

## anti-clotting and anti-allergy actions, and quinones, including

<!-- chunk -->

## anthraquinones (see overleaf) and naphthaquinones. The latter

<!-- chunk -->

## have antimicrobial and anti-tumour properties, for example

<!-- chunk -->

## juglone in walnut bark, and lapachol in pau d'arco.

# Coumarins

<!-- chunk -->

## Coumarins occur widely in plants, including black cohosh, wild

<!-- chunk -->

## oats, angelica, and horse chestnut, and they are generally

<!-- chunk -->

## antimicrobial and antifungal. The evocative smell of hay is due to

<!-- chunk -->

## the presence of coumarins that are lactones of hydroxycinnamic

<!-- chunk -->

## acids. They generally occur as glycosides, for example aesculin

<!-- chunk -->

## from horse chestnut. Dicoumarol that is originally derived from

<!-- chunk -->

## sweet clover (Melilotus officinalis) is used a strong anti-clotting

<!-- chunk -->

## agent, in the form of Warfarin, in allopathic medicine.

<!-- chunk -->

## Furanocoumarins include angelican and archangelican from

<!-- chunk -->

## angelica roots, which are antispasmodic. These need to be used

<!-- chunk -->

## cautiously as they can cause photosensitivity, increasing the

<!-- chunk -->

## effect of sunlight on the skin, but they can also be used

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutically for vitiligo and psoriasis. (Pengelly, 2004).

# Anthraquinones

<!-- chunk -->

## Anthraquinones occur as glycosides, and have a yellow-brown

<!-- chunk -->

## colour that has often been used for producing commercial dyes.

<!-- chunk -->

## They are found in senna, aloes, yellow dock, and cascara, and

<!-- chunk -->

## they pass unaltered through the stomach and small intestine, to

<!-- chunk -->

## be converted to their active form by micro-organisms. 8–12

<!-- chunk -->

## hours after ingestion, they stimulate peristalsis and inhibit water

<!-- chunk -->

## reabsorption in the large intestine, producing a laxative effect.

<!-- chunk -->

## Their peristaltic action can sometimes cause griping in the bowel,

<!-- chunk -->

## so they are best combined with herbs such as peppermint, ginger

<!-- chunk -->

## or fennel. They are contraindicated in spastic bowel problems

<!-- chunk -->

## and pregnancy, and should not be used over a long period of

<!-- chunk -->

## time as they can reduce the normal bowel reflexes and cause

<!-- chunk -->

## habituation.

# Tannins

<!-- chunk -->

## Tannins occur widely in nature, often as glycosides, and they

<!-- chunk -->

## represent the largest group of polyphenols. Tannins are the main

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutic constituents in witch hazel, agrimony, raspberry leaf,

<!-- chunk -->

## and meadowsweet. Their main therapeutic action is astringent,

<!-- chunk -->

## brought about by their ability to bind albumin, a protein in the

<!-- chunk -->

## skin and mucous membranes, to form a tight, insoluble

<!-- chunk -->

## protective layer that is resistant to infection. On the skin and in,

<!-- chunk -->

## the delicate linings of the mouth, the respirary, digestive, urinary

<!-- chunk -->

## and reproductive systems, tannins can separate bacteria that

<!-- chunk -->

## threaten to invade from their source of nutrition.

<!-- chunk -->

## Tannins occur either as hydrolysable or condensed tannins.

<!-- chunk -->

## Sxq hydrolysable tannins have the ability to protect the skin and

<!-- chunk -->

## mucosa from irritation and to reduce swelling and inflammation.

<!-- chunk -->

## They have a drying effect that is useful for curbing over-

<!-- chunk -->

## secretion of mucous, bleeding and diarrhoea. Herbs rich in

<!-- chunk -->

## tannins make useful mouthwashes for infected and bleeding

<!-- chunk -->

## gums, gargles for sore throats, eyewashes for inflamed or

<!-- chunk -->

## infected eyes, remedies for catarrh, inflammation of the GI tract,

<!-- chunk -->

## diarrhoea, and heavy menstrual bleeding, compresses to heal

<!-- chunk -->

## burns, abrasions and cuts, and lotions to bathe haemorrhoids and

<!-- chunk -->

## inflammatory skin conditions.

<!-- chunk -->

## Condensed tannins include oligomeric procyanidins, which

<!-- chunk -->

## have become widely known for their antioxidant and

<!-- chunk -->

## cardiovascular properties. They are found in green and black tea,

<!-- chunk -->

## red wine and grape seeds. Grape seed extract has been

<!-- chunk -->

## demonstrated to have strong antioxidant activity, protecting

<!-- chunk -->

## against free radical damage and cardiovascular disease, and

<!-- chunk -->

## preventing degeneration of connective tissue.

<!-- chunk -->

### Filipendula, or meadowsweet, is a

<!-- chunk -->

### source of tannin and can be used as an

<!-- chunk -->

### astringent in fighting infection.

# Flavonoids

<!-- chunk -->

## Flavonoids and flavonoid glycosides occur widely in nature and

<!-- chunk -->

## impart a yellow, orange and red colour to fruits, vegetables and

<!-- chunk -->

## flowers. With their antioxidant actions, they are an important part

<!-- chunk -->

## of our daily diet, having a beneficial effect on the heart and

<!-- chunk -->

## circulation, strengthening and healing blood vessel walls and

<!-- chunk -->

## enhancing our resilience to stress. They act synergistically with

<!-- chunk -->

## ascorbic acid to enhance the body's ability to metabolise it.

<!-- chunk -->

## Flavonoids are also anti-inflammatory (e.g. quercitrin), hepato-

<!-- chunk -->

## protective (e.g. silymarin and quercitrin), anti-tumour, anti-viral

<!-- chunk -->

## and hypotensive. Herbs rich in flavonoids (e.g. kaempherol,

<!-- chunk -->

## myricitin, quercitrin) protect against cardiovascular disease and

<!-- chunk -->

## are used to treat vascular problems, including for example

<!-- chunk -->

## venous insufficiency, bruising, piles and nose bleeds.

<!-- chunk -->

## Isoflavones, such as genistein from soya, have a similar

<!-- chunk -->

## structure to oestrogen. They bind to oestrogen receptors in the

<!-- chunk -->

## body and are known as phytoestrogens. They occur in herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## includingare shatavari, wild indigo, liquorice, red clover and

<!-- chunk -->

## black cohosh. They have been found to help prevent tumours

<!-- chunk -->

## and breast cancer, and to relieve menopausal symptoms.

<!-- chunk -->

## Anthocyanins and anthocyanidins are found in red, blue and

<!-- chunk -->

## black fruits, and particularly found in high amounts in grape

<!-- chunk -->

## skins, elderberries and bilberries. They also occur in herbs,

<!-- chunk -->

## including ginkgo, cat's claw and corn silk. They have antioxidant

<!-- chunk -->

## actions that protect against oxidative damage, particularly in the

<!-- chunk -->

## eyes and connective tissue.

# Terpenes

<!-- chunk -->

## Terpenes, or terpenoids, occur widely in a variety of forms,

<!-- chunk -->

## including monoterpenes, sesquiterpenes and triterpenes.

<!-- chunk -->

## Monoterpenes are the main components of volatile oils (see

<!-- chunk -->

## next page), and include bitter iridoids, as in the sedative

<!-- chunk -->

## valepotriates in valerian, hypotensive asperulsides in cleavers,

<!-- chunk -->

## and paeoniflorin in peony, which has anti-inflammatory,

<!-- chunk -->

## febrifuge and sedative actions.

<!-- chunk -->

### Cimicifuga, or black cohosh, contains

<!-- chunk -->

### isoflavones, which have been found

<!-- chunk -->

### to prevent tumours.

<!-- chunk -->

## Sesquiterpenes are also found in volatile oils or as lactones,

<!-- chunk -->

## and have a bitter taste, anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial

<!-- chunk -->

## actions. Sesquiterpenes are found in myrrh, hops, German

<!-- chunk -->

## chamomile and vitex, and sesquiterpene lactones occur in

<!-- chunk -->

## boneset, feverfew, yarrow, wormwood, globe artichoke and

<!-- chunk -->

## elecampane.

<!-- chunk -->

## Triterpenes have a similar structure to steroids (see below).

# Bitters

<!-- chunk -->

## Bitter principles is a term for a group of chemicals that have a

<!-- chunk -->

## very bitter taste and a cooling effect. They are diverse in structure

<!-- chunk -->

## but have certain therapeutic actions in common, and include

<!-- chunk -->

## mostly terpenes, flavonoids and some alkaloids. Through their

<!-- chunk -->

## effect on the bitter receptors on the tongue, they promote

<!-- chunk -->

## secretion of digestive enzymes from the stomach and intestines,

<!-- chunk -->

## flow of bile from the liver and release of hormones.

<!-- chunk -->

## Bitters are prescribed for poor appetite and digestion, gastritis,

<!-- chunk -->

## heartburn, to regulate blood sugar, to relieve allergies and

<!-- chunk -->

## inflammation and to aid convalescence. Many bitter herbs have

<!-- chunk -->

## other actions; some are relaxant or sedative like hops and

<!-- chunk -->

## valerian, others are anti-inflammatory like devil's claw, and some,

<!-- chunk -->

## like marigold, exert a beneficial action on the immune system,

<!-- chunk -->

## acting as natural antibiotics and anti-neoplastics. Well known

<!-- chunk -->

## “bitter tonics” include dandelion, cleavers, blessed thistle,

<!-- chunk -->

## wormwood, dock root and gentian.

# Triterpenoids and Saponins

<!-- chunk -->

## Triterpenoids represent a large and diverse group that includes

<!-- chunk -->

## phytosterols, triterpenoid saponins, steroidal saponins and

<!-- chunk -->

## cardiac glycodises.

<!-- chunk -->

### The leaves of Cynara scolymus, or

<!-- chunk -->

### globe artichoke, contain sequiterpene

<!-- chunk -->

### actones, which can reduce

<!-- chunk -->

### inflamation and protect against


# Phytosterols

<!-- chunk -->

## Phytosterols such as sitosterol and stigmasterol are vital to the

<!-- chunk -->

## formation of cell membranes and help regulate cholesterol, for

<!-- chunk -->

## example guggulsterones in guggulu which lower cholesterol and

<!-- chunk -->

## triglycerides by their regulatory effect on the thyroid are a good

<!-- chunk -->

## example. Phytosterols have been used as building blocks for

<!-- chunk -->

## making steroid drugs and may have the ability to inhibit tumour

<!-- chunk -->

## formation; withanolides in ashwagandha, for example, have

<!-- chunk -->

## antitumour and hepatoprotective properties (Pengelly, 2004).

# Saponins

<!-- chunk -->

## Saponins are glycosides that form a soap-like lather when they

<!-- chunk -->

## are mixed with water and precipitate cholesterol. Herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## containing saponins have a bitter taste and haemolytic activity.

<!-- chunk -->

## They can dissolve red blood cells walls so should never be

<!-- chunk -->

## injected into the blood stream. Taken orally, however, they are

<!-- chunk -->

## hardly absorbed through an intact intestine and help to promote

<!-- chunk -->

## digestion and absorption, for example of nutrients including

<!-- chunk -->

## calcium and silicon. Some, like horse chestnut, have a beneficial

<!-- chunk -->

## action on blood vessel walls, some decrease blood coagulation,

<!-- chunk -->

## blood sugar and cholesterol levels (Tillotson, 2001). Some, like

<!-- chunk -->

## goldenrod and horsetail, are duiretic. Others like mullein are

<!-- chunk -->

## expectorant, and several have hepato-protective and immuno-

<!-- chunk -->

## modulating effects, for example Korean ginseng and liquorice.

# Triterpenoid saponins

<!-- chunk -->

## These help regulate steroidal hormonal activity and counter the

<!-- chunk -->

## effects of stress, and often have antifungal properties. Herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## containing these hormone-regulating properties are known as

<!-- chunk -->

## adaptogens, the most famous of which is panax ginseng. Others

<!-- chunk -->

## include liquorice, wild yam and fenugreek. Some, like wild yam

<!-- chunk -->

## and liquorice, act as anti-inflammatories.

<!-- chunk -->

### Solidago virgaurea, or goldenrod,

<!-- chunk -->

### contains saponins, which promote

<!-- chunk -->

### digestion and absorption.

# Steroidal saponins

<!-- chunk -->

## These, such as diosgenin from wild yam, are used in the body as

<!-- chunk -->

## building blocks for the production hormones secreted by the

<!-- chunk -->

## testes, ovaries and adrenal glands, and for vitamin D.

# Cardiac glycosides

<!-- chunk -->

## Discovered in 1785 in foxglove, these have been widely

<!-- chunk -->

## researched for their ability to increase cardiac output by effecting

<!-- chunk -->

## the force and speed of heart contractions, which is beneficial in

<!-- chunk -->

## dealing with heart failure. Herbs containing these are generally

<!-- chunk -->

## for use by practitioners only.

# Volatile Oils

<!-- chunk -->

## The exotic perfumes and delicious tastes of aromatic herbs are

<!-- chunk -->

## derived from volatile oils, which are complex combinations

<!-- chunk -->

## compounds, and the different combinations of these produce the

<!-- chunk -->

## wide variation in scent and therapeutic effects in the herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## containing them. Up to 60 different chemical constituents have

<!-- chunk -->

## been identified in some oils. Categories of volatile oils include

<!-- chunk -->

## terpenoids, including monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes and

<!-- chunk -->

## phenylpropanoids. Herbs rich in volatile oils have to be stored

<!-- chunk -->

## carefully in sealed bottles or containers as volatile oils can

<!-- chunk -->

## evaporate easily.

<!-- chunk -->

## All volatile oils are antiseptic, stimulating the production of

<!-- chunk -->

## white blood cells and enhancing immunity. Many oils have

<!-- chunk -->

## antibacterial, antifungal and antiviral actions, as well as anti-

<!-- chunk -->

## inflammatory and antispasmodic properties, especially those

<!-- chunk -->

## containing sesquiterpenes, such as for example azulene in

<!-- chunk -->

## German chamomile which is particularly applicable for the relief

<!-- chunk -->

## of inflamed and irritated conditions of the digestive tract, while

<!-- chunk -->

## those in dill relax spasm and colicky pain in the gut. Some oils

<!-- chunk -->

## have an expectorant action such as in thyme and hyssop, clearing

<!-- chunk -->

## mucous from the chest, while others are diuretic, useful for fluid

<!-- chunk -->

## retention and urinary infections. While they exert their beneficial

<!-- chunk -->

## effects on the physical body, they also reach the brain and

<!-- chunk -->

## nervous system and have a wide range of mento-emotional

<!-- chunk -->

## applications.

# Fixed Oils

<!-- chunk -->

## These are the lipids found in all plants, especially in the seeds,

<!-- chunk -->

## and they contain fatty acids which are either saturated,

<!-- chunk -->

## monounsaturated or polyunsaturated. They are vital for growth

<!-- chunk -->

## and health, the formation of cell membranes andthe healthy

<!-- chunk -->

## functioning of the immune and cardiovascular systems. Two

<!-- chunk -->

## fixed oils that exist in every cell, particularly in the nervous

<!-- chunk -->

## system, known as essential fatty acids, are linoleic (found in

<!-- chunk -->

## evening primrose oil, and saw palmetto berries), and linolenic

<!-- chunk -->

## acid (found in flax seed). These essential fatty acids are not able

<!-- chunk -->

## to be synthesised in the body and so need to be taken in through

<!-- chunk -->

## our diet. In the body linoleic acid is converted into gamma

<!-- chunk -->

## linolenic acid (GLA); atopic allergies such as eczema and asthma

<!-- chunk -->

## and other immune problems have been related to the lack of the

<!-- chunk -->

## enzyme responsible for this conversion in some individuals.

<!-- chunk -->

## Evening primrose oil contains GLA and for this reason is very

<!-- chunk -->

## useful for treating such problems.

# Polysaccharides

<!-- chunk -->

## These large sugar molecules are found widely in the plant world,

<!-- chunk -->

## for example in fructose, glucose, and cellulose, and consist of

<!-- chunk -->

## chains of sugars linked to other molecules. They include

<!-- chunk -->

## mucilage, gums, and fructans. Some polysaccharides,

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly beta-glucans found in, for example, reishi and

<!-- chunk -->

## shiitaki mushrooms, have immune-stimulating properties. They

<!-- chunk -->

## achieve this through throughactivating cytokines which enhance

<!-- chunk -->

## the production of white blood cells and antibodies, and with their

<!-- chunk -->

## anti-inflammatory and anti-tumour properties. Liquorice,

<!-- chunk -->

## codonopsis, aloe vera, rehmania and cinnamon also contain

<!-- chunk -->

## immune-stimulating polysaccharides.

# Mucilage

<!-- chunk -->

## This is a sugary, gel-like substance with the ability to draw water

<!-- chunk -->

## to it to form as viscous fluid. When taken orally, mucilage coats

<!-- chunk -->

## the mucous membranes of the digestive, respiratory and genito-

<!-- chunk -->

## urinary tracts and protects them from irritation and inflammation.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs rich in mucilage including slippery elm, marshmallow and

<!-- chunk -->

## plantain are prescribed for their cooling and soothing properties.

<!-- chunk -->

## They can relieve diarrhoea by reducing peristalsis caused by

<!-- chunk -->

## irritation of the gut lining, but can also be used as laxatives as

<!-- chunk -->

## they absorb water into the bowel and bulk out the stool, e.g.

<!-- chunk -->

## psyllium seeds.

<!-- chunk -->

### Aloe Barbadensis, or aloe vera,

<!-- chunk -->

### contains polysaccharides, which

<!-- chunk -->

### stimulate the immune system.

# Gums

<!-- chunk -->

## These are protective and healing exudates composed of

<!-- chunk -->

## monosaccharides which are released when a plant is damaged.

<!-- chunk -->

## Those in guggulu enhance the liver's metabolism of cholesterol

<!-- chunk -->

## by promoting the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the blood

<!-- chunk -->

## (Tillotson, 2001). Marigold is high in gums with antimicrobial,

<!-- chunk -->

## antifungal and anti-inflammatory effects.

# Fructans

<!-- chunk -->

## These are composed of fructose and occur especially in the

<!-- chunk -->

## Asteraceae family as inulin. Herbs rich in inulin include

<!-- chunk -->

## elecampane, globe artichoke, goldenrod, gentian, codonopsis and

<!-- chunk -->

## burdock. Inulin helps regulate blood sugar and enhances the

<!-- chunk -->

## immune system by acting as a prebiotic to nourish the beneficial

<!-- chunk -->

## flora in the gut.

<!-- chunk -->

### Calendula officinalis, or marigold, is

<!-- chunk -->

### high in gums.

# Alkaloids

<!-- chunk -->

## A diverse group of chemicals that contain a nitrogen-bearing

<!-- chunk -->

## molecule and are pharmacologically very potent. Many of the

<!-- chunk -->

## more toxic plants contain alkaloids, such as atropine in

<!-- chunk -->

## belladonna and morphine from the opium poppy, the first

<!-- chunk -->

## alkaloid to be isolated in 1806 (Tillotson, 2001). Caffeine,

<!-- chunk -->

## ephedrine, quinine, strychnine, piperine, nicotine and codeine are

<!-- chunk -->

## all alkaloids with diverse actions, ranging from stimulants,

<!-- chunk -->

## bronchodilators, antimicrobials and anti-inflammatories, to

<!-- chunk -->

## narcotics and painkillers.

# The Herbal Consultation

# Before you make a diagnosis, prescribe remedies

# and prepare herbal medicines, it is important to

# understand the concepts of holism and

# homeostasis, and how plants can enhance the

# body's own innate healing processes. Treating

# underlying causes and not simply addressing

# symptoms forms the basis of a herbalist's

# practice, and every consultation, treatment plan

# and herbal prescription is tailored to each

# individual patient's needs, with the aim of

# bringing positive and lasting results.

# Healing the Whole Person

# Modern medical herbalism is a synthesis of

# ancient and modern theories and practices. Its

# underlying philosophy is that health is intimately

# connected to the harmony of body, mind and

# spirit, which enables a balance of natural forces in

# the body. In a clinical context the herbalist will

# interpret symptoms of ill health as a disturbance

# of this balance, and consider them in the context

# of the patient as a whole, their lives, both inner

# and outer.

<!-- chunk -->

## As Dr Edward Bach, famed for his flower remedies, said: “…

<!-- chunk -->

## disease of the body itself is nothing but the result of the

<!-- chunk -->

## disharmony between the soul and mind” and “…health is

## therefore the true realisation of what we are; we are perfect; we

# Using Herbs as Medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbalists use the leaves, flowers, stems, berries, roots or seeds

<!-- chunk -->

## of medicinal plants as their therapeutic tools. By definition a herb

<!-- chunk -->

## is any plant that has a medicinal action in the body, and this

<!-- chunk -->

## includes most fruits and vegetables. In fact herbs act very much

<!-- chunk -->

## like foods, and many common foods are used for their medicinal

<!-- chunk -->

## actions: carrots are good for skin and urinary problems; oats are

<!-- chunk -->

## a great tonic to the nervous system, garlic fights infection,

<!-- chunk -->

## regulates blood pressure and prevents cholesterol and blueberries

<!-- chunk -->

## combat free radicals, strengthen blood vessels and help prevent

<!-- chunk -->

## urinary tract infections.

<!-- chunk -->

## Plants absorb, process and store vital nutrients from the soil,

<!-- chunk -->

## providing raw materials (close in chemical composition to those

<!-- chunk -->

## that make up the human body) for the growth and repair of all

<!-- chunk -->

## bodily tissues that are easily digested and assimilated. Their

<!-- chunk -->

## vitamins, minerals, and trace elements are vital for health and

<!-- chunk -->

## recovery, while other medicinal substances such as tannins,

<!-- chunk -->

## volatile oils, phenols and saponins have affinities for particular

<!-- chunk -->

## tissues and systems and act more specifically to promote

<!-- chunk -->

## homeostasis and healing.

<!-- chunk -->

## Clearly, then, herbs operate at the level of biochemical

<!-- chunk -->

## reactions in the body, but they are capable of much more. They

<!-- chunk -->

## certainly provide us with a wealth of wonderful chemicals but

<!-- chunk -->

## their healing power goes far beyond the physical to the realms of

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## our hearts and minds, for they help to restore harmony to an

<!-- chunk -->

## integrated whole.

# The First Visit

# It is worth recommending to patients that they

# prepare for a first visit to a herbalist by compiling

# lists of present symptoms, past medical and drug

# history, illnesses and operations as far back as

# infancy. Their immediate family may provide

# extra information that has been forgotten about,

# for example breast feeding and illness, as well as

# temperament in early childhood.

<!-- chunk -->

## Medical reports from other consultants, as well as blood profiles,

<!-- chunk -->

## urine analyses, allergy tests, x-ray or scan reports, can provide

<!-- chunk -->

## important information. A diary of food eaten over the previous

<!-- chunk -->

## weeks will also be helpful to the practitioner when analysing the

<!-- chunk -->

## diet. A herbalist will always enquire into mento-emotional

<!-- chunk -->

## realms, and some patients may find it helpful to prepare for this

<!-- chunk -->

## since they may find it hard to talk about painful experiences, or

<!-- chunk -->

## may not be accustomed to talking about themselves.

# Individual Evaluation

<!-- chunk -->

## The consultation begins the minute patient meets practitioner.

<!-- chunk -->

## Consciously or unconsciously, the practitioner will be assessing

<!-- chunk -->

## the patient. The build of the body, the hue and tone of the skin,

<!-- chunk -->

## the brightness of the eyes and hair, the colour of the lips, the

<!-- chunk -->

## expression on the face, the tone of voice, general appearance and

<!-- chunk -->

## dress sense all begin to tell the story. Then there is body

<!-- chunk -->

## language; the expression in the face, the level of tension in the

<!-- chunk -->

## muscles, gait and posture all convey important messages.

<!-- chunk -->

## During the consultation the patient is given time and

<!-- chunk -->

## opportunity to describe their concerns in detail. Each person is

<!-- chunk -->

## evaluated as an individual by the herbalist, who records and

<!-- chunk -->

## analyses current presenting symptoms in relation to the complete

<!-- chunk -->

## medical history in order to understand the underlying causes and

<!-- chunk -->

## contributing factors that have made the patient seek help.

<!-- chunk -->

## A case history includes:

## • main presenting symptoms

<!-- chunk -->

## relaxation

## • appetite, digestion and elimination

<!-- chunk -->

## • thirst and sweat

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## • sleep

## • energy

## Through questioning, the practitioner will systematically go

<!-- chunk -->

# Treatment

# The treatment of most ailments begins at home.

# Many people are almost unwittingly using herbal

# medicine in common household remedies like salt

# gargles for sore throats, hot lemon and honey

# drinks for colds and catarrh, chamomile tea for

# sleep, peppermint to settle the stomach, vinegar

# for wasp stings and dock leaves for nettle stings.

<!-- chunk -->

## The more you can learn about simple remedies for minor

<!-- chunk -->

## ailments, which could be sitting in your larder, growing in your

<!-- chunk -->

## garden or wild in the hedgerows, the more opportunity you will

<!-- chunk -->

## have to treat the first signs of acute infections and minor ailments

<!-- chunk -->

## without the necessity of drugs such as antibiotics, and thereby

<!-- chunk -->

## help to prevent the development of more serious disorders.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs used in this way make excellent preventive medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## and can enhance general well-being when taken in conjunction

<!-- chunk -->

## with a healthy diet and lifestyle. For more chronic or serious

<!-- chunk -->

## disorders it is advisable to consult a professional herbalist who

<!-- chunk -->

## uses herbs in the context of a holistic approach to healing, where

<!-- chunk -->

## physical symptoms are viewed in relation to other factors,

<!-- chunk -->

## including temperament, stress, social, domestic and working

<!-- chunk -->

## environment, relationships, diet, relaxation and exercise. All play

<!-- chunk -->

## a part in the emergence of an individual pattern of symptoms.

# Who Consults a Herbalist?

<!-- chunk -->

## Most people who consult a herbalist present with chronic

<!-- chunk -->

## disorders rather than acute symptoms. They may be seeking a

<!-- chunk -->

## more natural alternative or complement to allopathic drugs from

<!-- chunk -->

## their doctor for their disorder, that addresses causes rather than

<!-- chunk -->

## symptoms or they may have been treated unsuccessfully

<!-- chunk -->

## elsewhere. Frequently it is those whose symptoms do not fit into

<!-- chunk -->

## a classical “disease” picture or who have symptoms for which

<!-- chunk -->

## there is little in the way of allopathic medicine to remedy their

<!-- chunk -->

## situation. Allergies such as eczema, urticaria and conjunctivitis,

<!-- chunk -->

## and hormonal, nervous and immune problems are good

<!-- chunk -->

## examples of these. Often people come after years of coping with

<!-- chunk -->

## health problems, in which case it may take some time to return

### enhances wellbeing and makes

## and “joie de vivre” so that the patient is better able to cope with

## their problems.

# Scheduling Visits

<!-- chunk -->

## Generally, medical herbalists do not hold open surgery, since

<!-- chunk -->

## appointments tend to be lengthy and so need to be booked in

<!-- chunk -->

## advance. First appointments are likely to last about an hour and

<!-- chunk -->

## follow up visits are thirty to forty-five minutes. Many herbalists

<!-- chunk -->

## operate a sliding scale of charges for the consultation and the

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal medicines prescribed, and for students, pensioners, the

<!-- chunk -->

## unemployed or those experiencing hard financial times fees may

<!-- chunk -->

## be reduced.

<!-- chunk -->

## To illustrate, a patient who presents with chronic ear infections

<!-- chunk -->

## may not require antibiotics to provide an effective and lasting

<!-- chunk -->

## cure. Examination of past medical history may show that there is

<!-- chunk -->

## a history of digestive problems, eczema, asthma, or hay fever,

<!-- chunk -->

## and several courses of antibiotics that have been prescribed in the

<!-- chunk -->

## past. Further questioning may reveal chronically sluggish

<!-- chunk -->

## bowels, a tendency to bloating and abdominal discomfort, a high

<!-- chunk -->

## intake of milk products, white bread, sugary foods and drinks

<!-- chunk -->

## and not enough fruit and vegetables. It may be that stress has

<!-- chunk -->

## also played its part in compromising digestion and liver function.

<!-- chunk -->

## It is likely that the underlying problem here lies in the gut. Poor

<!-- chunk -->

## digestion and elimination suggested by the sluggish bowels and

<!-- chunk -->

## wind indicate that food is not being digested adequately, resulting

<!-- chunk -->

## in poor absorption, a low nutritional profile and some degree of

<!-- chunk -->

## dysbiosis (disturbance of the gut flora) leading to leaky gut

<!-- chunk -->

## syndrome and toxicity. A diet high in gluten, dairy produce,

<!-- chunk -->

## refined carbohydrates and sugar, tends to disturb the gut, lower

<!-- chunk -->

## immunity and cause accumulation of mucous and chronic

<!-- chunk -->

## congestion in the eustachian tube that leads from the throat to the

<!-- chunk -->

## ear, predisposing to ear infections. Courses of antibiotics further

<!-- chunk -->

## aggravate the disturbance of the gut flora and lower immunity,

<!-- chunk -->

## and the cycle continues.

# Formulating a Herbal Prescription

# Herbal prescriptions are generally tailor-made for

# each individual, depending on their specific

# needs. They need to address a variety of different

# issues. Digestion and elimination are absolutely

# central to good health and poor digestion, as

# dysbiosis and toxicity are underlying factors in a

# whole range of different illness including gut

# problems, lowered immunity, allergies, auto-

# immune disease, obesity and cancer.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs to improve digestion and clear toxicity from the gut are

<!-- chunk -->

## therefore the first consideration. Then there are herbs that can be

<!-- chunk -->

## added for the constitutional imbalance and the system of the

<!-- chunk -->

## body affected, whether it is the nervous system in the case of

<!-- chunk -->

## anxiety and insomnia or the respiratory system in the case of

<!-- chunk -->

## bronchitis. Finally, herbs need to be included that are specific to

<!-- chunk -->

## the actual symptoms or disease, like frankincense for arthritis and

<!-- chunk -->

## uva ursi for urinary tract infections.

<!-- chunk -->

## In short, the following factors need to be addressed when

<!-- chunk -->

## formulating a prescription:

<!-- chunk -->

## • digestion

<!-- chunk -->

## • toxicity

<!-- chunk -->

## • constitution

<!-- chunk -->

## • system involved

<!-- chunk -->

## • disease

<!-- chunk -->

## In the above instance of chronic ear infection, antimicrobial

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs like garlic, turmeric, ginger, golden seal, neem and

<!-- chunk -->

## cinnamon could be given to combat infection and dysbiosis.

<!-- chunk -->

## Those chosen could be combined with immune-enhancing herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## such as andrographis, thyme, echinacea, and pau d'arco.

<!-- chunk -->

## Decongestant herbs like peppermint, elderflowers, yarrow and

<!-- chunk -->

## ginger can be given in teas (as hot infusions work better than

<!-- chunk -->

## tinctures) to clear excess mucous. Diluted essential oils of

<!-- chunk -->

## lavender, chamomile or thyme can be used in ear drops or used

<!-- chunk -->

## for massage around the ear and throat to relieve congestion in the

<!-- chunk -->

## eustachian tube.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many ask how long it will take to recover, and of course this

<!-- chunk -->

## depends very much on the nature of the illness and how long the

<!-- chunk -->

## symptoms have been apparent, as well as on the age,

<!-- chunk -->

## constitution, vitality and strength of the patient. A person treated

<!-- chunk -->

# Prescribing Herbal Medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## The method of administering herbs and the length of treatment

<!-- chunk -->

## needed by a patient will vary considerably according to the

<!-- chunk -->

## condition being treated, which herbs are used, their age, build

<!-- chunk -->

## and constitution, and even the time of year.

<!-- chunk -->

### The dosage of herbs chosen for the

<!-- chunk -->

### prescription needs to be carefully

<!-- chunk -->

### determined.

<!-- chunk -->

## The dosage, the herbs chosen for the prescription, and the

<!-- chunk -->

## timing of administration all need to be determined. A largely

<!-- chunk -->

## built person with big bones and muscles, and a comparatively

<!-- chunk -->

## sluggish metabolism, will generally require herbs to be given in

<!-- chunk -->

## larger doses and over a longer period of time than a small

<!-- chunk -->

## framed, lightweight person with a more sensitive body and faster

<!-- chunk -->

## metabolism.

<!-- chunk -->

## Dosage for adult patients can also vary according to the

<!-- chunk -->

## practitioner and which kind of herbal medicines they practice. A

<!-- chunk -->

## standard dose of tincture can vary from a few drops to 5mls (one

<!-- chunk -->

## teaspoon). Teas are generally taken a cupful at a time, powders

<!-- chunk -->

## are taken in doses of ¼–1 tsp and syrups may require being

<!-- chunk -->

## taken a dessertspoon or tablespoon at a time.

# Chronic and Acute Conditions

<!-- chunk -->

## When treating chronic conditions, generally mild herbal remedies

<!-- chunk -->

## are taken three times daily, over months at a time if necessary. It

<!-- chunk -->

## may be that the first prescription and dietary advice is intended to

<!-- chunk -->

## improve digestion and absorption and to clear toxins from the

<!-- chunk -->

## system, which is necessary in so many cases. This will be

<!-- chunk -->

## followed up by more nourishing tonic medicines until the patient

<!-- chunk -->

## is better. Acute conditions may require stronger herbs given up

<!-- chunk -->

## to every two hours. To illustrate, ashwagandha is nourishing and

<!-- chunk -->

## strengthening and is taken often 2–3 times a day over a few

<!-- chunk -->

## weeks or months to improve energy, vitality, immunity and

<!-- chunk -->

## enhance resilience to stress. Echinacea and wild indigo are taken

<!-- chunk -->

## every 2 hours to enhance immunity and combat acute infections.
