<!-- chunk -->

## Hot preparations are needed when treating fevers, colds, catarrh

<!-- chunk -->

## and problems associated with cold, such as poor circulation and

<!-- chunk -->

## menstrual cramps. Others problems such as urinary problems

<!-- chunk -->

## and conditions associated with heat, such as hot flushes and acne,

<!-- chunk -->

## are better suited to cool preparations. Skin problems may

<!-- chunk -->

## improve more rapidly using herbal teas as opposed to tinctures,

<!-- chunk -->

## while tinctures may be preferable when more concentrated

<!-- chunk -->

## medicines are needed, as when treating a virulent infection.

<!-- chunk -->

## The herbs chosen may also indicate their best method of

<!-- chunk -->

## administration. When giving teas, the aerial parts of a plant are

<!-- chunk -->

## prepared as infusions while roots, barks and seeds are better

<!-- chunk -->

## suited to decoctions. Nourishing tonics are best taken as powders

<!-- chunk -->

## stirred into warm milk or water, while warming spices to clear

<!-- chunk -->

## catarrhal congestion and coughs can be taken as powders mixed

<!-- chunk -->

## with honey and taken off a spoon.

<!-- chunk -->

## Generally, herbs are taken either side of or during a meal.

<!-- chunk -->

## When using herbs to enhance appetite, digestion and absorption,

<!-- chunk -->

## they can be taken before a meal; for problems associated with

<!-- chunk -->

## heat, acidity and inflammation they can be taken with a meal,

<!-- chunk -->

## otherwise they can be taken immediately after eating. Tinctures

<!-- chunk -->

## need to be diluted with water, otherwise they can be unpleasant

<!-- chunk -->

## tasting and can irritate a delicate stomach.

# Safety Issues

# The question of possible side effects and toxicity

# has arisen more lately as herbs are increasingly

# under the scrutiny of the scientific eye. However,

# adverse reactions to herbal medicines seldom

# occur in practice, and those that do occur

# generally consist of mild rashes or bowel

# changes. A herbal practitioner would not

# normally expect a “healing crisis” with an

# exacerbation of symptoms before they start to

# recede.

<!-- chunk -->

## There are two main sources of information about the efficacy and

<!-- chunk -->

## the safety of herbal medicines – ancient folklore and modern

<!-- chunk -->

## science. The empirical evidence gathered by herbalists over

<!-- chunk -->

## thousands of years, which is now being increasingly justified by

<!-- chunk -->

## scientific research, means that patients may be assured that their

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal prescriptions are based on reliable foundations. Many

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs form the basis of modern orthodox medicines, and it may

<!-- chunk -->

## be surprising to learn that the pharmaceutical industry harvests

<!-- chunk -->

## huge plantations of herbs for use in the production of drugs each

<!-- chunk -->

## year. It also grows herbs for further research activities.

<!-- chunk -->

## The use of whole plant medicines, as opposed to isolated active

<!-- chunk -->

## ingredients, helps to prevent adverse side effects. The many

<!-- chunk -->

## types of substances in medicinal plants work synergistically

<!-- chunk -->

## together, and probably all have important roles to play in the

<!-- chunk -->

## healing process. The primary healing agents are the active

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents that were isolated by the early chemists and

<!-- chunk -->

## developed into modern drugs, but the importance of the other

<!-- chunk -->

## apparently secondary constituents should not be ignored, since

<!-- chunk -->

## they are vital for determining the efficacy of the primary healing

<!-- chunk -->

## agents. Some secondary synergistic substances make the active

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents more easily assimilated and available in the body,

<!-- chunk -->

## while others will buffer the action of other potent plant

<!-- chunk -->

## chemicals, preventing possible side effects. It is largely the

<!-- chunk -->

## combination of both types of substances occurring in the whole

<!-- chunk -->

## plant that determines the potency and safety of herbal medicine.

# Potential Adverse Reactions

<!-- chunk -->

## Having said this, with the huge range of biochemical constituents

<!-- chunk -->

## that occur in herbs it is possible that, though generally safe, some

<!-- chunk -->

## could potentially cause allergic reactions and idiosyncratic

<!-- chunk -->

## responses in the same way that foods do. Most of these can be

<!-- chunk -->

## avoided by herbalists who are generally familiar with the

<!-- chunk -->

## chemistry of herbs they are prescribing and only prescribe herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## which are formulated to suit the specific needs of the patient in

<!-- chunk -->

## appropriate doses only after taking a detailed case history.

<!-- chunk -->

## Certain people are more likely to have hypersensitive reactions to

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs than others, particularly those who already have a history

<!-- chunk -->

## of food allergy or intolerance or chemical sensitivity. This is

<!-- chunk -->

## more likely if they suffer from digestive problems, specifically

<!-- chunk -->

## imbalances in the intestinal flora and leaky gut syndrome, which

<!-- chunk -->

## actually lend themselves very well to herbal treatment.

<!-- chunk -->

## The risk of adulteration of herbs supplied to herbalists is one

<!-- chunk -->

## that is obviously a concern. Adverse effects have occurred on

<!-- chunk -->

## occasions due to adulteration with toxic herbs, as well as bad

<!-- chunk -->

## labelling. When buying herbs, it is vital that their sources are

<!-- chunk -->

## known, reputable and preferably organic, since adverse reactions

<!-- chunk -->

## to pesticides and preservatives are hard to quantify and could be

<!-- chunk -->

## confused with reactions to a plant itself. Indian and Chinese

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs are considered more of a safety problem than European

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs, although the use of pesticides in Eastern Europe has also

<!-- chunk -->

## attracted negative attention.

# Herb/Drug Interactions

<!-- chunk -->

## This is a relatively new science but available information on the

<!-- chunk -->

## subject (much of which may be speculative rather than empirical)

<!-- chunk -->

## is growing all the time. Although herbs have been taken for

<!-- chunk -->

## thousands of years, they have only been used in combination

<!-- chunk -->

## with nutritional supplements and allopathic drugs on a

<!-- chunk -->

## widespread basis for approximately the last forty years or so.

<!-- chunk -->

## The concern is not so much that the reaction between a herb and

<!-- chunk -->

## a drug is toxic, rather that it is possible that certain herbs can

<!-- chunk -->

## affect the bioavailability of drugs and nutrients, and cause an

<!-- chunk -->

## increase or decrease in levels of drugs in the blood. This is

<!-- chunk -->

## important to know, especially if patients are taking specific doses

<!-- chunk -->

## of powerful drugs such as cardiac medication, anti-clotting

<!-- chunk -->

## agents or they may need to have surgery.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs high in mucilage or fibre, such as slippery elm or

<!-- chunk -->

## psyllium seeds, or herbs rich in tannins which might bind up

<!-- chunk -->

## drugs in the intestines, may inhibit absorption. Warming

<!-- chunk -->

## digestive herbs such as cayenne, long and black pepper can

<!-- chunk -->

## increase absorption of medicines, while herbs that act on liver

<!-- chunk -->

## enzyme systems may affect the break down of certain drugs and

<!-- chunk -->

## inhibit their elimination, effectively raising the drug dosage

<!-- chunk -->

## which could cause side effects. Care needs to be taken with

<!-- chunk -->

## insulin-dependent diabetics as certain herbs lower blood sugar.

<!-- chunk -->

## Interestingly in China, where the herbal tradition has remained

<!-- chunk -->

## unbroken and there is less suspicion about herbs than there is in

<!-- chunk -->

## the West, herbs are often combined with drugs for intentional

<!-- chunk -->

## effects, either to reduce side effects of drugs or to enhance their

<!-- chunk -->

## effects.

<!-- chunk -->

### Filipendula, or meadowsweet, is rich

<!-- chunk -->

### in tannins, which may inhibit the

<!-- chunk -->

### absorption of some drugs.

# The Herbal Pharmacy

# There are many ways to prepare herbal remedies

# so that they will be absorbed by the body and

# exert their beneficial effects. Depending on the

# condition being treated, and the health and age of

# the patient, a herbalist might choose to prescribe

# an infusion, a powder or a tincture, or a cream to

# apply to the skin. Here are step-by-step

# instructions for preparing these remedies and

# others including decoctions, honeys, elixirs,

# poultices and fragrant baths. Dosage instructions

# are included.

# Preparing Herbs

# Collecting wild herbs or growing them in your

# garden and harvesting them for making medicines

# can be very rewarding and uplifting. For those

# who do not have access to fresh plants, dried

# herbs are available from many suppliers. Try to

# use organic herbs as pesticides may disrupt the

# therapeutic effect of your remedies or cause

# adverse reactions.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs can be prepared as medicines in a variety of ways. What is

<!-- chunk -->

## important is that they are absorbed into the body so that they can

<!-- chunk -->

## exert their benefit. When internal preparations are swallowed,

<!-- chunk -->

## they pass through the digestive tract and into the bloodstream.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many people are unconsciously taking herbal remedies in their

<!-- chunk -->

## food on a daily basis, for not only do all the culinary herbs and

<!-- chunk -->

## spices add flavour to our diet, but also they contain volatile oils

<!-- chunk -->

## that have digestive and antimicrobial effects among many other

<!-- chunk -->

## benefits. As foods are absorbed from the digestive tract, so the

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutic constituents of the herbs enter the bloodstream and

<!-- chunk -->

## then circulate around the body.

<!-- chunk -->

## When used externally, herbs can be applied to the skin as in an

<!-- chunk -->

## aromatherapy massage or when we rub a dock leaf on to a nettle

<!-- chunk -->

## sting. They can also be used in herbal baths, compresses and

<!-- chunk -->

## poultices. Once in contact with the skin, they are absorbed into

<!-- chunk -->

## tiny capillaries under the surface and then circulated round the

<!-- chunk -->

## body. The conjunctiva of the eye also absorbs herbal

<!-- chunk -->

## preparations. A chamomile eyebath or a marigold compress will

<!-- chunk -->

## relieve sore and inflamed eyes. Inhalations are another very good

<!-- chunk -->

## therapeutic pathway and one that is utilised by aromatherapists.

<!-- chunk -->

## By inhalation into the nose which is lined with nerve endings, the

<!-- chunk -->

## messages from the herbs are carried directly to the brain and also

<!-- chunk -->

## to the lungs, where they are absorbed with oxygen into the

<!-- chunk -->

## bloodstream and circulated throughout the body.

<!-- chunk -->

### Grinding herbs ready for use.

# Preparations for Internal Use

# Infusions

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbal teas, often known as infusions, are simple water-based

<!-- chunk -->

## preparations that extract the medicinal properties of herbs, used

<!-- chunk -->

## either fresh or dried. They can either be drunk as teas or used

<!-- chunk -->

## externally as skin washes, eyebaths, compresses, douches, or

<!-- chunk -->

## added to baths or sitz baths.

<!-- chunk -->

## Infusions are prepared like a normal cup of tea using the soft

<!-- chunk -->

## parts of plants: leaves, stems and flowers.


<!-- chunk -->

## Take 1oz /25 gms of dried herb per pint of water or a

<!-- chunk -->

## teaspoon of herb per cupful of water. Double the amount of

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs if they are being used fresh.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place the herbs in a warmed teapot and pour on boiling

<!-- chunk -->

## water. Cover immediately to prevent volatile oils escaping

<!-- chunk -->

## into the atmosphere.

# 3

<!-- chunk -->

## Leave to infuse for 10–15 minutes and then strain.

<!-- chunk -->

## Infusions are generally best drunk when still hot, especially

<!-- chunk -->

## when treating fevers, colds and catarrh, but they need to be taken

<!-- chunk -->

## luke warm to cool for problems of the skin and urinary tract. If

<!-- chunk -->

## necessary, they can be covered and stored in the fridge for up to

<!-- chunk -->

## two days. Some herbs need to be prepared as cold infusions as

<!-- chunk -->

## their therapeutic components are likely to be destroyed by high

<!-- chunk -->

## temperatures. These include herbs that have a high proportion of

<!-- chunk -->

## mucilage like marshmallow and plantain leaf. They are prepared

<!-- chunk -->

## in the same way but with cold water and left to infuse for 10–12

<!-- chunk -->

## hours.

# Dosage

<!-- chunk -->

## Infusions are generally taken by the cupful three to six times a

<!-- chunk -->

## day, depending on whether the ailment being treated is chronic or

<!-- chunk -->

## acute. It may come as a surprise to some who are used to the

<!-- chunk -->

## enticing tastes of culinary herbs such as basil and rosemary, that

<!-- chunk -->

## many herbs are found by our pampered palates to taste strange,

<!-- chunk -->

## often even unpleasant. Although the bitters in some herbs need

<!-- chunk -->

## to be tasted to be effective, the bitter taste is generally not

<!-- chunk -->

## something we relish. However, it is possible to combine several

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs together in an infusion so that aromatic, pleasant tasting

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs such as peppermint, fennel, lemon balm and lavender can

<!-- chunk -->

## disguise less palatable herbs while not reducing their effects.

<!-- chunk -->

## Liquorice and aniseed also make excellent herbs for flavouring.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbal teabags are sold in all high street health food shops and

<!-- chunk -->

## supermarkets (buy organic if you can) and normally comprise

<!-- chunk -->

## the more aromatic, pleasant tasting herbs like lime flower, fennel,

<!-- chunk -->

## peppermint.

<!-- chunk -->

### Hot infusions are more effective than

<!-- chunk -->

### tinctures for treating skin complaints,

<!-- chunk -->

### fevers, colds and catarrh.

# Decoctions

<!-- chunk -->

## The hard woody parts of plants have tough cell walls that require

<!-- chunk -->

## greater heat to break them down before they will release their

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents into water. Bark, seeds, roots, rhizomes and nuts all

<!-- chunk -->

## need to be prepared as decoctions. Use the same proportion of

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs to water as you do when preparing an infusion, just add a

<!-- chunk -->

## little more water to make up for losses during boiling.


<!-- chunk -->

## To make their constituents more accessible to the water,

<!-- chunk -->

## break the herb up into small pieces with a pestle and mortar

<!-- chunk -->

## if the parts are very hard.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place herbs in a stainless steel or enamel saucepan and cover

<!-- chunk -->

## them with cold water. Bring to the boil, cover and simmer for

<!-- chunk -->

## 10–15 minutes.

# 3

<!-- chunk -->

## Strain and drink in the same way as an infusion.

# Tinctures, Glycerites and Vinegars

<!-- chunk -->

## Tinctures are concentrated extracts of herbs made with a mixture

<!-- chunk -->

## of water and alcohol which acts to extract the constituents of the

<!-- chunk -->

## plants and also as a preservative. According to herbal

<!-- chunk -->

## pharmacopoeias there is a correct ratio of water and alcohol to

<!-- chunk -->

## plant matter for each herb depending on the constituents that

<!-- chunk -->

## need extracting. This can range from 25% alcohol for simple

<!-- chunk -->

## glycosides and tannins, to 90% for resins and gums such as those

<!-- chunk -->

## in marigold flowers. Herbs can be used either fresh or dried.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place the chopped herbs in a large clean jar and pour the

<!-- chunk -->

## water and alcohol mixture over it so the plant is immersed.

<!-- chunk -->

## Using dried herbs, the ratio is 1 part of herbs per 5 parts of

<!-- chunk -->

## liquid. Fresh herbs are used in a ratio of 1 part herb to 2 parts

<!-- chunk -->

## liquid. To illustrate, to make 1 litre (1¾ pints) of sage

<!-- chunk -->

## tincture, take 200g (7oz) of dried leaves and pour over 1 litre

<!-- chunk -->

## (1¾ pints) of fluid. Sage requires a 45% alcohol solution so

<!-- chunk -->

## neat brandy or vodka would be perfectly adequate. (It is

<!-- chunk -->

## possible to obtain 96% naturally fermented alcohol. In the

<!-- chunk -->

## UK this requires an alcohol licence which can be obtained

<!-- chunk -->

## from HM Revenue and Customs. If you have this, use 450ml

<!-- chunk -->

## alcohol to 550ml water.) Place an airtight lid on the jar and

<!-- chunk -->

## leave it to macerate away from direct sunlight for no less

<!-- chunk -->

## than two weeks, shaking the jar well about once a day.


<!-- chunk -->

## Once the tincture has macerated, use a press such as a wine

<!-- chunk -->

## press to extract as much of the fluid as possible.

<!-- chunk -->

## Alternatively, squeeze it through muslin which is much

<!-- chunk -->

## harder work but possible. Then discard the herbs, transfer

<!-- chunk -->

## the tincture to a clean, dark bottle with a lid, label it with the

<!-- chunk -->

## name of the herb and the date and store in a cool place.

<!-- chunk -->

## Glycerites are prepared similarly using a mixture of water,

<!-- chunk -->

## alcohol and glycerol to extract the plant's constituents and as a

<!-- chunk -->

## preservative. Glycerol has a sweet, syrup-like consistency which

<!-- chunk -->

## imparts a sweet taste to the preparation making it more palatable

<!-- chunk -->

## than a tincture, and a good medium for children's medicines.

<!-- chunk -->

## Glycerol breaks down chemically into 3 parts fatty acids and

<!-- chunk -->

## part alcohol, so although it tastes sweet it does not contain sugar.

<!-- chunk -->

## Glycerol is particularly good at extracting the aromatic properties

<!-- chunk -->

## of plants and is best used for plants such as lavender, rosemary,

<!-- chunk -->

## rose, basil, chamomile, mint, oregano, thyme and lemon balm.

<!-- chunk -->

### Macerating tinctures.

<!-- chunk -->

## The herbs are used in the same ration as when making

<!-- chunk -->

## tinctures; using dried herbs, the ratio is 1 part of herbs per 5 parts

<!-- chunk -->

## of liquid. Fresh herbs are used in a ratio of 1 part herb to 2 parts

<!-- chunk -->

## liquid. If using vodka or brandy, the ratio of ingredients for the

<!-- chunk -->

## liquid is 60% glycerol, 40% alcohol. (If you have access to 96%

<!-- chunk -->

## alcohol, use 60% glycerol, 20% alcohol and 20% water.)

<!-- chunk -->

## To make a glycerite, place the chopped herbs in a large clean

<!-- chunk -->

## jar and pour the water, alcohol and glycerol mixture over it so

<!-- chunk -->

## the plant is immersed and follow instructions from here on for

<!-- chunk -->

## making tinctures.

<!-- chunk -->

## Tinctures and glycerites are more concentrated than infusions

<!-- chunk -->

## and decoctions, meaning only small amounts need to be taken at

<!-- chunk -->

## regular intervals through the day. The dose will vary from 5-10

<!-- chunk -->

## drops to a 5ml teaspoon which is taken in a little warm water or

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal tea, 3 to 6 times daily depending on whether the condition

<!-- chunk -->

## being treated is chronic or acute. Tinctures can also be added to

<!-- chunk -->

## bath water, mixed with water to compresses, mouthwashes or

<!-- chunk -->

## gargles, or stirred into a base to make ointments or creams. They

<!-- chunk -->

## require more preparation time but they have several advantages.

<!-- chunk -->

## They are easy to store, do not deteriorate in cold or damp

<!-- chunk -->

## conditions, take up relatively little storage space, are easy to carry

<!-- chunk -->

## around and keep almost indefinitely, although they are best taken

<!-- chunk -->

## within two years.

<!-- chunk -->

## Tinctures can also be prepared using neat cider vinegar as the

<!-- chunk -->

## acetic acid acts as a solvent and preservative. Raspberry vinegar

<!-- chunk -->

## for example is a traditional remedy for coughs and sore throats.

<!-- chunk -->

## Fill a wide mouth glass jar full of one fresh herb of your choice.

<!-- chunk -->

## Cover the herb with good quality (preferably apple cider)

<!-- chunk -->

## vinegar, filling the jar to the brim. Cork or cover with a screw

<!-- chunk -->

## top lid. Keep in a cool, dark place for six weeks. Strain through

<!-- chunk -->

## muslin and press well.

# Oxymels

<!-- chunk -->

## The combination of infused cider vinegar and honey is known as

<!-- chunk -->

## an oxymel. The practice originated in the Middle East and was

<!-- chunk -->

## brought to England following the Crusades when the medicines

<!-- chunk -->

## of Avicenna were widely used. Knights and their ladies would be

<!-- chunk -->

## offered hot oxymels when they broke their fast as a stimulating

<!-- chunk -->

## way to start the day. Prepare in the same way as herb vinegars,

<!-- chunk -->

## using equal proportions of honey and cider vinegar.

# Herbal Honeys

<!-- chunk -->

## Honey has been used for healing for thousands of years. It is

<!-- chunk -->

## hydroscopic which means that it absorbs water-soluble

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents and the volatile oils of plants. Honey has

<!-- chunk -->

## antibacterial, immune-enhancing, expectorant and healing

<!-- chunk -->

## properties, and makes an excellent medium for antimicrobial

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs such as garlic, onions, holy basil, thyme, hyssop, oregano

<!-- chunk -->

## and rosemary. It contains pollen which is rich in protein,

<!-- chunk -->

## vitamins, minerals and fatty acids and helpful in the treatment of

<!-- chunk -->

## allergies and asthma, as well as propolis which is a powerful

<!-- chunk -->

## antimicrobial. Being rich in easily digestible sugars, honey is also

<!-- chunk -->

## highly nutritive and energy giving. Herbal honeys can be used to

<!-- chunk -->

## treat sore throats, coughs and colds, chest infections, asthma.

<!-- chunk -->

## They can also be used externally to heal or soothe skin problems

<!-- chunk -->

## such as cuts and grazes, burns and varicose ulcers. Thyme honey

<!-- chunk -->

## from Greece is renowned for its health giving properties, as is

<!-- chunk -->

## Manuka honey from New Zealand, which is often used as an

<!-- chunk -->

## antibacterial.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbal honeys are made by pouring honey over herbs. Dried

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs preserved in honey are more likely to keep for longer than

<!-- chunk -->

## fresh ones.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place your chosen herbs, coarsely chopped, in a clean,

<!-- chunk -->

## sterilized jar, cover them with runny honey and stir well.


<!-- chunk -->

## Seal with an airtight lid, label clearly and leave to macerate

<!-- chunk -->

## for at least 4 weeks but preferably several months. Store in a

<!-- chunk -->

## cool dark place or in the fridge.

<!-- chunk -->

## Fresh herbs can be used if you have them; simply chop them

<!-- chunk -->

## finely and mix with a teaspoon of honey. You can also make

<!-- chunk -->

## sweets and throat lozenges by mixing powdered dried herbs into

<!-- chunk -->

## honey to make a paste which can be rolled into balls, and then

<!-- chunk -->

## again in the powder to prevent stickiness for handling and

<!-- chunk -->

## storing. Store in a tightly fitting tin.

# Dosage

<!-- chunk -->

## Take 1 tablespoonful of herbal honey in a little hot water or

<!-- chunk -->

## simply off the spoon. Do not give to children under 1 year old

<!-- chunk -->

## due to risk of botulinus.

<!-- chunk -->

### Herbal honeys.

# Elixirs

<!-- chunk -->

## Honey can also be combined with equal parts of brandy to make

<!-- chunk -->

## my favourite way to take herbs. Elixirs have several benefits.

<!-- chunk -->

## Both the honey and the brandy act as preservatives, increase the

<!-- chunk -->

## shelf life of the medicine, they are very easy to prepare and the

## combination tastes delicious! The honey brings out the flavour of

<!-- chunk -->

## aromatic herbs and its sweetness offsets the pungency of the

<!-- chunk -->

## brandy.

<!-- chunk -->

## 1 part of dried herbs is mixed with 5 parts of honey and

<!-- chunk -->

## brandy. When using fresh herbs use 1 part of herbs to 2 parts of

<!-- chunk -->

## honey and brandy. Unlike most sweet medicines, it can be used

<!-- chunk -->

## in small doses, thanks to the particular combination of honey and

<!-- chunk -->

## alcohol. Elixirs can either be made with a single herb or

<!-- chunk -->

## combinations of your choice. The dose is 1/2tsp/30 drops 3–6

## times daily according to whether the problem is chronic or acute.

<!-- chunk -->

## For example, to make elecampane root elixir, take 200gm of

<!-- chunk -->

## the dried root, place in a large jar and cover it with a mixture of

<!-- chunk -->

## 500ml of brandy and 500ml of runny honey. Use a tightly fitting

<!-- chunk -->

## lid and store in a dark place for at least 3 weeks and up to a few

## months before pressing.

# Herbal Powders

<!-- chunk -->

## Dried herbs can be ground into powder which can be used in a

<!-- chunk -->

## fluid medium or made into tablets or capsules to prolong its shelf

## life as powder tend to deteriorate relatively quickly. Taking

## powders has the advantage of ingesting the whole plant and not

### Herbal powders.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many herbs are available from herbal suppliers in tablet or

## capsule form and this is certainly a convenient way to take herbs,

## but it bypasses the taste buds on the tongue which may reduce

# Fresh Juices

<!-- chunk -->

## Extracting the juice of a plant is the best way to prepare soft,

<!-- chunk -->

## juicy plants such as aloe vera, purslane, pomegranate, cleavers,

<!-- chunk -->

## ginger, marshmallow, nettle, mint or dandelion. Juice provides a

<!-- chunk -->

## concentrate, easily assimilated by the body. Cabbage juice, for

## example, is excellent for relieving peptic ulcers, gastritis, heart

# Herbal Pastes

<!-- chunk -->

## Crushed dried plants or powder mixed with water or aloe gel can

<!-- chunk -->

## be used to make a paste. Pastes are generally intended for

<!-- chunk -->

## poultices and plasters which can be used externally. Herbs that

<!-- chunk -->

## speed healing and soothe the skin can be made into pastes

<!-- chunk -->

## including calendula, turmeric, slippery elm, aloe vera and gotu

<!-- chunk -->

## kola.

# Suppositories

<!-- chunk -->

## Suppositories can be made easily by mixing powdered herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## with cocoa butter. Warm cocoa butter in a double boiler until it

<!-- chunk -->

## melts, remove from the heat and stir in powdered herbs, enough

<!-- chunk -->

## to make a paste. Mix well then place in the fridge to harden.

<!-- chunk -->

## Next, roll it out until it is about ¾″thick and cut into ¾″ strips

<!-- chunk -->

## which can be inserted into the rectum or vagina. Insert one

<!-- chunk -->

## suppository 2–3 times daily.

<!-- chunk -->

## The advantage of using suppositories is that the herbal remedy

<!-- chunk -->

## can be absorbed quickly directly into the bloodstream through

<!-- chunk -->

## the mucosa of the rectum or vagina. This not only enables both

<!-- chunk -->

## local and systemic problems to be treated quickly and simply but

<!-- chunk -->

## it also obviates the laborious process of giving herbs by mouth to

<!-- chunk -->

## travel the distance of the alimentary canal before being absorbed.

### Making suppositories.

# Preparations for External Use

# Most herbal constituents are absorbed readily

# through the skin and the following preparations

# are designed to enhance this pathway into the

# body. The easiest way of course to use herbs

# externally is to apply them directly to the skin as

# we do when we rub a dock leaf on to a nettle

# sting.

# Juice

<!-- chunk -->

## The fresh juice of many remedies can be applied directly to the

<!-- chunk -->

## skin. Aloe vera juice, for example can be rubbed on to the skin

<!-- chunk -->

## to soothe burns, bites, and stings. The juice of dock leaves is

<!-- chunk -->

## famous for relieving nettle stings. Greater celandine is a very

<!-- chunk -->

## effective treatment for warts. Just pick a stem and it will

<!-- chunk -->

## immediately start to ooze brilliant tangerine-yellow sap. Cover

<!-- chunk -->

## the wart in the juice every day for three weeks and the wart will

<!-- chunk -->

## disappear.

# Ointments and Creams

<!-- chunk -->

## Ointments and creams can be applied to the skin not only to treat

<!-- chunk -->

## skin problems but also to relieve less superficial problems such

<!-- chunk -->

## as inflamed joints and headaches. Any herb fresh or dried can be

<!-- chunk -->

## included in an ointment using this simple recipe:


<!-- chunk -->

## Melt 50gm (2oz) of beeswax with 450mls (¾ pint) of olive

<!-- chunk -->

## oil in a pyrex bowl over a low heat in a double boiler.


<!-- chunk -->

## Add as much herb as possible to the oil and leave to

<!-- chunk -->

## macerate on the heat for a few hours. After this time the

<!-- chunk -->

## constituents will have been taken up by the oil and the

<!-- chunk -->

## mixture can then be poured through a piece of muslin placed

<!-- chunk -->

## over a jug and then squeezed to extract as much of the oil as

<!-- chunk -->

## possible. The herb can then be discarded.

# 3

<!-- chunk -->

## When the oil is still warm it can be poured into clean

<!-- chunk -->

## ointment jars where it will quickly solidify. Seal with an

<!-- chunk -->

## airtight lid and label clearly. Store in a cool, dark place.

<!-- chunk -->

## Creams can be made up easily by stirring tinctures, infusions,

<!-- chunk -->

## decoctions or a few drops of essential oil into a cream base such

<!-- chunk -->

## as aqueous cream. 2–3 drops of chamomile oil mixed into 2oz

<!-- chunk -->

## (50gm) of cream works well on many types of eczema.

# Compresses

<!-- chunk -->

## A clean cloth or flannel can be soaked in a strong hot or cold

<!-- chunk -->

## infusion or a decoction, a dilute tincture or water with a few

<!-- chunk -->

## drops of diluted essential oil, then wrung out and applied to the

<!-- chunk -->

## affected part. This can help relieve symptoms such as headaches,

<!-- chunk -->

## abdominal pain and colic, backache, boils and painful joints. The

<!-- chunk -->

## treatment needs to repeated several times for good effect.

# Poultices

<!-- chunk -->

## These are similar to compresses but involve using the herb itself

<!-- chunk -->

## rather than an extract of the herb.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place the herb, fresh or dried between two pieces of gauze.

<!-- chunk -->

## If you use fresh leaves, stems or roots, they need to be

<!-- chunk -->

## bruised before being applied. If the herbs are dry, add a little

<!-- chunk -->

## hot water to powdered or finely chopped herbs to make a

<!-- chunk -->

## paste.


<!-- chunk -->

## Use a light cotton bandage to bind the gauze poultice to the

<!-- chunk -->

## affected part and keep it warm with a hot water bottle.

<!-- chunk -->

## Replace after 4 hours and apply about 3 times a day in total.

<!-- chunk -->

## Some herbs, such as cabbage leaves, can be applied directly to

<!-- chunk -->

## the skin. They need to be softened first by removing any hard

<!-- chunk -->

## stalks or ribs and immersing them briefly in hot water to prevent

<!-- chunk -->

## any discomfort to the skin. Once applied they can be secured in

<!-- chunk -->

## place by a light bandage and left overnight.

# Liniments

<!-- chunk -->

## A rubbing oil or liniment consists of extracts of herbs in an oil or

<!-- chunk -->

## tincture, or a mixture of both. The oils can be infused oils or

<!-- chunk -->

## essential oils diluted in a base such as sesame oil. They are used

<!-- chunk -->

## in massage to relax or stimulate muscles and ligaments, or to

<!-- chunk -->

## soothe away pain from inflammation or injury. They are intended

<!-- chunk -->

## to be absorbed by the skin to reach the affected part, and so they

<!-- chunk -->

## often contain stimulating essential oils such as ginger or black

<!-- chunk -->

## pepper and are therefore not suitable for use on delicate baby

<!-- chunk -->

## skins.

# Oils

<!-- chunk -->

## Essential oils need to be used with care especially with children

<!-- chunk -->

## and babies. They can be used diluted in a base oil such as sesame

<!-- chunk -->

## oil (1–2 drops of oil per 5ml of base oil) for massage and to add

<!-- chunk -->

## to the bath. They can be used in burners to permeate the

<!-- chunk -->

## atmosphere or in inhalations for a variety of symptoms such as

<!-- chunk -->

## colds, catarrh, coughs, insomnia and anxiety.

<!-- chunk -->

## While essential oils are extracted from aromatic plants

<!-- chunk -->

## professionally by steam distillation, infused oils can be prepared

<!-- chunk -->

## easily at home.


<!-- chunk -->

## Place finely chopped, preferably fresh herbs (make sure

<!-- chunk -->

## they are not wet) in a jar with a tight fitting lid, cover them

<!-- chunk -->

## with an oil such as almond, coconut, olive or sesame,

<!-- chunk -->

## pouring it up to the top of the jar, and then stir well.


<!-- chunk -->

## Add the lid, label the jar with the name of the herb and the

<!-- chunk -->

## date, then leave the jar on a sunny windowsill to macerate for

<!-- chunk -->

## about 2 to 4 weeks. Be aware that if there is moisture on the

<!-- chunk -->

## plant or in the jar, or it is left too long, the oil may go

<!-- chunk -->

## mouldy.

<!-- chunk -->

## The oil will gradually take up the constituents of the plant; you

<!-- chunk -->

## can see this in action when you macerate St John's wort flowers

<!-- chunk -->

## in oil. In a matter of minutes, the oil will turn a deep red colour.

<!-- chunk -->

## St John's wort oil is a very useful remedy for healing cuts and

<!-- chunk -->

## sores, and when massaged over the affected part, it can relieve

<!-- chunk -->

## painful nerve conditions such as trigeminal neuralgia and

<!-- chunk -->

## shingles. After 2–4 weeks filter the oil through muslin into a

<!-- chunk -->

## clean jug, squeezing hard to extract as much oil as possible from

<!-- chunk -->

## the flowers. Then pour into an airtight, dark bottle, label it with

<!-- chunk -->

## the name and date of the oil, and store in a cool dark place to

<!-- chunk -->

## retain its therapeutic value for a maximum length of time.

# Herbal Baths

<!-- chunk -->

## A fragrant hot bath makes a very pleasant and simple way to take

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs. There are various ways of adding herbs to bath water; you

<!-- chunk -->

## can use dilute essential oils (1 drop of essential oil per drop of

<!-- chunk -->

## base oil such as sesame oil) and add them to the bath water; hang

<!-- chunk -->

## a muslin bag containing fresh or dried aromatic herbs under the

<!-- chunk -->

## hot tap as you draw the bath; or pour a pint (600ml) of a strong

<!-- chunk -->

## herbal infusion (double the standard dose described on page 79)

<!-- chunk -->

## into the water. Soak in the warm bath for 10-20 minutes.

<!-- chunk -->

## When herbs are used in this way, the essential oils from the

<!-- chunk -->

## plants are taken in via the pores of the skin which are opened up

<!-- chunk -->

## by the warmth of the water. The oils are also carried on the steam

<!-- chunk -->

## which is simultaneously inhaled via nose and mouth into the

<!-- chunk -->

## lungs, and from there into the bloodstream. From the nose

<!-- chunk -->

## messages are carried from the oils via nerve pathways to the

<!-- chunk -->

## brain. In this way herbal medicines are assimilated quickly and

<!-- chunk -->

## directly, bypassing the lengthy process of digestion involved

<!-- chunk -->

## when herbs are taken by mouth. They are particularly useful for

<!-- chunk -->

## relaxing and soothing the nervous system and for easing mental

<!-- chunk -->

## and emotional strain.

<!-- chunk -->

## Lavender, lemon balm, basil, holy basil, rose and chamomile

<!-- chunk -->

## are not only wonderfully fragrant but also relaxing, calming

<!-- chunk -->

## tension and anxiety and helping to ensure restful sleep.

<!-- chunk -->

## Chamomile is excellent for fractious children, particularly when

<!-- chunk -->

## they are unwell, for not only does it possess antimicrobial

<!-- chunk -->

## properties but also it helps induce sleep – nature's best way to

<!-- chunk -->

## ward off infection and enable self-healing. Rosemary baths,

<!-- chunk -->

## while also relaxing, have a stimulating edge as they enhance

<!-- chunk -->

## blood flow to the head and promote alertness and concentration.

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbal sitz baths can be very useful for soothing the pain and

<!-- chunk -->

## irritation of cystitis, vaginal infections or haemorrhoids. Simply

<!-- chunk -->

## fill a large, shallow bowl with about a litre (1.75 pints) of

<!-- chunk -->

## strained, strong infusion, enough to reach the necessary areas, sit

<!-- chunk -->

## in it and relax for 10–15 minutes!

# Hand and Foot Baths

<!-- chunk -->

## Mustard foot baths were used historically for all afflictions of

<!-- chunk -->

## cold and damp climates, from colds and flu to poor circulation

<!-- chunk -->

## and arthritis. The ancient tradition of hand and foot baths was

<!-- chunk -->

## made popular by the famous French herbalist, Maurice

<!-- chunk -->

## Messegue, who has written several books on herbal therapy

<!-- chunk -->

## based simply on this form of treatment. He recommends foot

<!-- chunk -->

## baths for 8 minutes in the evening and hand baths for 8 minutes

<!-- chunk -->

## in the morning. According to Messegue, the hands and feet are

<!-- chunk -->

## highly sensitive areas of the skin, rich in nerve endings and,

<!-- chunk -->

## despite some thickening of the skin from use, the constituents

<!-- chunk -->

## pass easily from the skin into the body. To try this, add

<!-- chunk -->

## 1tablespoon of mustard powder to a bowl of hot water, test the

<!-- chunk -->

## temperature and then sit with your feet in it for 8–10 minutes.

# Shelf Life

<!-- chunk -->

## The way herbs are prepared and stored is important as it will

<!-- chunk -->

## affect the length of time that plants will maintain their therapeutic

<!-- chunk -->

## components and therefore their beneficial effects. Powders have

<!-- chunk -->

## the shortest “shelf life,” which means the amount of time they

<!-- chunk -->

## can be stored on your shelves, and generally should be kept in

<!-- chunk -->

## dark, air tight containers and for no more than 6–9 months.

<!-- chunk -->

## Because they tend to oxidise and thereby deteriorate relatively

<!-- chunk -->

## rapidly, powders are often made into capsules and tablets to

<!-- chunk -->

## extend their shelf life; some are given protective coatings.

<!-- chunk -->

## Powders can also be combined with pastes and herbal extracts to

<!-- chunk -->

## extend their shelf life. Tablets will keep for longer, although they

<!-- chunk -->

## should be stored similarly away from direct sunlight. Herbal

<!-- chunk -->

## tinctures and glycerites will keep up to 3 years.

<!-- chunk -->

### Stored properly, herbal tinctures will

<!-- chunk -->

### keep up to 3 years.

# The Materia Medica

# A Materia Medica is a compendium of medicinal

# herbs used for their theraputic effects, and

# traditionally describes each herb's

# pharmacological properties and medicinal actions.

# The first such collection of knowledge on healing

# plants appeared in India around 700 BCE,

# compiled by the scholar Charaka, and a similar

# manual was assembled in China around 1000 CE.

# The term Materia Medica is Latin and has been

# around since Roman times when Dioscorides

# wrote a five-volume in Greek, De Materia

# Medica, which was subsequently translated into

# Latin around 60 CE. Dioscorides' book was a

# commentary on around 500 medicinal plants.

# How to Use the Materia Medica

# The Materia Medica is the heart of this book. It is

# a comprehensive directory of the 150 herbs most

# commonly used by modern Western herbalists.

# They are all easily available from most herbal

# suppliers, and because this book is intended for

# use by lay people as well as students and

# practitioners of herbal medicine, none of them is a

# “Schedule 3” herb, that is herbs whose dosage is

# restricted by law due to the presence of powerful

# constituents, often alkaloids, that require caution

# in their use.

# The Materia Medica is a detailed herb directory,

# organised alphabetically by Latin name. Each

# entry includes the common name, family, parts

# used, major constituents and the actions of the

# plants. It then lists the herb's indications for use

# in treatment according to the systems of the body,

# including recent cross-reference to the Treating

# Common Ailments chapter (see pages 275–353)

# so that you can be informed about the herbs that

# you choose.

# The Digestive System

# Good digestion is absolutely essential to good

# health. The digestive system enables our bodies

# to convert the food we eat into the energy needed

# for all the minute biochemical reactions that keep

# us alive. It also provides the major pathway for

# the elimination of toxins from the body.

<!-- chunk -->

## Health and vitality largely depend not only on an excellent diet

<!-- chunk -->

## but also on how efficiently our digestion makes the nutrients

<!-- chunk -->

## available to us and, in turn, passes out undigested food residues

<!-- chunk -->

## and the waste products of metabolism.

<!-- chunk -->

## The digestive tract is lined with a protective mucous membrane

<!-- chunk -->

## which serves to secrete digestive juices that contain enzymes

<!-- chunk -->

## designed to break food down into a form that our bodies can

<!-- chunk -->

## absorb. Digestion starts in the mouth with the action of the

<!-- chunk -->

## enzymes in saliva on the food we eat, but most of the process

<!-- chunk -->

## takes place in the stomach and small intestine. Other digestive

<!-- chunk -->

## enzymes are supplied to the digestive tract by the liver,

<!-- chunk -->

## gallbladder and pancreas. The conversion of food in the

<!-- chunk -->

## digestive tract provides energy, but it also requires energy to

<!-- chunk -->

## carry out all the essential biochemical reactions involved in the

<!-- chunk -->

## process. If our digestive energy is low or upset, it can lead to

<!-- chunk -->

## digestive symptoms such as wind, bloating stomach aches, IBS

<!-- chunk -->

## (irritable bowel syndrome), diarrhoea and constipation, and can

<!-- chunk -->

## fundamentally affect our general health and energy, predisposing

<!-- chunk -->

## to lethargy, lowered immunity, nervous problems, poor

<!-- chunk -->

## concentration and sleep disturbances.

# Influencing Factors

<!-- chunk -->

## Good digestion and elimination depend on several factors. We

<!-- chunk -->

## need to eat sufficient fibre from whole foods, vegetables and

<!-- chunk -->

## fruits and to drink plenty of fluids to ensure regular peristaltic

<!-- chunk -->

## movements that propel food along the alimentary canal. The

<!-- chunk -->

## right diet is vital to good health and normal function of the

<!-- chunk -->

## digestive tract. Over-refined foods, excess sugar, fizzy drinks, ice

<!-- chunk -->

## cream, and too many fermented and fried foods can all irritate

<!-- chunk -->

## and cause disturbances. Indigestible foods such as bread, hard

<!-- chunk -->

## cheese, red meat and hard raw food such as nuts and seeds can

<!-- chunk -->

## leave partly digested or undigested food residues in the gut that

<!-- chunk -->

## are prone to fermentation and predispose to a toxic state in the

<!-- chunk -->

## gut.

<!-- chunk -->

## We need to eliminate food residues as well as the waste

<!-- chunk -->

## products of cellular metabolism every day, to help prevent

<!-- chunk -->

## fermentation and toxicity and the absorption of these toxins into

<!-- chunk -->

## the blood stream, and thence into the whole body. Dysbiosis, or a

<!-- chunk -->

## toxic state of the bowel involving a disturbance of the bacterial

<!-- chunk -->

## population of the gut, is increasingly being recognised as one of

<!-- chunk -->

## the underlying causes of many health problems including IBS,

<!-- chunk -->

## allergies, auto-immune disease and obesity.

<!-- chunk -->

# The Nervous System

# Our nervous system is an amazing

# communication network, by which the brain and

# nerve cells send messages via neurotransmitters

# across synapses from one nerve cell to another, or

# to a bunch of muscle fibres. It is a wonderful

# example of the intimate link between mind and

# body; in fact they are one and the same thing.

<!-- chunk -->

## Part of our physical body, the nervous system is made up of

<!-- chunk -->

## nerve cells (neurons) and fibres, which comprise the brain and

<!-- chunk -->

## spinal cord, the peripheral nerves and the autonomic nervous

<!-- chunk -->

## system. Tiny sacs filled with neurotransmitters are stored at the

<!-- chunk -->

## end of each neuron. There are gaps between each neuron called

<!-- chunk -->

## synapses. When a nerve impulse reaches the end of the nerve

<!-- chunk -->

## cell, it triggers the sacs to release the neurotransmitters into the

<!-- chunk -->

## synapses, which then float across the synaptic space until they

<!-- chunk -->

## reach the neighbouring neuron. The neurotransmitters then click

<!-- chunk -->

## into specialized receptor sites on the next neuron, which then

<!-- chunk -->

## fires an electrical impulse down its length. This causes the

<!-- chunk -->

## transmission of nerve impulses through the nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

## Glutamate and GABA are the most abundant neurotransmitters

<!-- chunk -->

## in the central nervous system, and especially in the cerebral

<!-- chunk -->

## cortex, which is where thinking occurs and sensations are

<!-- chunk -->

## interpreted. GABA receptors are very common in our nervous

<!-- chunk -->

## systems; in fact, about 40% of the synapses in the brain have

<!-- chunk -->

## GABA receptors. GABA is made from glutamate and its

<!-- chunk -->

## function is to inhibit the transmission of nerve impulses from one

<!-- chunk -->

## neuron to another, reducing the anxiety and stress that happens

<!-- chunk -->

## when the neurons are overexcited. Serotonin is another

<!-- chunk -->

## neurotransmitter and it enhances GABA. Without sufficient

<!-- chunk -->

## GABA, our neurons fire too often and too easily and this can

<!-- chunk -->

## give rise to a range of nervous problems including anxiety

<!-- chunk -->

## disorders, panic attacks, depression, seizure disorders,

<!-- chunk -->

## addictions, headaches, Parkinson's disease and cognitive

<!-- chunk -->

## impairment.

<!-- chunk -->

## The nervous system is responsible for carrying out physical

<!-- chunk -->

## actions and registering sensations, while at the same time it is the

<!-- chunk -->

## tool for our experience and the expression of all our thoughts

<!-- chunk -->

## and feelings. Physical imbalances and disease can affect the way

<!-- chunk -->

## we think and feel, while every thought and emotion has a direct

<!-- chunk -->

## effect on our physical state. Negative thoughts and feelings sap

<!-- chunk -->

## our energy and vitality and reduce resistance, and are expressed

<!-- chunk -->

## as symptoms such as migraine, peptic ulcers and heart disease.

<!-- chunk -->

## Happiness and positivity directly affect the chemistry of our

<!-- chunk -->

## tissues and secretions in the body and help to create health and

<!-- chunk -->

## vibrancy.

<!-- chunk -->

### The central nervous system includes

### the brain and spinal cord and is

### nervous activities. The peripheral

<!-- chunk -->

# Stress Hormones

<!-- chunk -->

## Stress is part of our everyday lives; there is very little escaping it!

<!-- chunk -->

## And yet some of us are better at dealing with it than others. Our

<!-- chunk -->

## strength and resilience can be worn down by long term mental or

<!-- chunk -->

## emotional difficulties, acute trauma, overwork, lack of sleep,

<!-- chunk -->

## chronic or regular illness, poor diet and digestive problems

<!-- chunk -->

## which inhibit absorption of nutrients. When we feel anxious,

<!-- chunk -->

## fearful, upset or angry, a chain of physiological events is sparked

<!-- chunk -->

## off; messages to secrete stress hormones such as adrenaline and

<!-- chunk -->

## cortisol are triggered from the hypothalamus, pituitary and

<!-- chunk -->

## adrenal glands which flood our bodies and have far-reaching

<!-- chunk -->

## effects throughout the body. The “fight or flight” response is set

<!-- chunk -->

## off, our heart rate increases, our breath quickens as more oxygen

<!-- chunk -->

## flows through the lungs, blood flow is increased to our muscles

<!-- chunk -->

## which are tensed up ready for action to protect our body in an

<!-- chunk -->

## emergency. When the stress response fires continually for days,

<!-- chunk -->

## months, even years, it can put a strain on our body and put our

<!-- chunk -->

## health at risk. For example, under stress, our heart pumps faster,

<!-- chunk -->

## our blood vessels constrict to divert more oxygen to our muscles,

<!-- chunk -->

## which raises our blood pressure. Frequent or chronic stress will

<!-- chunk -->

## make our heart work too hard for too long, our blood pressure

<!-- chunk -->

## can remain high and this increases the risk of having a stroke or

<!-- chunk -->

## heart attack.

# The Gut-Brain Connection

<!-- chunk -->

## It is well known that there is a strong, two-way connection

<!-- chunk -->

## between the gastro-intestinal tract and the central nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

## When adrenaline is secreted, our digestive enzymes do not flow

<!-- chunk -->

## in the same way; we don't digest and absorb the food we eat

<!-- chunk -->

## properly and this allows a residue of undigested or partially

<!-- chunk -->

## digested food to sit around in the gut and ferment, causing a

<!-- chunk -->

## whole range of digestive disturbances and upsetting the

<!-- chunk -->

## metabolism of the body.

<!-- chunk -->

## Just as we have neurons in our brain, we also have them in our

<!-- chunk -->

## gut where they are known as the enteric nervous system.

<!-- chunk -->

## Neurons in the gut include those that produce neurotransmitters

<!-- chunk -->

## such as serotonin, the “happy hormone”; apparently about 90%

<!-- chunk -->

## of serotonin is found in our gut in the entero-chromaffin cells,

<!-- chunk -->

## where it is used to regulate intestinal movements. The remainder

<!-- chunk -->

## is synthesised in serotonergic neurons of the brain, where it has

<!-- chunk -->

## various functions including the regulation of mood, feelings of

<!-- chunk -->

## wellbeing and happiness, appetite and sleep. Serotonin also has

<!-- chunk -->

## some cognitive functions, including memory and learning.

<!-- chunk -->

### Happiness and positivity directly

<!-- chunk -->

### affect our body chemistry and help to

<!-- chunk -->

### create health and vibrancy.

<!-- chunk -->

## Recent years have witnessed the rise of the bacterial population

<!-- chunk -->

## of the gut (gut microbiota) as a major topic of research. It is

<!-- chunk -->

## becoming clear that the central nervous system can affect the

<!-- chunk -->

## microbiota and the microbiota has a significant influence on the

<!-- chunk -->

## brain and our behaviour. Within the gut, some organisms are

<!-- chunk -->

## commensal, meaning they have a non-harmful coexistence with

<!-- chunk -->

## us, other are mutualistic, with mutual benefit, and some can be

<!-- chunk -->

## harmful or pathogenic.

<!-- chunk -->

## The commensal and mutualistic microbiota have many roles;

<!-- chunk -->

## they maintain normal mucosal immune function, the integrity of

<!-- chunk -->

## the gut lining and the absorption of nutrients. They synthesise

<!-- chunk -->

## vitamins and short chain fatty acids, and break down dietary

<!-- chunk -->

## toxins, making them less harmful. They inhibit the overgrowth

<!-- chunk -->

## of pathogenic micro-organisms and stimulate local immunity,

<!-- chunk -->

## inhibiting infections like Salmonella, parasites such as pinworms,

<!-- chunk -->

## and decreasing the risk of food poisoning. They also enhance

<!-- chunk -->

## general immunity; in fact, four-fifths of the body's immune

<!-- chunk -->

## system is found in the gut lining. Our gut flora can release

<!-- chunk -->

## molecules that directly influence the chemistry of the brain

<!-- chunk -->

## including the regulation of the production of neurotransmitters,

<!-- chunk -->

## thereby affecting our mood and behaviour. GABA is one of the

<!-- chunk -->

## neurotransmitters in the brain influenced by the gut flora that has

<!-- chunk -->

## a calming or quieting influence.

<!-- chunk -->

## Variations and changes in the composition of the gut

<!-- chunk -->

## microbiota can fundamentally influence our normal physiology

<!-- chunk -->

## and contribute to diseases ranging from inflammation to obesity,

<!-- chunk -->

## headaches, panic attacks and depression. The use of antibiotics,

<!-- chunk -->

## synthetic hormones and steroids, as well as poor digestion and

<!-- chunk -->

## stress can all contribute to the proliferation of pathogenic yeasts

<!-- chunk -->

## and bacteria in the gut (dysbiosis). These create toxins, destroy

<!-- chunk -->

## vitamins, inactivate digestive enzymes and lead to the formation

<!-- chunk -->

## of chemicals which are toxic. They can provoke inflammatory

<!-- chunk -->

## diseases including ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease and arthritis

<!-- chunk -->

## by causing autoimmune reactions and leaky gut syndrome, as

<!-- chunk -->

## well as a host of neurological and mood disturbances including

<!-- chunk -->

## anxiety, depression and lethargy.

# The Immune System

# The immune system consists of the lymphatic

# system, white blood cells, and specialised cells

# and chemicals, including antibodies. When

# infection threatens to overcome our homeostatic

# mechanisms and invade the body, the immune

# system rallies its defences to deal with it.

<!-- chunk -->

## The lymphatic system produces more lymphocytes and

<!-- chunk -->

## macrophages which work with cytokine chemicals to destroy the

<!-- chunk -->

## invaders. The thymus gland aids the production of, and stores,

<!-- chunk -->

## white blood cells known as T-cells, which attack cells infected by

<!-- chunk -->

## bacteria, fungi and viruses. The spleen, liver, tonsils, adenoids

<!-- chunk -->

## and wall of the intestine also contain lymphatic tissue. The

<!-- chunk -->

## lymphatic tissue lining the gut is responsible for maintaining

<!-- chunk -->

## lymphocytes capable of responding to all the antigens that enter

<!-- chunk -->

## the body through food entering the digestive tract.

<!-- chunk -->

## Should these protective mechanisms fail, specific immune

<!-- chunk -->

## responses occur. Molecules on the surface of infecting organisms

<!-- chunk -->

## (antigens) stimulate lymphocytes and produce antibodies to

<!-- chunk -->

## destroy the antigens. These have a memory so that antigens are

<!-- chunk -->

## recognised should infection reoccur, ensuring the body is able to

<!-- chunk -->

## respond effectively with the organisms before an infection

<!-- chunk -->

## develops.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## is essential to have plenty of nutritious, natural, preferably

<!-- chunk -->

## organic food to eat, a balance of work and play, exercise and

<!-- chunk -->

## relaxation, sufficient sleep, a minimum of pollution in our

<!-- chunk -->

## environment, a positive attitude to dealing with stress and the

<!-- chunk -->

## cultivation of practices to engender peace of mind. A positive

<!-- chunk -->

## outlook, fun, laughter, serenity, being in beautiful, peaceful

<!-- chunk -->

## surroundings, and clean air can all boost immunity. Our natural

<!-- chunk -->

## immunity is clearly lowered by physical or emotional stress,

<!-- chunk -->

## burning the candle at both ends, poor diet, toxins, smoking

<!-- chunk -->

## cigarettes, and drinking excess alcohol.

<!-- chunk -->

## considering immunity. If our “digestive fire” is good, the food

## eaten will be digested and assimilated well and the residue of

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

# The Respiratory System

# The respiratory system is responsible for

# supplying the blood with oxygen, which then

# carries it to the cells of the body which require

# oxygen to carry out their vital functions. As they

# use oxygen they give off carbon dioxide as a

# waste product, which is then carried to the lungs

# where it is exhaled.

<!-- chunk -->

## Oxygen is breathed in through the mouth and the nose and then

<!-- chunk -->

## passes through the larynx and trachea into the chest cavity. The

<!-- chunk -->

## trachea then divides into 2 bronchi, which branch into numerous

<!-- chunk -->

## bronchial tubes leading to the lungs where they divide into many

<!-- chunk -->

## smaller tubes which connect to tiny air sacs called alveoli. Our

<!-- chunk -->

## lungs contain about 600 million alveoli, and these allow oxygen

<!-- chunk -->

## to diffuse through them into the surrounding capillaries, and for

<!-- chunk -->

## carbon dioxide from the veins to enter the respiratory system to

<!-- chunk -->

## be exhaled by the same pathway. Breathing is brought about by

<!-- chunk -->

## movements of the diaphragm, a sheet of muscle lying at the base

<!-- chunk -->

## of the chest. When it contracts, oxygen is pulled into the lungs

<!-- chunk -->

## and when it relaxes, carbon dioxide is pumped out.

<!-- chunk -->

## We may be able to go days without food and water but only a

<!-- chunk -->

## few minutes without air. To ensure sufficient intake of oxygen

<!-- chunk -->

## we need to have a healthy respiratory system, plenty of fresh air

<!-- chunk -->

## and exercise and to breathe properly. Congestion of the airways

<!-- chunk -->

## from excess catarrh reduces the amount of oxygen we take in.

<!-- chunk -->

## The quality of the air is also of vital importance. Pollution,

<!-- chunk -->

## cigarette smoke, carbon monoxide and lead from car fumes are

<!-- chunk -->

## all things that can become pollution in the lungs, which is then

<!-- chunk -->

## carried in the blood round the body and into the cells.

<!-- chunk -->

## In India air is called prana, the breath of life, gases vital for

<!-- chunk -->

## normal functioning of our cells and tissues, as well as the energy

<!-- chunk -->

## of the atmosphere around us, which radiates from the trees and

<!-- chunk -->

## other green plants and ultimately from the sun. Correct breathing

<!-- chunk -->

## is important for our nerves and muscles to enable relaxation and

<!-- chunk -->

## rest, as well as engendering a clear alert mind. In many cultures

<!-- chunk -->

## and religions the use of the breath is central to spiritual practices

<!-- chunk -->

## such as yoga and meditation and traditional movements like Qi

<!-- chunk -->

## Gong and Tai Chi.

<!-- chunk -->

## The respiratory system is open to the atmosphere via the nose

<!-- chunk -->

## and mouth and so vulnerable to airborne irritation and infection.

<!-- chunk -->

## It also functions as a pathway for elimination of toxins, along

<!-- chunk -->

## with the skin, the bowels and the urinary tract. If the body is

<!-- chunk -->

## overloaded with toxins it can overburden the respiratory system

<!-- chunk -->

## and lead to problems. For this reason, our overall health needs to

<!-- chunk -->

## be considered when treating respiratory problems.

<!-- chunk -->

# The Urinary System

# The urinary system consists of the kidneys,

# bladder and ureters. During circulation, blood

# passes through the kidneys, which act as an

# elaborate filtering system. They remove used and

# unwanted water, minerals, urea and wastes from

# the blood which becomes urine, and reabsorb

# what is still required by the body back into the

# bloodstream.

<!-- chunk -->

## In this way the kidneys control the amount of water and salts that

<!-- chunk -->

## are absorbed back into the blood and what is excreted as waste.

<!-- chunk -->

## They also help maintain the correct acid/alkali balance in the

<!-- chunk -->

## body. The kidneys funnel the urine into the bladder along 2 tubes

<!-- chunk -->

## which are the ureters. The bladder stores the urine until muscular

<!-- chunk -->

## contractions push it out through the urethra. Each day, your

<!-- chunk -->

## kidneys produce about 1.5 litres of urine. The Chinese value the

<!-- chunk -->

## kidneys as the seat of vital energy, known as kidney Jing, which

<!-- chunk -->

## promotes longevity and immunity.

<!-- chunk -->

## The urinary tract is prone to damage from the effects of an

<!-- chunk -->

## unhealthy lifestyle, poor diet and pollution. Solvents, paint,

<!-- chunk -->

## synthetic fragrances and colours, preservatives and nitrogenous

<!-- chunk -->

## waste from a high protein diet have to be passed out of the body

<!-- chunk -->

## via urine, and all impose a strain on the kidneys and can

<!-- chunk -->

## contribute to urinary problems. Urinary tract infections can affect

<!-- chunk -->

## the urethra, then pass into the bladder causing cystitis. From the

<!-- chunk -->

## bladder, infection can pass along the ureters to the kidneys and

<!-- chunk -->

## cause pyelonephritis. Other kidney infections can develop as

<!-- chunk -->

## secondaries from infection, such as Streptococcal throat

<!-- chunk -->

## infection, causing tonsillitis. Infections in babies and children

<!-- chunk -->

## may be related to structural abnormalities, but most often they

<!-- chunk -->

## are caused by E. Coli bacteria from the bowel that creep round

<!-- chunk -->

## from the anus, their journey aided by wiping from back to front

<!-- chunk -->

## rather than vice versa after urination or a bowel movement.

<!-- chunk -->

## Urinary tract infections tend to affect girls more than boys due to

<!-- chunk -->

## their anatomical differences, in that the passage from the urethra

<!-- chunk -->

## to the bladder is much shorter in girls. Vaginal infections, such as

<!-- chunk -->

## thrush, can also be related to urinary tract infections.

<!-- chunk -->

## It is important to drink plenty of fluids to assist the kidneys in

<!-- chunk -->

## their cleansing work, to flush through toxins and the waste

<!-- chunk -->

## products of metabolism, and to prevent them from causing

<!-- chunk -->

## irritation of the urinary tract along the way.

<!-- chunk -->

## There are many herbs that exert their action on the urinary

<!-- chunk -->

## system and which can be used preventatively and therapeutically.

<!-- chunk -->

## Mucilaginous herbs like marshmallow, corn silk, slippery elm,

<!-- chunk -->

## aloe vera and oats soothe irritation and inflammation. Aromatic

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs rich in antimicrobial volatile oils with a diuretic action,

<!-- chunk -->

## including chamomile, fennel, lemon balm, thyme and coriander,

<!-- chunk -->

## taken regularly as teas or in food are excellent for helping to

<!-- chunk -->

## prevent infection. Cranberries and bilberries/blueberries are also

<!-- chunk -->

## valuable, helping to prevent infection by preventing pathogenic

<!-- chunk -->

# The Circulatory System

# Our bodies contain about 5 litres of blood,

# consisting of plasma, red blood cells, white blood

# cells, and platelets, which is continually

# transported around the body via the circulatory

# system. Its purpose is to carry oxygen, hormones,

# gases and nutrients to every cell of the body and

# to take away the waste products of metabolism.

<!-- chunk -->

## The blood is also responsible for maintaining the correct body

<!-- chunk -->

## temperature and ph of the body. The circulatory system also

<!-- chunk -->

## includes the transport of lymph. The lymphatic system distributes

<!-- chunk -->

## immune cells called lymphocytes which protect the body against

<!-- chunk -->

## infection, it absorbs lipids from the gut and carries them to the

<!-- chunk -->

## blood. With the circulatory system, it returns fluids and plasma

<!-- chunk -->

## proteins from cells and tissues to the blood, and thus maintains

<!-- chunk -->

## fluid balance.

<!-- chunk -->

## The heart pumps oxygen and nutrient-rich blood into the aorta,

<!-- chunk -->

## the main artery, from where it flows about 60,000 miles through

<!-- chunk -->

## a vast network of vessels of different sizes, arteries and

<!-- chunk -->

## capillaries, to reach and nourish all the tissues of the body. Once

<!-- chunk -->

## the waste products, including carbon dioxide, are collected from

<!-- chunk -->

## the cells, the deoxygenated blood flows into the veins and is

<!-- chunk -->

## circulated back to the heart and the lungs where carbon dioxide

<!-- chunk -->

## and oxygen are exchanged. On its journey round the body, the

<!-- chunk -->

## blood passes through the kidneys which filter much of the waste

<!-- chunk -->

## from the blood. It also passes through the small intestine and into

<!-- chunk -->

## the portal vein which passes through the liver, where sugars from

<!-- chunk -->

## the blood are filtered and stored.

<!-- chunk -->

## Most circulatory problems are caused by blocked arteries,

<!-- chunk -->

## which in turn are caused by atherosclerosis or hardening of the

<!-- chunk -->

## arteries. For the heart muscle to work efficiently it requires its

<!-- chunk -->

## own supply of oxygenated blood, which is carried through four

<!-- chunk -->

## small coronary arteries. Should these become blocked and

<!-- chunk -->

## prevent blood flow to the heart muscle, serious damage to the

<!-- chunk -->

## heart may occur.

<!-- chunk -->

## There are several factors that contribute to circulatory

<!-- chunk -->

## problems, including high blood pressure, high blood cholesterol,

<!-- chunk -->

## smoking, obesity, heredity, lack of exercise and emotional stress.

<!-- chunk -->

## Damage or stress to the inner lining of the blood vessels leads

<!-- chunk -->

## over time to a build-up of debris and narrowing of the artery,

<!-- chunk -->

## predisposing to blockage. High homocysteine levels increase the

<!-- chunk -->

## build up of plaque in the arteries and emotional stress can cause

<!-- chunk -->

## the release biochemicals that contribute to the injury of arterial

<!-- chunk -->

## tissues. Inflammation within the blood vessels can also cause the

<!-- chunk -->

## deposition of cholesterol as a protective mechanism. Cholesterol

<!-- chunk -->

## from excess dietary sugar and carbohydrates, or errors of the

<!-- chunk -->

## liver's metabolism of cholesterol can also line and narrow the

<!-- chunk -->

## arteries, making them susceptible to plaque deposits.

<!-- chunk -->

# The Musculo-skeletal System

# Our musculo-skeletal system consists of bones,

# muscles, tendons, ligaments, joints, cartilage and

# other connective tissue, which together provide

# the form and stability of the body and enable

# movement. Bones provide the structure of the

# body and protect the delicate internal structures

# such as the brain, spinal column, lungs and heart.

# They contain bone marrow where specialised

# cells including stem cells manufacture red blood

# cells.

<!-- chunk -->

## Although bone seems hard and rigid, bone cells are constantly

<!-- chunk -->

## being made and replaced and it is completely re-formed every

<!-- chunk -->

## years. The hard outer part is made mainly of protein such as

<!-- chunk -->

## collagen and hydroxyapatite, which largely consists of calcium

<!-- chunk -->

## and other minerals. Bones depend on minerals including calcium,

<!-- chunk -->

## and vitamin D for their density and strength. They also rely on

<!-- chunk -->

## activity and weight bearing exercise and the action of hormones,

<!-- chunk -->

## including growth and parathyroid hormone, oestrogen,

<!-- chunk -->

## testosterone, and calcitonin. They need a good blood supply

<!-- chunk -->

## which is brought to them by vessels that enter via their outer

<!-- chunk -->

## membrane, the periosteum, where most of their nerve supply is

<!-- chunk -->

## located.

<!-- chunk -->

## The junctions between bones are our joints, of which some,

<!-- chunk -->

## such as the shoulder and knee joints, move and allow a wide

<!-- chunk -->

## range of movement and some, like those in the skull, do not.

<!-- chunk -->

## Joints are designed to provide stability and protect against

<!-- chunk -->

## damage from use. They are lined with synovial fluid which

<!-- chunk -->

## provides nourishment to cartilage on the end of bones and

<!-- chunk -->

## prevents friction as they move. Cartilage is a tough and resilient

<!-- chunk -->

## tissue composed of collagen and proteoglycans that also prevents

<!-- chunk -->

## friction as the joints move. Ligaments are strong elastic fibrous

<!-- chunk -->

## cords composed largely of connective collagen surrounding the

<!-- chunk -->

## joints, and these act to strengthen and stabilise them. Their

<!-- chunk -->

## elasticity allows movement and protects the joints by ensuring

<!-- chunk -->

## that these movements are only in certain directions.

<!-- chunk -->

## There are 3 types of muscles: skeletal, smooth and cardiac.

<!-- chunk -->

## Skeletal muscles are bundles of elastic fibres attached to bones

<!-- chunk -->

## and joints. They contract and relax, enabling smooth, controlled

<!-- chunk -->

## movements and maintain our posture. The action of skeletal

<!-- chunk -->

## muscle is voluntary, controlled by the conscious brain unlike

<!-- chunk -->

## smooth muscle in the blood vessels, chest and abdominal organs

<!-- chunk -->

## and cardiac muscle in the heart which is involuntary. Their

<!-- chunk -->

## growth, strength and elasticity depends on growth hormone and

<!-- chunk -->

## testosterone and is maintained and increased by regular exercise.

<!-- chunk -->

## The health of our musculo-skeletal system depends on good

<!-- chunk -->

## diet, digestion, absorption and elimination. Over-using or

<!-- chunk -->

## neglecting certain groups of muscles, posture, and the amount of

<!-- chunk -->

## fresh air and exercise we take all have their effect. Stress and the

<!-- chunk -->

## inability to relax put a strain on the system and can contribute to

<!-- chunk -->

## joint and muscle problems. The biggest factor however is age.

<!-- chunk -->

## From around the age of 30 our bone density diminishes, and this

<!-- chunk -->

## accelerates in women after the menopause, meaning that our

<!-- chunk -->

## bones become more fragile and prone to fractures and breaks.

<!-- chunk -->

## Changes in cartilage and connective tissue affect the strength and

<!-- chunk -->

## stability of the joints. Thinning of the cartilage makes the joint

<!-- chunk -->

## more susceptible to damage and to wear and tear, predisposing to

<!-- chunk -->

## osteoarthritis. The connective tissue in the ligaments and tendons

<!-- chunk -->

## becomes less elastic, which can cause stiffness and limited

<!-- chunk -->

## movement. Muscle tissue is also affected and the size and

<!-- chunk -->

## strength of muscles gradually diminishes, which means less

<!-- chunk -->

## support and stability generally, and particularly of the joints,

<!-- chunk -->

## making them more prone to damage.

<!-- chunk -->

# The Skin

# Our skin is a mirror of our health and plays many

# important roles in the body. It protects us against

# dirt, infection, extremes of temperate and climate,

# sunlight, pollution, and physical injury. It secretes

# antiseptic substances to ward off infection, backed

# up by beneficial flora that live on the skin and the

# acid mantle formed by sweat, also helping to

# inhibit infection.

<!-- chunk -->

## Below the outer layer of skin, the epidermis, is the dermis, a

<!-- chunk -->

## thick, strong and elastic layer of tissue which is richly supplied

<!-- chunk -->

## with blood vessels, sweat and oil glands, and nerve endings.

<!-- chunk -->

## When the weather is cold the blood vessels contract to keep heat

<!-- chunk -->

## inside the body, and when it is hot they dilate to bring blood to

<!-- chunk -->

## the surface to enable the body to loose heat and maintain the

<!-- chunk -->

## correct temperature of the body.

<!-- chunk -->

## The several million sweat glands enable the skin to be a major

<!-- chunk -->

## organ of excretion. Sweat contains water, mineral salts,

<!-- chunk -->

## nitrogenous wastes and other toxins and is similar in content to

<!-- chunk -->

## urine. Most adults excrete about 1 pint (600mls) of fluid through

<!-- chunk -->

## the skin daily and up to ten times more when taking vigorous

<!-- chunk -->

## exercise or in hot weather. It is important to take sufficient

<!-- chunk -->

## exercise to produce a sweat on a regular basis, in order to clear

<!-- chunk -->

## toxins and not overburden the other pathways of elimination, the

<!-- chunk -->

## kidneys and bowels. Sweat production also helps maintain a

<!-- chunk -->

## stable inner environment by regulating the water and electrolyte

<!-- chunk -->

## balance in the body, and in this way it works hand in hand with

<!-- chunk -->

## the kidneys.

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

### dermis and sub-cutaneous tissue. The

<!-- chunk -->

### hypodermis connects the skin to

<!-- chunk -->

### muscle and bone.

<!-- chunk -->

## endings which relay messages to the brain about sensations from

<!-- chunk -->

## the environment, heat or cold, pleasure or pain. It can be a useful

<!-- chunk -->

## diagnostic tool, reflecting the effect of our outer environment as

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

<!-- chunk -->

## emotional problems like anxiety or grief.

<!-- chunk -->
