# The Eyes

# Often described as the “gateway to the soul”, our

# eyes are one of the sense organs and clearly

# express emotions like joy, excitement and

# happiness as well as fear, anxiety, anger, grief,

# and suffering. As such they convey much about

# our state of health both physically and mentally.

<!-- chunk -->

## The white, opaque part of the eye is the sclera which protects the

<!-- chunk -->

## eye and serves as an attachment for the muscles that move it.

<!-- chunk -->

## Light passes through the transparent cornea, which is like a dome

<!-- chunk -->

## at the front of the eye, under which is the iris and pupil. The iris

<!-- chunk -->

## is the coloured part of the eye which is composed of muscles that

<!-- chunk -->

## govern the amount of light that enters it, while the pupil is the

<!-- chunk -->

## hole that lets light pass through into the back of the eye. The

<!-- chunk -->

## aqueous humour is the fluid between the lens and cornea and the

<!-- chunk -->

## vitreous humour is the fluid in the major part of the eyeball. The

<!-- chunk -->

## crystalline lens behind the pupil focuses light onto the retina,

<!-- chunk -->

## which is composed of thousands of tiny structures known as

<!-- chunk -->

## rods and cones, which are responsible for conveying messages

<!-- chunk -->

## via the optic nerve to the brain, and ultimately results in vision.

<!-- chunk -->

## Light also influences our physical health, and mental and

<!-- chunk -->

## emotional state. Sunlight entering the eye stimulates the secretion

<!-- chunk -->

## of endorphins by the pineal gland and these give us a feeling of

<!-- chunk -->

## well-being. During the winter months in the Northern

<!-- chunk -->

## Hemisphere the many hours of darkness can predispose to

<!-- chunk -->

## seasonal affective disorder (SAD) and reduced resistance to

<!-- chunk -->

## infection, so it is important to spend time outside in sunlight,

<!-- chunk -->

## even on a dull day.

<!-- chunk -->

## The production of tears and crying is another important

<!-- chunk -->

## function of the eyes. Tears contain endorphins, which are opiate-

<!-- chunk -->

## like substances that help us to release emotional pain and tension

<!-- chunk -->

## and calm us down. In addition, tears washed constantly in tiny

<!-- chunk -->

## amounts across the eyes protect them from damage and help

<!-- chunk -->

## clear away debris. The inner and outer surfaces of each eye are

<!-- chunk -->

## covered with the delicate conjunctiva lubricated by tears which

<!-- chunk -->

## drain into the channels passing into the nose. The eyelids also

<!-- chunk -->

## protect the eyes.

<!-- chunk -->

## There are certain nutrients which are vital to eye health. Lutein

<!-- chunk -->

## and zeaxanthin are antioxidant carotenoids found in dark, green,

<!-- chunk -->

## leafy vegetables such as spinach, kale, squash, peas, broccoli,

<!-- chunk -->

## corn and eggs. It helps protect the eyes from oxidative stress and

<!-- chunk -->

## high-energy light. It is found in the macula, a small area of the

<!-- chunk -->

## retina responsible for central vision, and a diet rich in lutein helps

<!-- chunk -->

## to prevent cataracts and macular degeneration as we get older.

<!-- chunk -->

## Essential fatty acids including omega-3 from fatty fish, walnuts,

<!-- chunk -->

## soya beans and flax seeds are also vital. High levels of

<!-- chunk -->

## antioxidant vitamins A, C and E can reduce the risk of cataracts

<!-- chunk -->

## and also play a role in delaying age-related macular

<!-- chunk -->

## degeneration. Copper found in mixed nuts, sunflower seeds,

<!-- chunk -->

## liver, beans and lentils is another antioxidant that has a specific

<!-- chunk -->

## relevance to the eyes. Red meat and poultry contain a good level

<!-- chunk -->

## of zinc. Zinc found in oysters, fortified cereals, nuts, beans, red

<!-- chunk -->

## meat and poultry is also important to eye health and the

<!-- chunk -->

## maintenance of good vision through macular function.

<!-- chunk -->

## Elderberries and bilberries are rich in antioxidants, known as

<!-- chunk -->

## anthocyanocides, and help to protect the eyes. Anthocyanocides

<!-- chunk -->

## contain or boost the action of a molecule known as glutathione, a

<!-- chunk -->

## key antioxidant found in the aqueous humour and necessary for

<!-- chunk -->

## prevention of a variety of eye problems, including cataracts, in

<!-- chunk -->

## later life. They help support the repair and synthesis of new

<!-- chunk -->

## capillaries and are used to improve night vision and treat

<!-- chunk -->

## disorders of the retina. Other herbs with a similar action include

<!-- chunk -->

## astragalus root, milk thistle seed, turmeric root, and garlic. The

<!-- chunk -->

## eyelids and conjunctiva are prone to various problems which can

<!-- chunk -->

## be successfully treated using herbs including chamomile,

<!-- chunk -->

## calendula, marshmallow and elderflowers.

# The Hormonal System

# The hormonal or endocrine system is a system of

# chemical messaging. Its purpose is

# communication and coordinating many different

# functions of the body which enable homeostasis,

# i.e. maintaining the stable state within the body

# which is vital for health. These include tissue

# function, metabolism and the production of

# energy, reproduction, mood, growth and

# development.

<!-- chunk -->

## These huge feats are accomplished via a network of endocrine

<!-- chunk -->

## glands and organs that produce, store, and secrete hormones as

<!-- chunk -->

## they are required by the body. They work in conjunction with the

<!-- chunk -->

## nervous system, reproductive system, kidneys, gut, liver and

<!-- chunk -->

## pancreas. Hormones are special chemicals that are manufactured

<!-- chunk -->

## by one cell or a group of cells and carried in the bloodstream to

<!-- chunk -->

## specific targets, which may be organs, tissues, or cells. Different

<!-- chunk -->

## types of hormones cause different effects on other cells or tissues

<!-- chunk -->

## of the body. Endocrine glands are located in many regions of the

<!-- chunk -->

## body, and include the hypothalamus, which controls the pituitary

<!-- chunk -->

## or master gland, and which in turn controls the other glands

<!-- chunk -->

## which include the thyroid, parathyroid, thymus and adrenal

<!-- chunk -->

## glands, the pancreas, the ovaries and testis.

<!-- chunk -->

## For healthy functioning of our endocrine system, the glands

<!-- chunk -->

## need to work correctly, the blood needs to carry hormones

<!-- chunk -->

## efficiently to their target points, and the receptor sites on the

<!-- chunk -->

## target cells need to respond properly for the hormones to enter

<!-- chunk -->

## the cells and do their work. Too much or too little of any of the

<!-- chunk -->

## hormones secreted by these glands can cause disruption in the

<!-- chunk -->

## body. For example too much growth hormone from the pituitary

<!-- chunk -->

## gland will mean you grow excessively tall. Too little and you will

<!-- chunk -->

## be very short. Too little insulin from the pancreas causes

<!-- chunk -->

## diabetes. Excess thyroid hormones cause an increase in

<!-- chunk -->

## metabolism which imposes a strain on the nervous system and

<!-- chunk -->

## heart, while low thyroid function causes lethargy and weight

<!-- chunk -->

## problems. Imbalances of reproductive hormones cause a wide

<!-- chunk -->

## range of menstrual, sexual and gynaecological problems and

<!-- chunk -->

## influence fertility. Such hormonal imbalances may be caused by

<!-- chunk -->

## problems with cell receptor sites, problems regulating the

<!-- chunk -->

## hormones in the blood stream, or the body may have difficulty

<!-- chunk -->

## controlling hormone levels due to poor breakdown and excretion

<!-- chunk -->

## of hormones from the body due to low liver or kidney function.

<!-- chunk -->

## For our hormonal system to function well we need to eat a

<!-- chunk -->

## healthy diet, with plenty of essential fatty acids, minerals,

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly magnesium, trace elements and antioxidant nutrients

<!-- chunk -->

## including beta carotene, zinc, selenium, and vitamins B, C, and

<!-- chunk -->

## E. Stress, coffee and alcohol and nutritional deficiencies can

<!-- chunk -->

## significantly disrupt hormonal balance. Herbs such as liquorice

<!-- chunk -->

## and echinacea support the thymus gland in its immune work;

<!-- chunk -->

## bladderwrack and ashwagandha influence the thyroid; vitex

<!-- chunk -->

## helps to regulate the pituitary gland; liquorice, wild yam and

<!-- chunk -->

## ginsengs influence the adrenals; wild yam, black cohosh, vitex,

<!-- chunk -->

## shatavari, ashwagandha and ginseng all help regulate

<!-- chunk -->

## reproductive hormones. Bitter herbs such as dandelion root, milk

<!-- chunk -->

## thistle and burdock help the liver's breakdown of hormones so

<!-- chunk -->

## they are excreted from the body once they have done their work.

<!-- chunk -->

# Growing, Harvesting and Storing

# Herbs

# There's no better way to be sure of the provenance

# of your herbs than growing them yourself; then

# you will be sure of their identity, be reassured of

# their organic status and be able to harvest them at

# the most potent time for their active ingredients.

# Many herbs are easy to grow – indeed a few are

# considered invasive weeds by some – and

# instructions on preparing the soil, sowing and

# propagating, harvesting and preserving herbs to

# retain their maximum therapeutic properties are

# included in this chapter.

# Growing Herbs

# Herbs are greatly rewarding plants to grow.

# Providing they have suitable soil and shelter from

# prevailing winds, most medicinal herbs grow

# easily in temperate climates, with no specialist

# knowledge or skills required. Any herbs that

# originate from tropical regions will take a little

# more care, can be put outside only after the last

# frosts have gone, and should be taken indoors in

# the autumn.

<!-- chunk -->

## A herb garden can be as large or small, and as formal or informal

<!-- chunk -->

## as you like. Whatever space you have available can be adapted to

<!-- chunk -->

## growing herbs. They can be intermingled with flowers and

<!-- chunk -->

## shrubs in large or small herbaceous borders, adding interest and

<!-- chunk -->

## beauty with their attractive foliage and architectural shapes, not

<!-- chunk -->

## to mention their delicious scents. Or they can be planted in

<!-- chunk -->

## specially designed herb gardens, in corners of vegetable gardens,

<!-- chunk -->

## or intermingled with the vegetables (where they can work well as

<!-- chunk -->

## companion plants to deter pests). If you have less space you can

<!-- chunk -->

## plant herbs in pots on a patio or even on your window sill, or in

<!-- chunk -->

## window boxes. Both the planning and the practical laying out of

<!-- chunk -->

## a herb garden can bring many hours of pleasure and satisfaction.

<!-- chunk -->

## Medicinal herbs consist of a mixture of annuals, biennials,

<!-- chunk -->

## perennials, shrubs and even trees. Annual herbs include dill,

<!-- chunk -->

## coriander, basil, German chamomile, and marigold, and these can

<!-- chunk -->

## easily be grown from seed. Once grown they may self-seed

<!-- chunk -->

## fairly freely and can be either left to grow as they are or, as

<!-- chunk -->

## seedlings, transplanted to their preferred site in the garden in

<!-- chunk -->

## springtime. Biennials take two summers to come into flower,

<!-- chunk -->

## usually producing an attractive rosette of leaves in the first year.

<!-- chunk -->

## They include burdock, angelica, mullein, and evening primrose,

<!-- chunk -->

## all of which also self-seed freely. Herbaceous perennials continue

<!-- chunk -->

## from one year to the next, dying down in autumn and

<!-- chunk -->

## reappearing in spring the following year. They can mostly be

<!-- chunk -->

## grown from seed, but may be easier to grow from other methods

<!-- chunk -->

## of propagation such as root division, planting cuttings or offsets.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many common herbs can be bought in nurseries or garden

<!-- chunk -->

## centres, and more unusual herbs can be found in specialist herb

<!-- chunk -->

## nurseries. Pot herbs can be planted at most times of the year,

<!-- chunk -->

## except when the ground is frozen or covered with snow, and

<!-- chunk -->

## provided they are healthy they will establish themselves with

<!-- chunk -->

## very little trouble. Try to avoid planting new pot herbs in dry, hot

<!-- chunk -->

## weather, and if weather does become dry around newly planted

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs then keep them well-watered until they are fully

<!-- chunk -->

## established. Always ensure that you choose strong healthy-

<!-- chunk -->

## looking plants, free from disease or insects, and avoid straggly

<!-- chunk -->

## plants and those whose roots are escaping from the bottom of the

<!-- chunk -->

## pot. Make sure the plants are clearly labelled to avoid confusion

<!-- chunk -->

## later. If you want your herb garden to look established quickly

<!-- chunk -->

## buy 2 or 3 of each herb to plant in groups. Some fast-growing

<!-- chunk -->

## perennials may have to be moved once they grow and need more

<!-- chunk -->

## space.

# Planning Your Herb Garden

<!-- chunk -->

## Before planting your herbs it is well worth making rough plans

<!-- chunk -->

## of your garden, or the space you have available, and a planting

<!-- chunk -->

## design on paper before approaching the practical side of

<!-- chunk -->

## planting. Firstly, you need to decide where you will grow your

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs. Planting them near the house has its advantages, as it is

<!-- chunk -->

## easy to gather them, and harder to forget what you have and risk

<!-- chunk -->

## letting them go over before you notice them, which can be very

<!-- chunk -->

## annoying! You will also see and have more chance to appreciate

<!-- chunk -->

## them, and their delicious scents, the nearer you have them to the

<!-- chunk -->

## house. You also need to take into account your type of soil, and

<!-- chunk -->

## how much sun or shade you have in the space you have

<!-- chunk -->

## allocated.

# Soil Conditions

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs are fairly easy to grow, since they are generally not fussy

<!-- chunk -->

## about where they grow and will take in most situations and soils.

<!-- chunk -->

## If your soil is deep, moist and rich the plants will probably grow

<!-- chunk -->

## quickly, with lots of lush foliage, but their flavour and smell will

<!-- chunk -->

## not be as strong as herbs grown in poorer dry soil. Many of our

<!-- chunk -->

## favourite herbs, such as rosemary, sage, lavender, basil and

<!-- chunk -->

## oregano, are natives of the Mediterranean where it is dry and the

<!-- chunk -->

## soil is hard and stony, so they are used to withstanding fairly

<!-- chunk -->

## adverse conditions. Plants grown in such soils do not look so

<!-- chunk -->

## vibrant and lushly attractive but will taste and smell wonderful.

<!-- chunk -->

## However, because they grow less fast than those grown on rich,

<!-- chunk -->

## moist soil they cannot be harvested as frequently. The kind of

<!-- chunk -->

## soil that herbs tolerate least is heavy clay soil, which in wet

<!-- chunk -->

## conditions does not drain well and can become waterlogged.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many Mediterranean herbs will rot away in such damp situations.

<!-- chunk -->

## If your soil is wet and heavy add plenty of organic matter and

<!-- chunk -->

## sharp sand to lighten it and help drainage. If your soil is very

<!-- chunk -->

## light and sandy, dig in a small amount of organic matter to make

<!-- chunk -->

## it more water retentive, and therefore more able to retain

<!-- chunk -->

## nutrients in the soil.

<!-- chunk -->

## Most herbs, particularly those that originate in warm climates,

<!-- chunk -->

## like to be grown in warm, sheltered and sunny positions, while

<!-- chunk -->

## some prefer light shade, so your herb-growing area should

<!-- chunk -->

## ideally include a shady spot. This is often provided by a hedge or

<!-- chunk -->

## fence which, when suitably placed for their protection, will have

<!-- chunk -->

## another advantage in that it allows the delicate scents of aromatic

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs to linger on warm air, and not be blown away as the would

<!-- chunk -->

## in a breezy open position. However if your garden is warm and

<!-- chunk -->

## sheltered there is no need to be too concerned about enclosing it,

<!-- chunk -->

## and herbs can be planted in the open.

<!-- chunk -->

### Herbs such as angelica are biennials,

<!-- chunk -->

### and can take two summers to come

<!-- chunk -->

### into flower.

# Sowing Seeds

<!-- chunk -->

## You can buy herb seeds from specialist suppliers or save them

<!-- chunk -->

## from the previous year. For early plants, sow seeds in early

<!-- chunk -->

## spring, in pots or seed trays in a greenhouse or propagator.

<!-- chunk -->

## Using fresh seedling compost, sow the seeds evenly and

<!-- chunk -->

## sparingly by sprinkling them over the firmed surface of the soil

<!-- chunk -->

## or in shallow drills. Cover the seeds lightly with a thin layer of

<!-- chunk -->

## compost or fine sand and water with a fine rose on your watering

<!-- chunk -->

## can. Label clearly. Cover the tray with a piece of glass or plastic

<!-- chunk -->

## or a sheet of newspaper.

<!-- chunk -->

## Once the seeds have germinated, remove the newspaper, or

<!-- chunk -->

## once the seedlings reach the glass/plastic sheet, remove it. When

<!-- chunk -->

## the seedlings are large enough to handle you can thin them or

<!-- chunk -->

## transplant them to pots to encourage growth. Once they have

<!-- chunk -->

## become sturdy little plants they are ready to plant outdoors in

<!-- chunk -->

## early summer. Alternatively, you can sow seeds directly into

<!-- chunk -->

## warmer soil in late spring/early summer once all sign of winter

<!-- chunk -->

## frosts has gone. Cover the seeds with soil, the depth of which

<!-- chunk -->

## can be measured by multiplying the diameter of the seeds 2–3

<!-- chunk -->

## times.

<!-- chunk -->

### Specially designed raised beds make

<!-- chunk -->

### a feature of architectural perennials,

<!-- chunk -->

### such as globe artichoke and fennel.

<!-- chunk -->

## Growing herbs from seeds is both rewarding and fascinating,

<!-- chunk -->

## particularly if you are using seeds that you have collected

<!-- chunk -->

## yourself. You may often find that your own seeds germinate

<!-- chunk -->

## more successfully than bought ones, particularly if they are fresh

<!-- chunk -->

## and sown immediately they are ripe and ready to drop. They can

<!-- chunk -->

## be sown in trays and left in a greenhouse or cold frame covered

<!-- chunk -->

## with a piece of glass or polythene until they germinate. They

<!-- chunk -->

## may not germinate until the following spring, so you need to be

<!-- chunk -->

## fairly patient.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many herbs self-seed freely if their seed heads are left alone,

<!-- chunk -->

## for example elecampane, lady's mantle, chamomile, coriander,

<!-- chunk -->

## marigold and motherwort. Seeds will germinate when conditions

<!-- chunk -->

## are right, and will grow into strong healthy plants. If they grow

<!-- chunk -->

## where you don't want them they can be easily moved when

<!-- chunk -->

## ready.

<!-- chunk -->

## Many variegated types of herbs, and decorative coloured herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## such as purple and golden sages, will not come true when grown

<!-- chunk -->

## from seed and so need to be propagated by other methods, such

<!-- chunk -->

## as cuttings or root division.

# Root Division

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs that form good clumps are excellent candidates for root

<!-- chunk -->

## division. In fact, for best results, herbs such as irises, valerian,

<!-- chunk -->

## lemon balm, elecampane and yarrow need to be divided every 3–

<!-- chunk -->

## 4 years into smaller clumps. Root division is best done in autumn

<!-- chunk -->

## or early spring. First cut back the top growth and dig up the

<!-- chunk -->

## entire plant with a fork. Carefully divide the clump with your

<!-- chunk -->

## hands into several pieces, each retaining a good system of roots,

<!-- chunk -->

## and replant where you have chosen. If the clump is too solid to

<!-- chunk -->

## divide with your hands you will need to use a garden fork. Dig

<!-- chunk -->

## the fork into the middle of the clump and lever it about, forcing

<!-- chunk -->

## the clump to separate.

# Taking Cuttings

<!-- chunk -->

## Taking cuttings from established plants is an easy way to

<!-- chunk -->

## propagate herbs and can be very rewarding. Softwood, semi-ripe

<!-- chunk -->

## and hardwood cuttings can be taken depending on the plant. Soft

<!-- chunk -->

## tip cuttings are generally successful with most herbaceous

<!-- chunk -->

## perennials, while semi-ripe and hardwood cuttings are suitable

<!-- chunk -->

## for shrubs and small trees.

<!-- chunk -->

### Prick out the seedlings once they

<!-- chunk -->

### have developed their first true leaves,

<!-- chunk -->

### transferring them into individual

<!-- chunk -->

### pots.

<!-- chunk -->

## Full sun

<!-- chunk -->

## Lavender, basil, rosemary, coriander, sage, hyssop, thyme,

<!-- chunk -->

## marjoram.

<!-- chunk -->

## Dappled shade

<!-- chunk -->

## Angelica, mint, fennel, lemon balm, ground ivy.

<!-- chunk -->

## Shade

<!-- chunk -->

## Valerian, sweet violet.

<!-- chunk -->

## Moist loam

<!-- chunk -->

## Angelica, elecampane, meadowsweet, mints, valerian, lady's

<!-- chunk -->

## mantle, lemon balm, skullcap, sweet violet.

<!-- chunk -->

## Well drained loam

<!-- chunk -->

## Lavender, basil, coriander, marjoram, wood betony, hyssop,

<!-- chunk -->

## rosemary, burdock, thyme, sage, dill, fennel, lady's mantle.

<!-- chunk -->

## Chalky soil

<!-- chunk -->

## Hyssop, lavender, marjoram, motherwort, pasque flower,

<!-- chunk -->

## rosemary.

<!-- chunk -->

## Light sandy soil

<!-- chunk -->

## Chamomile, coriander, evening primrose, fennel, lavender,

<!-- chunk -->

## thyme, wild carrot, marjoram.

<!-- chunk -->

## Clay soil

<!-- chunk -->

## Burdock, mints, wormwood. Other plants will grow well in

<!-- chunk -->

## clay if there is adequate top soil, with reasonable drainage

<!-- chunk -->

## loam and moist loam.

<!-- chunk -->

## Marshy ground

<!-- chunk -->

## Horsetail, mints, iris, marshmallow, meadowsweet, skullcap,

<!-- chunk -->

## valerian, angelica.

<!-- chunk -->

## When taking cuttings, gently tear a small side-shoot off a stem

<!-- chunk -->

## so that it has a heal on it, or cut the shoot's stem just below a leaf

<!-- chunk -->

## joint using a sharp knife 2-4″/5–10cm long. Remove the lower

<!-- chunk -->

## leaves and insert into holes made with a pencil, stick or dibber

<!-- chunk -->

## around the edge of a pot of cutting compost, or a mixture of peat

<!-- chunk -->

## and sand. You may wish to dip the end into hormone rooting

<!-- chunk -->

## powder first. Firm the soil around the cuttings and water it well.

<!-- chunk -->

## Once you detect signs of new growth at the tip, lift each cutting

<!-- chunk -->

## gently using your fingers or your dibber and plant up in

<!-- chunk -->

## individual pots, disturbing the new roots as little as possible.

# Softwood cuttings

<!-- chunk -->

## These are best taken in spring and early summer from healthy

<!-- chunk -->

## looking plants. Once inserted around the edge of your pot or

<!-- chunk -->

## tray, spray the cuttings with water using a plant spray and cover

<!-- chunk -->

## with a plastic propagator lid, a sheet of polythene or an inflated

<!-- chunk -->

## plastic bag to retain the moisture. Roots develop quickly on

<!-- chunk -->

## softwood cuttings, generally within 3–6 weeks, but it can be just

<!-- chunk -->

## a few days in warm conditions. Root development stimulates leaf

<!-- chunk -->

## growth, so you will know roots are formed when you see tiny

<!-- chunk -->

## new leaves shooting at the growing tip. Once the root system has

<!-- chunk -->

## had a chance to establish itself the cutting can be gently lifted and

<!-- chunk -->

## potted up in an individual pot or planted in a nursery bed.

<!-- chunk -->

## Generally speaking, cuttings are best kept during their first

<!-- chunk -->

## winter in pots in a sheltered area, a greenhouse or plastic tunnel

<!-- chunk -->

## in cold areas, and planted out in their positions the following

<!-- chunk -->

## spring.

<!-- chunk -->

### Take softwood cuttings just below a

<!-- chunk -->

### leaf joint, remove the lower leaves

<!-- chunk -->

### and insert into cutting compost.

# Semi-ripe cuttings

<!-- chunk -->

## These are taken in summer when stems are harder as they ripen

<!-- chunk -->

## at the base but are still flexible. Side-shoots are taken off the new

<!-- chunk -->

## growth, torn away from the main stem leaving a little heal of

<!-- chunk -->

## older wood. Once inserted in pots or trays and watered in, they

<!-- chunk -->

## are also best covered with plastic or polythene to retain moisture,

<!-- chunk -->

## but it is not absolutely vital as they are more resilient than

<!-- chunk -->

## softwood cuttings. Keep in pots in a cold frame or a sheltered

<!-- chunk -->

## area of the garden out of direct sunlight until growth starts the

<!-- chunk -->

## following spring, as rooting takes considerably longer than

<!-- chunk -->

## softwood cuttings.

# Hardwood cuttings

<!-- chunk -->

## These are taken from shrubby herbs or trees such as witch hazel,

<!-- chunk -->

## rosemary, hawthorn and cramp bark in autumn, once the plant is

<!-- chunk -->

## dormant. Take a side shoot of the current year's growth up to

<!-- chunk -->

## 12″/30cm, remove lower leaves and insert half their length in

<!-- chunk -->

## compost in light soil in the garden in a sheltered position. Firm

<!-- chunk -->

## the soil around the cutting and water well. Leave in position for

<!-- chunk -->

## around a year until a good root system is developed.

# Root cuttings or offsets

<!-- chunk -->

## This is the ideal method of propagation for herbs that have

<!-- chunk -->

## running roots or that send up side-shoots around the main plant,

<!-- chunk -->

## such as yarrow, chamomile, elecampane, and mint. Cut the

<!-- chunk -->

## spreading roots or runners from the parent plant at the end of

<!-- chunk -->

## summer or early autumn. Cut the root into small pieces approx

<!-- chunk -->

## 2″/5cm long and put them flat on top of a compost with a little

<!-- chunk -->

## sand in a seed tray. Cover with a plastic bag or sheet of plastic

<!-- chunk -->

## and leave in a cold frame, greenhouse, plastic tunnel or sheltered

<!-- chunk -->

## part of the garden. Once new shoots appear, remove the plastic

<!-- chunk -->

## bag and plant out.

<!-- chunk -->

### Chamomile can be partially covered

<!-- chunk -->

### with soil in the centre so that, once

<!-- chunk -->

### rooted, new plants can be separated

<!-- chunk -->

### off.

# Layering

<!-- chunk -->

## Low growing and shrubby herbs such as sage, thyme, lavender

<!-- chunk -->

## and periwinkle can be propagated by layering. Take a low

<!-- chunk -->

## growing branch and fix it with a peg or a stone in contact with

<!-- chunk -->

## the soil. If you nick the underside of the branch it will root more

<!-- chunk -->

## readily. Once a root has developed you can separate the thus

<!-- chunk -->

## formed new plant, dig it up and replant.

# Mounding

<!-- chunk -->

## Spreading herbs such as chamomile, thyme and marjoram can be

<!-- chunk -->

## partially covered with soil in their centre, thus bringing many

<!-- chunk -->

## different parts of the plant in contact with the soil so that, once

<!-- chunk -->

## rooted, lots of new plants can be separated off.

# Harvesting Herbs

# When harvesting herb plants it is important to

# establish first which part of the plant you need,

# whether that be the leaves, flowers, root, rhizome

# or seeds, and when is the best time to harvest that

# required part. Choose plants that look as healthy

# and vibrant as possible, so they are free from

# disease and infestation.

<!-- chunk -->

## Make sure they are growing well away from areas that have been

<!-- chunk -->

## sprayed or polluted by traffic, industry or animals. Only pick the

<!-- chunk -->

## amount of herb that you need at any one time, as they will easily

<!-- chunk -->

## spoil and be wasted otherwise. Harvest just a few leaves and

<!-- chunk -->

## flowers from each plant so as not to threaten the health or

<!-- chunk -->

## survival of any one plant.

# Leaves and Flowers

<!-- chunk -->

## Aromatic leaves of herbs, e.g. basil, thyme, sage, mint and lemon

<!-- chunk -->

## balm are best harvested when the flowers are about to open as

<!-- chunk -->

## the essential oil content is highest at that period. Flowers and

<!-- chunk -->

## flowering tops such as St John's wort, agrimony, goldenrod,

<!-- chunk -->

## yarrow, skullcap and hyssop are best picked as they are about to

<!-- chunk -->

## burst into bloom. A flat basket is the best vessel to collect herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## in as it makes it easier to avoid bruising or crushing leaves or

<!-- chunk -->

## flowers. They should be collected on a dry day once the dew has

<!-- chunk -->

## dried. During the growing season leaves and flowers are best

<!-- chunk -->

## gathered and used fresh, ideally straight from the garden. At the

<!-- chunk -->

## same time, harvest some extra ones for drying or freezing to last

<!-- chunk -->

## through the winter months as the growing time for herbs is

<!-- chunk -->

## relatively short. Herbs that are particularly worth storing are

<!-- chunk -->

## those which could be useful for treating winter colds and coughs,

<!-- chunk -->

## for example hyssop, thyme, oregano, ground ivy and mullein,

<!-- chunk -->

## and for fevers, for example chamomile, yarrow and elderflowers.

<!-- chunk -->

## Fresh herbs for use in the kitchen, such as coriander leaves, mint,

<!-- chunk -->

## sage, marjoram, rosemary, basil and fennel, can be picked

<!-- chunk -->

## throughout the growing season.

# Seeds

<!-- chunk -->

## Seeds such as dill, coriander and fennel need to be caught when

<!-- chunk -->

## ripe, before they drop. You can cut off the whole flower head

<!-- chunk -->

## when harvesting them, tie it up in muslin or a paper bag with

<!-- chunk -->

## string or a rubber band and hang it upside down in a well

<!-- chunk -->

## ventilated dry room. As the flower head dries the seeds will

<!-- chunk -->

## conveniently drop into the bag. Store the seeds in envelopes, foil

<!-- chunk -->

## or small boxes with well fitting lids, and label clearly with the

<!-- chunk -->

## herb name and collection date.

# Roots and Rhizomes

<!-- chunk -->

## Roots and rhizomes, for example valerian, dandelion,

<!-- chunk -->

## elecampane, and burdock, are best harvested when the aerial

<!-- chunk -->

## parts have died down in autumn or before growing recommences

<!-- chunk -->

## in springtime, as they are richest in stored food at this time.

# Preserving Herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## The object of the drying process is to eliminate the moisture in

<!-- chunk -->

## the herb quickly, before it starts to die, so that it can be stored for

<!-- chunk -->

## a few months without deteriorating and retains its therapeutic

<!-- chunk -->

## properties.

# Harvesting and Preparing

<!-- chunk -->

## When harvesting flowers and leaves for storage make sure they

<!-- chunk -->

## are dry from rain or dew and pick them in the morning before

<!-- chunk -->

## the heat of the day reaches its peak. Use your fingers/hands to

<!-- chunk -->

## pick, unless stalks such as agrimony or yarrow are very tough, in

<!-- chunk -->

## which case you will need scissors. Pick gently, taking care not to

<!-- chunk -->

## bruise the plant.

<!-- chunk -->

## When lifting roots, dig them up with a garden fork, trying not

<!-- chunk -->

## to puncture the outer skin. Wash the soil off the roots and cut off

<!-- chunk -->

## any leaves left, then chop up into sections or slices to speed

<!-- chunk -->

## drying and lie them out to dry. If bark is needed – as from witch-

<!-- chunk -->

## hazel or cramp bark – it is best to peel the bark off whole

<!-- chunk -->

## branches that have been pruned rather than shaving bark off

<!-- chunk -->

## branches on the tree, as it may not do the tree much good.

# Drying

<!-- chunk -->

## Providing that herbs are dried properly, those dried at home are

<!-- chunk -->

## often of a much higher quality than shop-bought herbs in terms

<!-- chunk -->

## of colour, flavour and healing properties. Drying needs to occur

<!-- chunk -->

## as quickly and evenly as possible. Shade, air and constant

<!-- chunk -->

## warmth are all essential.

<!-- chunk -->

## The best place for drying herbs is a shaded, well-ventilated

<!-- chunk -->

## room, garden shed or barn, free from moisture or condensation.

<!-- chunk -->

## It is vital to avoid the kitchen, bathroom, utility room, sheds or

<!-- chunk -->

## garages if they are steamy or damp, as the herbs will not dry

<!-- chunk -->

## properly and will deteriorate. A steady temperature of about

<!-- chunk -->

## 90°F/32°C is ideal – such as an airing cupboard, above an aga or

<!-- chunk -->

## rayburn, or in a low oven with the door left open to allow water

<!-- chunk -->

## to evaporate and the circulation of air. If the atmosphere is too

<!-- chunk -->

## cold (below 72°F/22°C) the plants will reabsorb moisture from

<!-- chunk -->

## the air and take too long to dry.

<!-- chunk -->

## You can loosely tie aerial parts of herbs in small bunches by

<!-- chunk -->

## their stems, and hang them from a beam or a hook indoors. In

<!-- chunk -->

## warm, dry climates bunches of herbs can be hung up out of

<!-- chunk -->

## doors in the shade, or from a high ceiling in a warm room with

<!-- chunk -->

## the windows open. This may be rather an unpredictable way to

<!-- chunk -->

## dry herbs as the temperature varies so much through 24 hours.

<!-- chunk -->

## More reliable results may be obtained by spreading sprigs of

<!-- chunk -->

## herbs or pieces of bark/root or seed evenly over a tray, wire

<!-- chunk -->

## netting, box lid, fruit tray, drying frame, sheets of paper or

<!-- chunk -->

## muslin. Drying frames can be made fairly easily by stretching

<!-- chunk -->

## muslin or fine netting over a wooden frame, and are excellent for

<!-- chunk -->

## drying as they allow free circulation of air. Spread out the herbs

<!-- chunk -->

## so there is plenty of space between them and turn them

<!-- chunk -->

## frequently – once or twice on the first day, and once daily after

<!-- chunk -->

## that. Large leaved herbs such will dry more quickly if the leaves

<!-- chunk -->

## are stripped from their fleshy stems and the stems discarded.

<!-- chunk -->

## Always dry herbs separately – never mix with another species.

<!-- chunk -->

### Unless stalks are very tough, use your

<!-- chunk -->

### hands and fingers to pick herbs.

<!-- chunk -->

## Before storing herbs check that they are properly dry by seeing

<!-- chunk -->

## if they are brittle and rustle, crumble or snap easily between your

<!-- chunk -->

## fingers and thumb. If herbs are stored before they are completely

<!-- chunk -->

## dry they will reabsorb moisture from the atmosphere and

<!-- chunk -->

## deteriorate. It takes roughly 3–7 days for most herbs to dry.

# Freezing

<!-- chunk -->

## Some herbs, particularly those with soft leaves, such as

<!-- chunk -->

## marjoram, coriander, fennel, lemon balm, basil, and mint are

<!-- chunk -->

## ideal for freezing. Pick the leaves or flowers, wash them, and

<!-- chunk -->

## then place them in small plastic bags to freeze.

<!-- chunk -->

### The harvest.

# Storing

<!-- chunk -->

## Herbs are best stored in air-tight dark containers, wooden or

<!-- chunk -->

## cardboard boxes, paper bags or jars. Glass jars are ideally kept in

<!-- chunk -->

## a dark cupboard, as exposure to light will cause deterioration of

<!-- chunk -->

## the medicinal constituents of the herbs. Never store in plastic as it

<!-- chunk -->

## encourages condensation. Make sure to label the herbs clearly

<!-- chunk -->

## with their name, and the date they were harvested. Remove stalks

<!-- chunk -->

## and twigs from aerial parts of plants, and break roots, rhizomes

<!-- chunk -->

## and barks into small pieces before storing. Store seeds in packets

<!-- chunk -->

## in the fridge, or in air-tight jars.
